('67', 0, 8, 14, 521) Do not expect me to write another autobiography unless you would send me to prison for a fairly long term and procure the necessary permission to write it there.
('67', 0, 8, 15, 683) The papers can certainly be collected and printed.
('67', 0, 8, 16, 734) Mahadev can do it best.
('67', 0, 8, 17, 758) But he is overloaded with work.
('67', 0, 8, 18, 790) Nevertheless I shall see what is possible.
('67', 0, 8, 19, 833) I do hope C. F. Andrews was able to go to his sisters.
('67', 0, 8, 20, 888) Yes, it is good he proposed to stay there for two weeks.
('67', 0, 8, 21, 945) According to his cable, he should have started ere this reaches you.
('67', 0, 8, 22, 1014) But if he is still there, please tell him he can stay longer if he likes.
('67', 0, 8, 23, 1088) For the moment I am reconciled to the outdoor life.
('67', 0, 8, 24, 1140) Mira is absorbed in her garden work from early morning to late in the evening.
('67', 0, 8, 25, 1219) Do not expect any letter from her for some time.
('67', 0, 8, 26, 1268) You see, we are trying to become villagers but we are [far] from the thing.
('67', 0, 8, 27, 1344) She is the whole hogger among us all.
('67', 0, 8, 28, 1382) I am purposely not writing anything to C. F. A. as I expect he will have left before this is in your hands.

('67', 1, 6, 15, 2181) Let the bills come, they would be honoured nevertheless.
('67', 1, 6, 16, 2238) If you want me to send you cash please write.
('67', 1, 7, 17, 2284) I have told you in my wire that I could easily arrange for your examination in Bombay or Nagpur.
('67', 1, 7, 18, 2381) My impression is that there is the apparatus in Wardha also.
('67', 1, 7, 19, 2442) But if the friends there advise otherwise, their advice should be followed.
('67', 1, 7, 20, 2518) We were all glad to see Duncan 4. He does not look strong.
('67', 1, 7, 21, 2577) He will be here for two days.
('67', 1, 7, 22, 2607) Chandra is selfish.
('67', 1, 7, 23, 2627) She prefers to be on the floor from which there is no fall.
('67', 1, 7, 24, 2687) And she would watch the fun of my slipping from the bed down to the floor and probably having a bump on the forehead.
('67', 1, 7, 25, 2805) Tell her I shall succumb to none of her wiles.

('67', 2, 1, 2, 3145) 5. LETTER TO AMRIT KAUR
('67', 2, 2, 3, 3169) April 26, 1935
('67', 2, 3, 4, 3184) MY DEAR AMRIT,
('67', 2, 4, 5, 3199) I have your letter.
('67', 2, 4, 6, 3219) The sooner you go to Simla, the better.
('67', 2, 4, 7, 3259) You will do what work you can from there.
('67', 2, 4, 8, 3301) It is well to recognize your limitations.
('67', 2, 4, 9, 3343) Evidently both of you need the change.
('67', 2, 4, 10, 3382) Of course your yarn will be utilized.
('67', 2, 4, 11, 3420) You will have to spin for many months at the present rate before I can get a sari for Ba and a loin cloth for myself.
('67', 2, 4, 12, 3538) But that is not just now of consequence.
('67', 2, 4, 13, 3579) All that will come after your second training here.
('67', 2, 4, 14, 3631) It is a tragedy that you cannot find anyone in all Jullundur who knows all the processes.
('67', 2, 4, 15, 3721) When one comes to think of it, the progress of spinning among the so called cultured classes is very little.
('67', 2, 4, 16, 3830) Dalip Singh will find when he settles down to work among the Harijans that they have skill enough to earn a living but that as labourers they do not get employment as easily as the others and that as artisans they do not find customers for their wares.
('67', 2, 4, 17, 4083) No doubt improvement can be and should be made in their method of dealing with hide.
('67', 2, 4, 18, 4168) But this will follow his taking up the work.
('67', 2, 4, 19, 4213) He need not work as a representative of our organization.
('67', 2, 4, 20, 4271) He can work independently and yet get all the technical assistance he may need from us to the extent of our capacity.
('67', 2, 4, 21, 4389) The rain did interfere with our work at Indore but not much.
('67', 2, 4, 22, 4450) It damaged the village crafts exhibition that was held as a side show.
('67', 2, 4, 23, 4521) The women’s meeting too went off quite nicely.
('67', 2, 4, 24, 4568) Thousands of them came out, many perhaps for the first time in their lives.
('67', 2, 5, 25, 4644) Yours, BAPU [PS.]
('67', 2, 6, 26, 4662) Letter returned.
('67', 2, 7, 27, 4679) From the original: C. W. 3530. Courtesy: Amrit Kaur.
('67', 2, 7, 28, 4732) Also G. N. 6339

('67', 3, 1, 2, 4788) 6. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('67', 3, 2, 3, 4817) April 26, 1935
('67', 3, 3, 4, 4832) NARANDAS, Enclosed is a letter from Mathew.
('67', 3, 3, 5, 4876) I have written to him and told him not to expect Rs. 65 at present.
('67', 3, 3, 6, 4944) He can’t be given anything more than what I mentioned.
('67', 3, 3, 7, 4999) I have also told him that just now he would have to join as no better than a labourer.
('67', 3, 3, 8, 5086) If he proves his worth, we may think further provided circumstances permit.
('67', 3, 3, 9, 5162) He may be given railway fare if anything is owing to him in the accounts here, otherwise he will have to find even that from where he is.
('67', 3, 3, 10, 5300) The prize of Rs. 1,00,000 has not been awarded to anybody.
('67', 3, 3, 11, 5359) But it may be awarded if a good enough model of spinning wheel is received.
('67', 3, 3, 12, 5435) I have still not received a copy of the resolution.
('67', 3, 3, 13, 5487) It contains three main points: that the model cannot be considered “handy”; that only a model which is small enough for a village house and can be easily lifted and moved whenever necessary can be considered “handy”; and that such a model cannot be manufactured within Rs. 150. Would it require frequent repairs?
('67', 3, 3, 14, 5800) And would the expenses on repairs exceed five per cent of the cost annually?
('67', 3, 3, 15, 5877) I enclose a copy of the specific defects pointed out by Vinoba and Kakasaheb.
('67', 3, 3, 16, 5955) If Keshu 1can remove these defects, let him do so.
('67', 3, 3, 17, 6006) Kale’s machine is not with me.
('67', 3, 3, 18, 6037) It had gone to Ahmedabad.
('67', 3, 3, 19, 6063) I have asked them to send it back.
('67', 3, 3, 20, 6098) But I may not get it back and, therefore, may not be able to have a look at it.
('67', 3, 3, 21, 6178) It is better that Keshu should remain there and go on with his experiment.
('67', 3, 3, 22, 6253) Let him stay with you.
('67', 3, 3, 23, 6276) He should fix a limit for the expenditure on the experiments.
('67', 3, 3, 24, 6338) If he wishes to come to me, he may certainly do so.
('67', 3, 3, 25, 6390) But I won’t be able to tell him anything more or guide him further.
('67', 3, 3, 26, 6458) There is nothing more to be explained about this experiment.
('67', 3, 3, 27, 6519) Even if his invention does not deserve a prize of Rs. 1,00,000, whatever improvements he discovers are bound to be useful.
('67', 3, 3, 28, 6642) If the machine for making slivers has been perfected, it is also a good thing.
('67', 3, 3, 29, 6721) Let him describe in detail what progress he has made with it.
('67', 3, 3, 30, 6783) Since I have explained everything in this letter, I am not writing separately to him.
('67', 3, 3, 31, 6869) You may now organize the school as you think best.
('67', 3, 4, 32, 6920) 1 Keshav Gandhi, Maganlal Gandhi’s son
('67', 4, 0, 1, 6959) VOL. 67 : 25 APRIL, 1935 22 SEPTEMBER, 1935 5
('67', 4, 1, 2, 7005) becomes a technical institute for our work, that would be excellent.
('67', 4, 1, 3, 7074) Languages should be taught from a different point of view altogether.
('67', 4, 1, 4, 7144) At present they are taught from a literary point of view.
('67', 4, 1, 5, 7202) We should teach them simply as languages.
('67', 4, 1, 6, 7244) The curriculum should include Gujarati, Hindi and English and a little bit of Sanskrit.
('67', 4, 1, 7, 7332) The pupils should be taught the Urdu script.
('67', 4, 1, 8, 7377) Instruction in these subjects should be easy.
('67', 4, 1, 9, 7423) They can be taught while the pupils learn crafts.
('67', 4, 1, 10, 7473) The crafts should be such as would bring the pupils some payment.
('67', 4, 1, 11, 7539) There should be no fee, the pupil’s earning through crafts being counted as fee.
('67', 4, 1, 12, 7620) Beyond a fixed limit, the earning would go to the pupil.
('67', 4, 1, 13, 7677) The fee should include all the expenses.
('67', 4, 1, 14, 7718) You can introduce these changes gradually without much trumpeting or publicity.
('67', 4, 1, 15, 7798) Find the staff locally, if possible.
('67', 4, 1, 16, 7835) There should be no highly paid teacher.
('67', 4, 1, 17, 7875) Kusum 1, Lilavati 2
('67', 4, 2, 18, 7895) and others who have got trained should be your staff.
('67', 4, 2, 19, 7949) If Keshu helps, nothing like it.
('67', 4, 2, 20, 7982) Think over this.
('67', 4, 2, 21, 7999) If you wish to discuss this matter further with me, you may do so.
('67', 4, 2, 22, 8066) Do something about the inspection of Titus’s 3 work and finish with it.
('67', 4, 3, 23, 8138) Blessings from BAPU

('67', 5, 4, 4, 8825) 8. DISCUSSION WITH J. P. BHANSALI 2
('67', 5, 5, 5, 8861) [Before April 27, 1935]
('67', 5, 6, 6, 8885) GANDHIJI: How much did you spin yesterday?
('67', 5, 7, 7, 8928) BHANSALI: Not at all, I am sorry to say.
('67', 5, 8, 8, 8969) G. But I thought you had started spinning?
('67', 5, 9, 9, 9012) B. I did about fifty yards the other day.
('67', 5, 9, 10, 9054) But that's all.
('67', 5, 10, 11, 9070) G. How nice it would be if you would make a loin cloth for me .
('67', 5, 10, 12, 9134) I should be very glad if you could make a pair, but even one would satisfy me.
('67', 5, 11, 13, 9213) B. It would be a rare privilege to be able to spin for your loin cloth, but you know my state of mind!
('67', 5, 12, 14, 9316) Next day again there was a talk.
('67', 5, 12, 15, 9349) With child like naivete he asked Gandhiji, “You do not want the loin cloth.
('67', 5, 12, 16, 9425) You want me to work.
('67', 5, 12, 17, 9446) Don't you?”
('67', 5, 13, 18, 9458) G. You are right.
('67', 5, 13, 19, 9476) But if you must work, why not do this thing for me?
('67', 5, 14, 20, 9528) B. If I must work, why not command me to do some other work?
('67', 5, 14, 21, 9589) I am not worthy to do this sacred thing for you.
('67', 5, 15, 22, 9638) G. But surely those who spun for the cloth I am wearing were by no means purer than you.
('67', 5, 16, 23, 9727) B. No, Bapu.
('67', 5, 16, 24, 9740) I am humbler than even the humblest, humbler than the dust of their feet.
('67', 5, 17, 25, 9814) Harijan, 27 4 1935
('67', 5, 18, 26, 9833) 2 The discussion is extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “Weekly Letter”.
('67', 5, 18, 27, 9901) 3 Mahadev Desai had concluded: “The next day old associaters like Kakasaheb tackled him.
('67', 5, 18, 28, 9990) Bhansali persisted in pleading his unworthiness.
('67', 5, 18, 29, 10039) ‘But’, said Kakasaheb, ‘supposing Bapu were to ask one of us to fetch a glass of water, and if all of us were to say to him, ‘we are sorry, Bapu, we have not the purity to do anything for you’, what would happen to Bapu?’ That seemed to go straight home.
('67', 5, 18, 30, 10294) Bhansali wrote (for he talks only to Gandhiji): ‘All right, then.
('67', 5, 18, 31, 10360) I spin.
('67', 5, 18, 32, 10368) I shall err on the safe side.’ And he is now regularly spinning.”
('67', 6, 0, 1, 10434) VOL. 67 : 25 APRIL, 1935 22 SEPTEMBER, 1935 7
('67', 6, 1, 2, 10480) 9. A GROWING VICE?
('67', 6, 2, 3, 10499) The Principal of the Sanatana Dharma College, Lahore, writes:
('67', 6, 3, 4, 10561) Allow me to request you to peruse the accompanying newspaper cutting, notices, etc., which speak for themselves.
('67', 6, 3, 5, 10674) The Youth Welfare Association is doing very useful work here in the Punjab.
('67', 6, 3, 6, 10750) It has attracted notice in academic and administrative quarters, while it has secured the active interest of enlightened guardians of boys.
('67', 6, 3, 7, 10890) Pandit Sitaram Das of Bihar is the leading spirit of this movement which counts very many distinguished people here among its patrons.
('67', 6, 4, 8, 11025) The evil of juvenile seduction is admittedly more rampant in the Punjab and North West Frontier Province than elsewhere in India.
('67', 6, 5, 9, 11155) May I pray that you will draw the attention of the country to this canker through a note or letter in Harijan or in any other newspaper?
('67', 6, 5, 10, 11292) The Secretary of the Youth League wrote to me long ago on this very delicate subject.
('67', 6, 5, 11, 11378) On receiving his letter I entered into correspondence with Dr. Gopichand 1 who confirmed the statements made in the League Secretary’s letter.
('67', 6, 5, 12, 11521) But I could not see my way clear to discussing the problem in these columns or elsewhere.
('67', 6, 5, 13, 11611) I had known of the evil but was not sure that a newspaper discussion could deal with it to any purpose.
('67', 6, 5, 14, 11715) Nor am I sure now.
('67', 6, 5, 15, 11734) But I may not resist the appeal of the Principal of the College.
('67', 6, 5, 16, 11799) The vice is not new.
('67', 6, 5, 17, 11820) It is widespread.
('67', 6, 5, 18, 11838) As it is necessarily kept secret, it is not possible to detect it easily.
('67', 6, 5, 19, 11912) It goes hand in hand with easy life.
('67', 6, 5, 20, 11949) In the case referred to by the Principal, the teachers are alleged to be the corruptors of their own wards.
('67', 6, 5, 21, 12057) “When the salt loses its savour wherewith shall it be salted?” This is a matter which no commission, no government can deal with successfully.
('67', 6, 5, 22, 12200) It is the function of the moral reformer.
('67', 6, 5, 23, 12242) The parents have to be awakened to a sense of their responsibility.
('67', 6, 5, 24, 12310) The students should be brought in close touch with clean life.
('67', 6, 5, 25, 12373) The idea that ethics and clean living are the foundation of true education, should be seriously propagated.
('67', 6, 5, 26, 12481) Trustees of educational institutions have to exercise the greatest care in the selection of teachers, and having selected them they have to see to it that they remain up to the mark.
('67', 6, 5, 27, 12664) These are some of the ways in which the awful vice can be brought under control even if it cannot be eradicated.
('67', 6, 6, 28, 12777) Harijan, 27 4 1935
('67', 6, 7, 29, 12796) 1 Dr. Gopichand Bhargava, a Congress leader of the Punjab and later a Minister
('67', 7, 0, 1, 12875) 8 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('67', 8, 1, 10, 14941) If you have decided to engage that lady, then some portion of the upper storey of the old bungalow or of the new one in which you are now living should be spared for cases of delivery.
('67', 8, 1, 11, 15126) But before taking in such cases, she should visit the women in their homes and examine ordinary cases, give them medicines, meet village women, and so on.

('67', 9, 5, 14, 16613) 13. LETTER TO G. D. BIRLA
('67', 9, 6, 15, 16639) April 27, 1935
('67', 9, 7, 16, 16654) BHAI GHANSHYAMDAS, I have made mention to you of Sharma from Khurja.
('67', 9, 7, 17, 16723) He has some familiarity with nature cure.
('67', 9, 7, 18, 16765) I have known him for years.
('67', 9, 7, 19, 16793) He intends to gain some experience at Battle Creek and later visit some nature cure clinics of Europe, spending in all one and a half years.

('67', 10, 2, 3, 17922) SHARMA,
('67', 10, 3, 4, 17930) What is this?
('67', 10, 3, 5, 17944) The matter was trivial but pregnant with great import.
('67', 10, 3, 6, 17999) I did take note of what you said.
('67', 10, 3, 7, 18033) The load was more than you could carry and you needed assistance.
('67', 10, 3, 8, 18099) This was what pained me.
('67', 10, 3, 9, 18124) We are poor people; why need we carry so much luggage?
('67', 10, 3, 10, 18179) You did not need anything beyond a book, a blanket, a towel, a lota, a bowl, a sheet, a dhoti, a kurta and a cap.
('67', 10, 3, 11, 18293) Why did you bring more articles?
('67', 10, 3, 12, 18326) And since you had brought, you should have quietly called a porter and left, or you could have even left behind the excess luggage as I had suggested.
('67', 10, 3, 13, 18477) Neither Bhagwanji nor Kishoreprasad should have gone.
('67', 10, 3, 14, 18531) Both were busy but went to help you to carry the luggage.
('67', 10, 3, 15, 18589) That Kishoreprasad was also carrying letters is beside the point.
('67', 10, 3, 16, 18655) You had no reason at all to feel hurt.
('67', 10, 3, 17, 18694) You ought to have taken a lesson from the incident.
('67', 10, 3, 18, 18746) If even now you have learnt it, the incident will have served a useful purpose.

('67', 19, 11, 21, 31063) 34. A LETTER
('67', 19, 12, 22, 31076) April 30, 1935
('67', 19, 13, 23, 31091) Of course there are many ways of reaching God and yet all are derivable from the same source.
('67', 19, 13, 24, 31185) One who prays for the removal of untouchability may be doing more effective work than the one who goes among Harijans.

('67', 21, 1, 2, 32604) 37. NOTE TO SUMANGAL PRAKASH [April, 1935] 1
('67', 21, 2, 3, 32649) You took neem leaves pounded into pulp.
('67', 21, 2, 4, 32689) That may have made you feel hot.
('67', 21, 2, 5, 32722) Pounded leaves is not the same thing as the juice of the leaves.
('67', 21, 2, 6, 32787) They are as different as polished rice is from unpolished rice.
('67', 21, 2, 7, 32851) The leaves should not be strained.
('67', 21, 2, 8, 32886) I used to strain the vegetables a little when I was taking vegetable juice.
('67', 21, 2, 9, 32962) That way you will not get the feeling of heat.
('67', 21, 2, 10, 33009) You may take as much tamarind as you may find necessary.
('67', 21, 2, 11, 33066) If you want to take a little more you may do so.
('67', 21, 2, 12, 33115) Milk will satisfy the hunger.
('67', 21, 2, 13, 33145) The quantity of the milk cannot be increased too soon.
('67', 21, 2, 14, 33200) If green vegetable is palatable you may take five tolas to begin with.
('67', 21, 2, 15, 33271) Once you are able to digest it you may increase the quantity by five tolas at a times, going up to 20 tolas.
('67', 21, 2, 16, 33380) This should be taken thrice.
('67', 21, 2, 17, 33409) You do get goat’s milk at 10.30 and fresh cow’s milk in the morning and evening.
('67', 21, 3, 18, 33490) From the Hindi original: Sumangal Prakash Papers.
('67', 21, 3, 19, 33540) Courtesy: Nehru Memorial Museum and Library

('67', 22, 2, 3, 34254) May 1, 1935
('67', 22, 3, 4, 34266) MY DEAR AGATHA,
('67', 22, 4, 5, 34282) If it was possible, for your sake, to send somebody to London I would do so.
('67', 22, 4, 6, 34359) But I see that it cannot be done at present.
('67', 22, 4, 7, 34404) Rajaji will not look at the proposal 1 nor would anyone else.
('67', 22, 4, 8, 34466) There never has been within living memory such unbending attitude on the part of the Government one sees now.
('67', 22, 4, 9, 34576) It is the naked sword that is being dangled before India at the present moment.
('67', 22, 4, 10, 34656) I regard it as a trial from above.
('67', 22, 4, 11, 34691) If we have real love, i.e., ahimsa in us, all will be well.
('67', 22, 4, 12, 34751) If we have not and we have used it merely as a cloak, the naked sword is well deserved.
('67', 22, 4, 13, 34839) Anyway the mentality being as I have described it, no one of the front rank think of going to England, so long as the policy persists.
('67', 22, 4, 14, 34974) I did read a paragraph about Sir Samuel’s illness.
('67', 22, 4, 15, 35025) But the reports did not give it any serious importance.
('67', 22, 4, 16, 35081) I therefore refrained from writing or cabling.

('67', 24, 1, 2, 37315) 43. LETTER TO G. RAMACHANDRAN
('67', 24, 2, 3, 37345) May 1, 1935
('67', 24, 3, 4, 37357) MY DEAR RAMACHANDRAN,
('67', 24, 4, 5, 37379) I have deliberately refrained hitherto from replying to your letter regarding Kanti.
('67', 24, 4, 6, 37464) I am now able to give you the reply.
('67', 24, 4, 7, 37501) The girl should know nothing about our intentions till she grows to maturity.
('67', 24, 4, 8, 37579) Kanti may harbour and the age of maturity hold any communication with her directly or indirectly [sic].
('67', 24, 4, 9, 37683) He may write as he is already writing to your sister but nothing of what he writes should be secret from you.
('67', 24, 4, 10, 37793) All his letters should be accessible to you if and whenever you desire.
('67', 24, 4, 11, 37865) Each has to be worthy of the other.
('67', 24, 4, 12, 37901) If, therefore, the girl has to be prepared for Kanti, Kanti has to prepare himself for being worthy of her and you.
('67', 24, 4, 13, 38017) If when the time for marriage comes, Kanti is found not to have progressed along the right lines, you are free to withhold the girl from his assuming of course that when she comes to maturity, she will listen to you.
('67', 24, 4, 14, 38234) For you and me the proposed union can be tolerated only if it becomes a pattern for others to copy.
('67', 24, 4, 15, 38334) It must therefore be developed in the spirit of service.
('67', 24, 4, 16, 38391) Development along this line must mean greater simplicity, greater self abnegation, greater advance towards truth and ahimsa, uttermost brahmacharya in thought and word and deed.
('67', 24, 4, 17, 38569) The contemplation of the girl must mean to Kanti exclusion of every other woman from his thought for the gratification of his sexual impulse.
('67', 24, 4, 18, 38711) If these conditions are fulfilled, I should welcome the union.
('67', 24, 4, 19, 38774) There is nothing wrong, as it seems to me, from the inception.
('67', 24, 4, 20, 38837) Kanti honestly confessed as soon as he felt drawn to the girl.
('67', 24, 4, 21, 38900) His subsequent conduct too has appeared to me to have been free from reproach, This will be seen by Kanti who will send it to you.
('67', 24, 4, 22, 39031) If there is anything in my letter of which you disapprove please let me know, I am asking Kanti to send a copy of this to Devdas.
('67', 24, 4, 23, 39161) Of course Mahadev will see this as also Harilal.
('67', 24, 4, 24, 39210) Enclosed 1 is for your sister.
('67', 24, 5, 25, 39241) From a copy: C.W. 9742. Courtesy, Kantilal Gandhi
('67', 24, 6, 26, 39291) 1 Vide the preceding item

('67', 26, 2, 3, 40800) May 1, 1935 CHI.
('67', 26, 2, 4, 40817) VIDYAVATI,
('67', 26, 3, 5, 40828) Why are you making yourself miserable?
('67', 26, 3, 6, 40867) When you want to die a heroic death and tread the path of the brave, how can you show such weakness of heart?
('67', 26, 3, 7, 40977) You must display heroism under all conditions.
('67', 26, 3, 8, 41024) When one is afflicted with sickness, there are more occasions to show courage.
('67', 26, 3, 9, 41103) She is a true heroine who does not forget God in pain, shows a concern for the nurse, is content with whatever nursing she gets, takes the least amount of service and is always prepared to embrace death.
('67', 26, 3, 10, 41307) Being roused to battle and die is heroism of an inferior kind.
('67', 26, 3, 11, 41370) I am sending a telegram to Dr. Roy today.
('67', 26, 3, 12, 41412) Whatever happens, you will not show anger or condemn anyone.
('67', 26, 3, 13, 41473) You are not going to leave the Seva Sadan in a hurry.
('67', 26, 3, 14, 41527) Send a comforting letter to Tara.
('67', 26, 3, 15, 41561) Tell her not to cry.
('67', 26, 3, 16, 41582) If you smile even in your moment of sorrow, others will not cry either.

('67', 27, 8, 11, 42541) 49. FOREWORD TO “GUJARAT AND ITS LITERATURE”
('67', 27, 9, 12, 42586) [Before May 2, 1935] 1
('67', 27, 10, 13, 42609) The only reason for inviting me to write a Foreword to a literary work such as Shri Munshi’s can be that I am called ‘Mahatma’.
('67', 27, 10, 14, 42737) I can make no literary pretensions.
('67', 27, 10, 15, 42773) My acquaintance with Gujarati and for that matter any literature, is, for no fault of mine, next to nothing.
('67', 27, 10, 16, 42882) Having led a life of intense action since early youth I have had no opportunity of reading except in prisons whether in South Africa or in India.
('67', 27, 10, 17, 43028) Shri Munshi’s survey of Gujarati literature has made fascinating reading for me.
('67', 27, 10, 18, 43109) His miniature pen portraits of writers give one a fair introduction to their writings.
('67', 27, 10, 19, 43196) Shri Munshi’s estimate of our literary achievement appears to me to be very faithful.
('67', 27, 10, 20, 43282) The survey naturally confines itself to the language understood and spoken by the middle class.
('67', 27, 10, 21, 43378) Commercially minded and self satisfied, their language has naturally been ‘effeminate and sensuous’.
('67', 27, 10, 22, 43479) Of the language of the people we know next to nothing.
('67', 27, 10, 23, 43534) We hardly understand their speech.
('67', 27, 10, 24, 43569) The gulf between them and us, the middle class, is so great that we do not know them and they know still less of what we think and speak.
('67', 27, 10, 25, 43707) The dignified persistence of Shri Devendra Satyarthi, a writer whom I do not remember to have ever met, has made me peep into his
('67', 27, 11, 26, 43837) 1 Vide “Letter to K. M. Munshi”, 2 5 1935
('67', 28, 0, 1, 43879) VOL. 67 : 25 APRIL, 1935 22 SEPTEMBER, 1935 29
('67', 28, 1, 2, 43926) remarkable collection of folk songs of the provinces he has been travelling in.
('67', 28, 1, 3, 44006) They are the literature of the people.
('67', 28, 1, 4, 44045) The middle classes of the provinces to which the songs belong are untouched by them, even as we of Gujarat are untouched by the songs of folk, i.e., the language of the masses of Gujarat.
('67', 28, 1, 5, 44233) Meghani of the Saurashtra school has done folklore research in Kathiawar.
('67', 28, 1, 6, 44307) His researches show the gulf that exists between the language of the people and ours.
('67', 28, 2, 7, 44393) But the folklore belongs to an order of things that is passing away, if it has not already done so.
('67', 28, 2, 8, 44493) There is an awakening among the masses.
('67', 28, 2, 9, 44533) They have begun not with thought but with action, as I suppose they always do.
('67', 28, 2, 10, 44612) Their language has yet to take definite shape.
('67', 28, 2, 11, 44659) It is to be found somewhat, but only somewhat, in the newspapers, not in books.
('67', 28, 2, 12, 44739) Shri Munshi's work therefore may be said to have only commenced with the volume before me.
('67', 28, 2, 13, 44830) It was necessary.
('67', 28, 2, 14, 44848) But he has to continue the work so well begun.
('67', 28, 2, 15, 44895) He has the requisite passion for his work.
('67', 28, 2, 16, 44938) If he has health, he will now go direct to the people and find out what they are thinking, and he will give expression to their thoughts.
('67', 28, 2, 17, 45076) The unquestionable poverty of Gujarati is a token of the poverty of the people.
('67', 28, 2, 18, 45156) But no language is really poor.
('67', 28, 2, 19, 45188) We have hardly had time to speak since we have begun to act.
('67', 28, 2, 20, 45249) Gujarat like the rest of India is brooding.
('67', 28, 2, 21, 45293) The language is shaping itself.
('67', 28, 2, 22, 45325) There is enough work awaiting writers like our author.
('67', 28, 2, 23, 45380) Munshi has alluded to Parsi Gujarati.
('67', 28, 2, 24, 45418) So there is.
('67', 28, 2, 25, 45431) It is unfortunate that there is Parsi Gujarati.
('67', 28, 2, 26, 45479) It is confined to novels and stories of the shilling shocker style.
('67', 28, 2, 27, 45547) They are meant merely for passing the idle hour.
('67', 28, 2, 28, 45596) The language is tortured out of shape.
('67', 28, 2, 29, 45635) And just as there is Parsi Gujarati there is also Muslim Gujarati though on a much humbler scale.
('67', 28, 2, 30, 45733) It is impossible to ignore these two streams.
('67', 28, 2, 31, 45779) They are not wells of Gujarati undefiled.
('67', 28, 2, 32, 45821) But no reviewer of Gujarati literature can afford to ignore the existence of works which hundreds, if not thousands, of Parsis and Muslims read and by which, maybe, even shape part of their conduct.
('67', 28, 3, 33, 46020) M. K. GANDHI
('67', 28, 4, 34, 46033) Gujarat and Its Literature

('67', 29, 11, 18, 46611) BHAI MUNSHI, I had got your letter.

('67', 32, 6, 10, 51778) 57. TWO GOOD RESOLUTIONS
('67', 32, 7, 11, 51803) The Hindi Sahitya Sammelan, recently held at Indore, passed some useful resolutions.
('67', 32, 7, 12, 51888) Among them was one giving a definition of Hindi, and another expressing the opinion that all the languages that had descended from or had been largely influenced by Sanskrit should be written in the Devanagari script.
('67', 32, 8, 13, 52106) The first resolution is designed to emphasize the fact that Hindi does not supplant the provincial languages, that it supplements them, and that it extends the knowledge and usefulness of the speaker as an all India worker.
('67', 32, 8, 14, 52330) By recognizing the fact that the language written in the Urdu script but understood both by Mussalmans and Hindus is also Hindi, the Sammelan disarms the suspicion that it has any design upon the Urdu script.
('67', 32, 8, 15, 52539) The authorized script of the Sammelan still remains Devanagari.
('67', 32, 8, 16, 52603) The propagation of the Devanagari script among the Hindus of the Punjab, as elsewhere, will still continue.
('67', 32, 8, 17, 52711) The resolution in no way detracts from the value of the Devanagari script.
('67', 32, 8, 18, 52786) It recognizes the right of Mussalmans to write the language in the Urdu script as they have done hitherto.
('67', 32, 8, 19, 52893) In order to give practical effect to the second resolution, a committee was appointed with Kakasaheb Kalelkar as Chairman and Convener, to explore the possibility of such introduction and to make
('67', 32, 9, 20, 53089) 1 This was a postscript to Mahadev Desai’s letter to the addressee informing him of a bookshop at Lahore and advising him on behalf of Gandhiji to purchase the books he needed through Dr. Gopichand Bhargava so as to get a discount on the price.
('67', 33, 0, 1, 53334) 34 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('67', 33, 1, 2, 53375) such changes and additions in the Devanagri script as may be necessary to make it easier to write and more perfect than it is so as to represent the sounds not expressed by the existing letters.
('67', 33, 2, 3, 53570) Such a change is necessary if interprovincial contacts are to increase and if Hindi is to be the medium of communication between provinces.
('67', 33, 2, 4, 53710) The second was ever an accepted proposition for the past twenty five years with those who subscribe to the creed of the Hindi Sahitya Sammelan.
('67', 33, 2, 5, 53854) The question of script has often been discussed but never seriously tackled.
('67', 33, 2, 6, 53931) And yet it seems to be a natural corollary to the first proposition.
('67', 33, 2, 7, 54000) Learning sister languages becomes incredibly simple and easy.
('67', 33, 2, 8, 54062) Gitanjali, written in the Bengali script, is a sealed book to everyone except the Bengalis.
('67', 33, 2, 9, 54154) It is almost an open book when it is written in the Devanagari script.
('67', 33, 2, 10, 54225) There is in it a vast number of words derived from Sanskrit and easily understood by the people of the other provinces.
('67', 33, 2, 11, 54345) Everyone can test the truth of this statement.
('67', 33, 2, 12, 54392) We ought not unnecessarily to tax the future generations with the trouble of having to learn different scripts.
('67', 33, 2, 13, 54504) It is cruel to require a person desiring to learn Tamil, Telugu, Malayalam, Kanarese, Oriya and Bengali to learn six scripts, besides Devanagari, let alone the Urdu script if he would know what the Muslim brethren are saying and doing through their writings.
('67', 33, 2, 14, 54763) I have not presented an ambitious programme for a lover of his country or humanity.
('67', 33, 2, 15, 54847) Today the impenetrable barrier of different scripts has made the learning of sister languages and the learning of Hindi by the sister provinces a needlessly heavy task.
('67', 33, 2, 16, 55016) It will be for Kakasaheb’s committee on the one hand to educate and canvass public opinion in favour of the reform, and on the other to demonstrate by practical application its great utility in saving the time and energy of those who would learn Hindi or the provincial languages.
('67', 33, 2, 17, 55297) Let no one run away with the idea that the reform will diminish the importance of the provincial languages.
('67', 33, 2, 18, 55405) Indeed it can only enrich them even as the adoption of a common script has enriched the languages of Europe by making intercourse between its provinces easy.
('67', 33, 3, 19, 55563) Harijan, 4 5 1935
('67', 34, 0, 1, 55581) VOL. 67 : 25 APRIL, 1935 22 SEPTEMBER, 1935 35
('67', 34, 1, 2, 55628) 58. HOW TO DOUBLE INCOME
('67', 34, 2, 3, 55653) Though the spinning movement has been going on for the past seventeen years, and though it is giving a small but steady income to at least 1,20,000 women from year to year, the deplorable ignorance of the science of spinning on the part of workers keeps the income lower than it need be.
('67', 34, 2, 4, 55941) Bad cotton, badly carded and spun on a rickety wheel without regard to the revolutions of the spindle, results in a low output.
('67', 34, 2, 5, 56069) Attention to details can easily double the output and therefore the income.
('67', 34, 2, 6, 56145) If cotton is carefully picked, hand ginned and well carded, there will be an increased output and improvement in the strength and evenness of yarn.
('67', 34, 2, 7, 56293) Speed, strength, evenness and count of yarn depend perhaps most upon the number of revolutions of the spindle, i.e., the turns a spindle makes for every turn of the wheel.
('67', 34, 2, 8, 56465) The calculation is easily made by drawing a vertical line on the spindle disc and turning the wheel so slowly as to enable one easily to count the turns of the spindle.
('67', 34, 2, 9, 56634) A spindle should never have less than one hundred revolutions against one of the wheels.
('67', 34, 2, 10, 56723) But Shri Shankerlal Banker reports that during his tour be noticed spindles performing only thirty five revolutions.
('67', 34, 2, 11, 56840) No wonder if the output is miserably low and the yarn weak and fluffy.
('67', 34, 2, 12, 56911) The way to increase the revolutions of a spindle is to decrease the diameter of the sari which keeps the mal in its place.
('67', 34, 2, 13, 57034) Local workers should examine every wheel in their place and make the necessary changes in the spindle and other parts, wherever necessary.
('67', 34, 2, 14, 57173) It may be that in the end the takli may be found to be the best instrument of yarn production.
('67', 34, 2, 15, 57268) It requires the least attention, and the new method of takli spinning gives an average speed of 200 rounds, i.e., 266 yards of yarn, and as much as 440 rounds per hour.
('67', 34, 3, 16, 57437) Harijan, 4 5 1935

('67', 42, 3, 6, 69997) 69. LETTER TO AVADHESH DUTT AVASTHI May 7, 1935
('67', 42, 4, 7, 70045) AVADHESH, Tulsidas himself has said that the name of Rama is greater than Rama, meaning that Rama, who transcends the body, is formless and nameless and is greater than Rama in body.
('67', 42, 4, 8, 70228) Rama was certainly the son of Dasharatha and the husband of Sita, but He is also the Purushottama of our imagination because the Unmanifest is not different from the Manifest.
('67', 42, 4, 9, 70404) Everything is a manifestation of the Unmanifest.
('67', 42, 4, 10, 70453) I don’t insist on the name Rama, it might be Omkar or Krishna, or Ishwar.
('67', 42, 4, 11, 70527) I do get angry, but I feel angry with myself for it.
('67', 42, 4, 12, 70580) Full conquest of anger is possible only through self realization.
('67', 42, 4, 13, 70646) We should love even those who have the worst opinion of us.
('67', 42, 4, 14, 70706) This is ahimsa, the rest is only ignorance.

('67', 47, 1, 2, 76762) 80. INTERVIEW TO A MISSIONARY NURSE 1
('67', 47, 2, 3, 76800) [Before May 11,1935]
('67', 47, 3, 4, 76821) [NURSE:] You have the reputation of never being angry.
('67', 47, 3, 5, 76876) Is that true?
('67', 47, 3, 6, 76890) [GANDHIJI:] It is not that I do not get angry.
('67', 47, 3, 7, 76937) I do not give vent to anger.
('67', 47, 3, 8, 76966) I cultivate the quality of patience as angerlessness, and generally speaking I succeed.
('67', 47, 3, 9, 77054) But I only control my anger when it comes.
('67', 47, 3, 10, 77097) How I find it possible to control it would be a useless question, for it is a habit that everyone must cultivate and must succeed in forming by constant practice.
('67', 47, 4, 11, 77260) When did you come to experience this great love for the poor?
('67', 47, 4, 12, 77322) Could you tell me the period or the occasion?
('67', 47, 4, 13, 77368) I have always had a love for the poor all my life and in abundance.
('67', 47, 4, 14, 77436) I could cite illustration after illustration from my past life to show that it was something innate in me.
('67', 47, 4, 15, 77543) I have never felt that there was any difference between the poor and me.
('67', 47, 4, 16, 77616) I have always felt toward them as my own kith and kin.
('67', 47, 5, 17, 77671) Don’t you have anything like antipathy for filth and dirt?
('67', 47, 5, 18, 77730) I have no antipathy against dirty people but I have a horror of dirt.
('67', 47, 5, 19, 77800) I should not eat out of a dirty plate nor touch a dirty spoon or kerchief.
('67', 47, 5, 20, 77875) But I believe in removing dirt to its proper place, where it ceases to be dirt.
('67', 47, 6, 21, 77955) I do feel that whilst it is bad to encourage begging, I will not send away a beggar without offering him work and food.
('67', 47, 6, 22, 78075) If he will not work, I should let him go without food.
('67', 47, 6, 23, 78130) Those who are physically disabled like the halt and the maimed and the blind have got to be supported by the State.
('67', 47, 6, 24, 78246) There is, however, a lot of fraud going on under cover of pretended blindness or even genuine blindness.
('67', 47, 6, 25, 78351) So many blind have become rich because of ill gotten gains.
('67', 47, 6, 26, 78411) It would be a good thing if they were taken to an asylum, rather than to be exposed to this temptation.
('67', 47, 7, 27, 78515) Would you prevent missionaries coming to India in order to baptize?
('67', 47, 7, 28, 78583) Who am I to prevent them?
('67', 47, 7, 29, 78609) If I had power and could legislate, I should certainly stop all proselytizing.
('67', 47, 7, 30, 78688) It is the cause of much avoidable conflict between classes and unnecessary heart burning
('67', 47, 8, 31, 78777) 1 This is extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “Weekly Letter”.
('67', 47, 8, 32, 78835) 2 Here Mahadev Desai had explained that “the visitor next discussed the question of beggary”.
('67', 48, 0, 1, 78929) VOL. 67 : 25 APRIL, 1935 22 SEPTEMBER, 1935 49
('67', 48, 1, 2, 78976) among missionaries.
('67', 48, 1, 3, 78996) But I should welcome people of any nationality if they came to serve here for the sake of service.
('67', 48, 1, 4, 79095) In Hindu households the advent of a missionary has meant the disruption of the family coming in the wake of change of dress, manners, language, food and drink.
('67', 48, 2, 5, 79255) Is it not the old conception you are referring to?
('67', 48, 2, 6, 79306) No such thing is now associated with proselytization.
('67', 48, 2, 7, 79360) The outward condition has perhaps changed but the inward mostly remains.
('67', 48, 2, 8, 79433) Vilification of Hindu religion, though subdued, is there.
('67', 48, 2, 9, 79491) If there was a radical change in the missionaries’ outlook, would Murdoch’s books be allowed to be sold in mission depots?
('67', 48, 2, 10, 79614) Are those books prohibited by missionary societies?
('67', 48, 2, 11, 79666) There is nothing but vilification of Hinduism in those books.
('67', 48, 2, 12, 79728) You talk of the conception being no longer there.
('67', 48, 2, 13, 79778) Only the other day a missionary descended on a famine area withmoney in his pocket, distributed it among the famine stricken, converted them to his fold, took charge of their temple and demolished it.
('67', 48, 2, 14, 79979) This is outrageous.
('67', 48, 2, 15, 79999) The temple could not belong to the converted Hindus, and it could not belong to the Christian missionary.
('67', 48, 2, 16, 80105) But this friend goes and gets it demolished at the hands of the very men who only a little while ago believed that God was there.
('67', 48, 3, 17, 80235) But, Mr. Gandhi, why do you object to proselytization as such?
('67', 48, 3, 18, 80298) Is not there enough in the Bible to authorize us to invite people to a better way of life?
('67', 48, 3, 19, 80389) Oh yes, but it does not mean that they should be made members of the Church.
('67', 48, 3, 20, 80466) If you interpret your texts in the way you seem to do, you straight away condemn a large part of humanity unless it believes as you do.
('67', 48, 3, 21, 80602) If Jesus came to earth again, he would disown many things that are being done in the name of Christianity.
('67', 48, 3, 22, 80709) It is not he who says “Lord, Lord” that is a Christian, but “He that doeth the will of the Lord” that is a true Christian.
('67', 48, 3, 23, 80832) And cannot he who has not heard the name of Jesus Christ do the will of the Lord?
('67', 48, 4, 24, 80914) Harijan, 11 5 1935.
('67', 49, 0, 1, 80934) 50 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('67', 49, 1, 2, 80975) 81. GROSS ILL TREATMENT
('67', 49, 2, 3, 80999) I was working in a cheri under the auspices of the Harijan Sevak Sangh for a period of about four months.
('67', 49, 2, 4, 81105) A Harijan was expelled from the cheri, before I began Harijan work in the village, on account of his moral delinquencies.
('67', 49, 2, 5, 81227) The said Harijan once returned to visit his son studying in our school.
('67', 49, 2, 6, 81299) I allowed him to stop with me for the purpose.
('67', 49, 2, 7, 81346) He was resting in the school shed on the particular night.
('67', 49, 2, 8, 81405) In my absence, a party consisting of five persons belonging to the Harijan class who were the near relatives of the woman seduced, along with a few others of the so called castemen, took him out and beat him severely for the old offence of seducing a married woman, and drove him out of the shed.
('67', 49, 2, 9, 81702) Immediately I learnt of the incident, I approached the persons who had taken the law into their own hands and protested against the maltreatment and demanded the re admission of the Harijan into the cheri.
('67', 49, 2, 10, 81908) This was refused.
('67', 49, 2, 11, 81926) Therefore, I have withdrawn myself from the village.
('67', 49, 2, 12, 81979) The foregoing is a much condensed summary of a long letter.
('67', 49, 2, 13, 82039) I do not vouch for the accuracy of the statement.
('67', 49, 2, 14, 82089) But if the facts are as stated, surely it was wrong altogether to beat the Harijan as he appears to have been beaten.
('67', 49, 2, 15, 82207) If he had committed any crime, he should have been prosecuted.
('67', 49, 2, 16, 82270) But no one had any right to take the law into his own hands.
('67', 49, 2, 17, 82331) The correspondent was right in retiring from the cheri which was not prepared to do simple justice.
('67', 49, 2, 18, 82431) I hope that the matter was brought to the notice of the local Sangh and that the latter had tried to secure fair treatment for the Harijan concerned.
('67', 49, 2, 19, 82581) The whole affair is one for careful investigation.
('67', 49, 2, 20, 82632) I fear that such cases are frequent enough.
('67', 49, 2, 21, 82676) It is up to Harijan sevaks on the one hand to afford protection to the injured and on the other to awaken their sense of morality where it is lacking.
('67', 49, 2, 22, 82827) The offenders do not belong to any particular class.
('67', 49, 2, 23, 82880) All sections are tarred with the same brush.
('67', 49, 2, 24, 82925) Only those workers who have proved their worth and are above reproach will be able to create any impression at all on the delinquents.
('67', 49, 3, 25, 83060) Harijan, 11 5 1935
('67', 49, 4, 26, 83079) 82. WELLS FOR HARIJANS
('67', 49, 5, 27, 83102) The Government of Bombay are to be congratulated upon their decision to build wells for Harijans in the Presidency of Bombay.
('67', 49, 5, 28, 83228) The sum set apart is a trifle for the work to be done.
('67', 49, 5, 29, 83283) As is well known, wells have been constructed for Harijans for years past in Gujarat by
('67', 50, 0, 1, 83371) VOL. 67 : 25 APRIL, 1935 22 SEPTEMBER, 1935 51
('67', 50, 1, 2, 83418) the late Anti untouchability Board set up by the Congress, and since 1932 by the Harijan Sevak Sangh.
('67', 50, 1, 3, 83520) The latter has an extensive programme of well building for Harijans, and Sjt.
('67', 50, 1, 4, 83598) Juthabhai, a quiet and great worker, has made up his mind to devote his attention to this noble humanitarian work.
('67', 50, 1, 5, 83713) It is greatly to be desired that in this work there would be perfect co ordination between the various agencies working towards the same end.
('67', 50, 1, 6, 83855) If co operative effort is not possible, there may be at least a division of labour and areas.
('67', 50, 1, 7, 83949) Whatever is done, the end should be quick work, good work and cheapest cost.
('67', 50, 1, 8, 84026) The last can be satisfied only if there is unskilled voluntary labour forthcoming either on the part of Harijan Hindus or savarna Hindus or both.
('67', 50, 2, 9, 84172) Harijan, 11 5 1935
('67', 50, 3, 10, 84191) 83. VILLAGE WORKER’S QUESTIONS
('67', 50, 4, 11, 84222) A village worker writes:
('67', 50, 5, 12, 84247) 1. I am working in a small village of a hundred houses.
('67', 50, 5, 13, 84303) You have said that attention to sanitation and hygiene should precede medical relief.
('67', 50, 5, 14, 84389) But what is a worker to do when a villager suffering from fever seeks aid?
('67', 50, 5, 15, 84464) I have been hitherto advising them to use indigenous herbs obtainable in the village bazaar.
('67', 50, 5, 16, 84557) 2. What is to be done with the night soil during the rains?
('67', 50, 5, 17, 84617) 3. Can night soil be used for all crops?
('67', 50, 5, 18, 84658) 4. What is the advantage of eating gur 1 in preference to sugar?
('67', 50, 5, 19, 84723) Where cases of fever, constipation or such common diseases come to village workers for help, they will certainly have to render such help as they can.
('67', 50, 5, 20, 84874) Where one is certain of the diagnosis, there is no doubt that the village bazaar medicine is the cheapest and best.
('67', 50, 5, 21, 84990) If one must stock drugs, castor oil, quinine and boiling water are the best medical agents.
('67', 50, 5, 22, 85082) Castor oil may be locally procurable.
('67', 50, 5, 23, 85120) The senna leaf may serve the same purpose.
('67', 50, 5, 24, 85163) Quinine one should use sparingly.
('67', 50, 5, 25, 85197) Every fever does not require quinine treatment.
('67', 50, 5, 26, 85245) Nor does every fever yield to quinine.
('67', 50, 5, 27, 85284) Most fevers will disappear after a fast or a semi fast.
('67', 50, 5, 28, 85340) Abstention from cereals, pulses and milk, and taking fruit juices or
('67', 50, 6, 29, 85409) 1 Jaggery
('67', 51, 0, 1, 85419) 52 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('67', 51, 1, 2, 85460) boiling raisin water, even boiling gur water with fresh lemon juice or tamarind, is a semi fast.
('67', 51, 1, 3, 85557) Boiling water is a most powerful medical agent.
('67', 51, 1, 4, 85605) It may move the bowels, it will induce perspiration and therefore abate fever; it is the safest and cheapest disinfectant.
('67', 51, 1, 5, 85728) In every case where it is required to be drunk, the water must be allowed to cool till it is fairly bearable to the skin.
('67', 51, 1, 6, 85850) Boiling does not mean mere heating.
('67', 51, 1, 7, 85886) The water begins to bubble and evaporate after it is on the boil.
('67', 51, 1, 8, 85952) Where the workers do not know for certain what to do, they must allow the local vaidya to have full sway.
('67', 51, 1, 9, 86058) Where he is non existent or unreliable and the workers know a philanthropic doctor nearby, they may invoke his assistance.
('67', 51, 1, 10, 86181) But they will find that the most effective way of dealing even with disease is to attend to sanitation.
('67', 51, 1, 11, 86285) Let them remember that nature is the finest physician.
('67', 51, 1, 12, 86340) They may be sure that nature is repairing what man has damaged.
('67', 51, 1, 13, 86404) She appears to have become powerless when man continuously hampers her.
('67', 51, 1, 14, 86476) Then she sends death—her last and peremptory agent to destroy what is beyond repair—and provides a fresh garment for the wearer.
('67', 51, 1, 15, 86605) Sanitary and hygienic workers are therefore the best helpers of the best physician every person has, whether he knows it or not.
('67', 51, 1, 16, 86734) 2. Even during the rains villagers should perform functions in places not trodden by man.
('67', 51, 1, 17, 86824) Faeces must be buried.
('67', 51, 1, 18, 86847) This is a most difficult question owing to the erroneous training of villagers.
('67', 51, 1, 19, 86927) In Sindi village we are trying to persuade the villagers not to use the streets, to go to the adjoining fields and to throw dry clean earth on their own evacuations.
('67', 51, 1, 20, 87093) After two months’ continuous labour and co operation of the municipal councillors and others, they have been good enough generally to cease to defile the streets.
('67', 51, 1, 21, 87256) They go to the fields which their owners have been good enough to open for such use.
('67', 51, 1, 22, 87341) But the villagers still obstinately refuse to throw earth on their own evacuations.
('67', 51, 1, 23, 87425) ‘Surely it is bhangi’s work; it is sinful to look at faeces, more so to throw earth on them’, they say.
('67', 51, 1, 24, 87529) They have been taught to believe so.
('67', 51, 1, 25, 87566) Workers have therefore not to write on a clean slate.
('67', 51, 1, 26, 87620) They have to rub off what is drawn into the slate with steel points.
('67', 51, 1, 27, 87689) But I know that if we have faith in our mission, if we have patience enough to persist in the work of daily morning scavenging and, above all, if we don’t get irritated against the villagers, their prejudice will disappear as mist before the rays of the sun.
('67', 51, 1, 28, 87948) Age hardened ignorance
('67', 52, 0, 1, 87971) VOL. 67 : 25 APRIL, 1935 22 SEPTEMBER, 1935 53
('67', 52, 1, 2, 88018) cannot yield to a few months’ object lessons.
('67', 52, 1, 3, 88064) We are preparing for the rains in Sindi.
('67', 52, 1, 4, 88105) Naturally the owners of fields must protect their crops.
('67', 52, 1, 5, 88162) They cannot, therefore, allow free access to their fields as many do now.
('67', 52, 1, 6, 88236) We have suggested to them that they should put up fences a few feet inside their boundaries, leaving the marks intact.
('67', 52, 1, 7, 88355) The few feet they may leave will by the end of the season be richly manured strips of their fields.
('67', 52, 1, 8, 88455) A time is coming when owners of fields will invite people to use them.
('67', 52, 1, 9, 88526) Every man constantly using a particular field leaves on it two rupees’ worth of manure in a year, if Dr. Fowler’s estimate may be accepted.
('67', 52, 1, 10, 88666) The accuracy of the figure may be doubted.
('67', 52, 1, 11, 88709) The fact that a field benefits by the deposit of night soil in it is beyond doubt.
('67', 52, 1, 12, 88792) 3. No one has suggested that night soil may be administered to crops directly as manure.
('67', 52, 1, 13, 88881) What is meant is that addition of night soil to earth enriches it after a fixed time.
('67', 52, 1, 14, 88967) Night soil after being received into the earth has to undergo certain changes before the earth becomes fit for ploughing and cultivation.
('67', 52, 1, 15, 89105) The test in infallible.
('67', 52, 1, 16, 89129) Open up the earth after a stated time where you have buried night soil.
('67', 52, 1, 17, 89201) If you find that it is all sweet earth and no smell, no trace to faeces, the soil is fit to receive the seed.
('67', 52, 1, 18, 89311) I have used night soil in this manner for all manner of crops for the past thirty years with the greatest benefit.
('67', 52, 1, 19, 89426) 4. It is the universal testimony of experts that gur is more nutritious than sugar because it contains salts and vitamins which sugar does not contain.
('67', 52, 1, 20, 89578) As whole wheat meal is to fine flour, or unpolished rice to polished, so practically is gur to sugar.
('67', 52, 1, 21, 89680) Harijan, 11 5 1935
('67', 52, 2, 22, 89699) 84. LETTER TO T. PRAKASAM
('67', 52, 3, 23, 89725) WARDHA, May 11, 1935
('67', 52, 4, 24, 89746) MY DEAR PRAKASAM,
('67', 52, 5, 25, 89764) I have gone through your note.
('67', 52, 5, 26, 89795) I believe in the system of barter.
('67', 52, 5, 27, 89830) It can apply only to village communities.
('67', 52, 5, 28, 89872) In its very nature it can work among small groups of men.
('67', 52, 5, 29, 89930) The village movement [if it] 1 succeeds, must result in villagers exchanging their goods.
('67', 52, 5, 30, 90020) It won't spread by preaching but it will by practising it wherever possible.
('67', 52, 6, 31, 90097) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI
('67', 52, 7, 32, 90127) From a photostat: G.N. 9245
('67', 52, 8, 33, 90155) 1 Very faint in the source

('67', 53, 8, 17, 90769) It is a difficult thing.

('67', 55, 3, 5, 92784) 89. LETTER TO AMRITLAL V. THAKKAR 1
('67', 55, 4, 6, 92820) May 11, 1935
('67', 55, 5, 7, 92833) BHAI THAKKAR BAPA, I have been prejudiced against S. 2 from the very beginning.
('67', 55, 5, 8, 92913) This work hasn’t seemed clean to me.
('67', 55, 5, 9, 92950) It might not perhaps be proper to give anything, against the advice of Shukla and others, from the amount realized through the sale of the cattle.
('67', 55, 5, 10, 93097) If, therefore, you have full faith in him, you may give him something from the money which is lying in my name.
('67', 55, 5, 11, 93209) I sent a wire yesterday regarding Malkani.
('67', 55, 5, 12, 93252) I had to send another today.
('67', 55, 5, 13, 93281) He had gone to Nalvadi to see the work being done there.
('67', 55, 5, 14, 93338) While returning from there, he was bit by something 3 in the darkness.
('67', 55, 5, 15, 93409) He was accompanied by.
('67', 55, 5, 16, 93432) and others.
('67', 55, 5, 17, 93444) They lifted him up and laid him .

('67', 55, 5, 19, 93539) An incision was made to let out blood.
('67', 55, 5, 20, 93578) The night passed fairly well.
('67', 55, 5, 21, 93608) He will have to remain in the hospital for two days at least.
('67', 55, 5, 22, 93670) Even apart from this, I felt that it is not desirable that neither of you should be present in Delhi.
('67', 55, 5, 23, 93772) Whatever has to be done on the basis of your observations during your visit.
('67', 55, 5, 24, 93849) What may have happened during your absence.
('67', 55, 5, 25, 93893) It is essential that a plan should be drawn up.
('67', 55, 5, 26, 93941) There is, of course .
('67', 55, 5, 27, 93963) about one well.

('67', 55, 5, 33, 94249) BAPU From a photostat of the Gujarati: S.N. 22765

('67', 56, 6, 9, 95058) 91. LETTER TO CHHAGANLAL JOSHI
('67', 56, 7, 10, 95089) WARDHA, May 12, 1935
('67', 56, 8, 11, 95110) CHHAGANLAL, I read your letters, the one to me and the other to Thakkar Bapa, and your article in Roshani 2. I have also discussed the matter with Bhai Jivanlal 3 .
('67', 56, 8, 12, 95275) Nanalal was present at the discussion.
('67', 56, 8, 13, 95314) I didn’t like your letter to Bapa and your article in Roshani.
('67', 56, 8, 14, 95377) I admit the necessity of the sphere of your work being defined.
('67', 56, 8, 15, 95441) Your freedom should be respected.
('67', 56, 8, 16, 95475) I think the present bitterness is purely the result of temperamental differences.
('67', 56, 8, 17, 95557) I see no good coming out of your leaving the Sangh, nor from Jivanlal’s leaving it.
('67', 56, 8, 18, 95641) It should be a matter of shame for us that well to do and poor workers cannot work together.
('67', 56, 8, 19, 95734) Bhai Jivanlal and you should bear up with each other.
('67', 56, 8, 20, 95788) I don’t think that you wish to do anything without consulting Bhai Jivanlal, nor do I find that the latter objects to discussing things with you.
('67', 56, 8, 21, 95934) Today, therefore, I will content myself with this request that both of you should resolve henceforth to work in harmony like blood brothers.
('67', 56, 8, 22, 96075) I have given the same advice to Bhai Jivanlal.
('67', 56, 8, 23, 96122) I have also shown him this letter.
('67', 56, 8, 24, 96157) I am sending a copy of it to Thakkar Bapa.
('67', 56, 8, 25, 96200) Blessings from BAPU

('67', 58, 1, 2, 97899) 93. LETTER TO S. AMBUJAMMAL
('67', 58, 2, 3, 97927) May 12, 1935
('67', 58, 3, 4, 97940) AMBUJAM,
('67', 58, 4, 5, 97949) I got your letter and Rs. 110. You should not worry about Krishna.
('67', 58, 4, 6, 98016) There is no need for me to go to a hill station.
('67', 58, 4, 7, 98065) Moreover, there is so much work here that I cannot get out.

('67', 69, 8, 14, 112189) Ceresole proceeded to tell Gandhiji of some of the books he had recently read.
('67', 69, 8, 15, 112268) There was India in the Dark Wood .
('67', 69, 8, 16, 112303) wanting “the main framework of the dominant Hindu philosophy to be shattered”.
('67', 69, 8, 17, 112382) Pierre Ceresole said he had turned from this book with relief to Frank Lonwood’s book Jesus Lord or Leader where the author rejects the claim of Christianity as the final religion and pines for “a fuller and richer faith than we have yet reached and to believe that God, who has nowhere left Himself without witness,will use the highest institutions of other systems and of many races to enrich the thinking and worship of mankind.” He sees definite gain in the abandonment of a special claim for the inspiration of the Bible, and classes himself among those “who humbly desire to follow Jesus as leader, though their view of truth will not allow them to worship him as Lord”.
('67', 69, 8, 18, 113059) Gandhiji said: There is a swing in the pendulum, and I have a Christian friend telling me that the Gita shows him how to live the New Testament, and that many passages in the latter which used to be dark were intelligible to him through a study of the Gita.
('67', 69, 9, 19, 113317) 1 Panchgani 2 Addressee’s mother 3 This is extracted from “Weekly Letter” by Mahadev Desai who had explained: “Pierre Ceresole and Joe Wilkinson .
('67', 69, 9, 20, 113464) returning home after a strenous time in Bihar earthquake stricken districts, broke journey here at Wardha” 4 From Gandhi: 1915 1948—A Detailed Chronology
('67', 70, 0, 1, 113618) VOL. 67: 25 APRIL, 1935 22 SEPTEMBER, 1935 71
('67', 70, 1, 2, 113664) And yet Ceresole feels that each one must find his solace from his own faith.
('67', 70, 1, 3, 113742) He attended our prayer meetings regularly, morning and evening, but said one evening: “This repetition of one and the same thing over and over again jars on me.
('67', 70, 1, 4, 113903) It may be the defect of my rationalist, mathematical temperament.
('67', 70, 1, 5, 113969) But somehow I cannot like the repetition.”.
('67', 70, 2, 6, 114013) GANDHIJI: But even in mathematics you have your recurring decimals.
('67', 70, 3, 7, 114081) PIERRE CERESOLE: But each recurs with a definite new fact.
('67', 70, 4, 8, 114140) G. Even so each repetition, or japa as it is called, has a new meaning, each repetition carries you nearer and nearer to God.
('67', 70, 4, 9, 114266) This is a concrete fact, and I may tell you that you are here talking to no theorist but to one who has experienced what he says every minute of his life, so much so that it is easier for the life to stop than for this incessant process to stop.
('67', 70, 4, 10, 114512) It is a definite need of the soul.
('67', 70, 5, 11, 114547) P.C. I quite see it, but for the average man it becomes an empty formula.
('67', 70, 6, 12, 114621) G. I agree, but the best thing is liable to be abused.
('67', 70, 6, 13, 114676) There is room for any amount of hypocrisy, but even hypocrisy is an ode to virtue.
('67', 70, 6, 14, 114759) And I know that for ten thousand hypocrites you would find millions of simple souls who find their solace from it.
('67', 70, 6, 15, 114874) It is like scaffolding quite essential to a building.
('67', 70, 7, 16, 114928) P.C. But if I may carry the simile a little further, you agree that the scaffolding has to be removed when the building is complete?
('67', 70, 8, 17, 115061) G. Yes, it would be removed when this body is removed.
('67', 70, 9, 18, 115116) P. C. Why?
('67', 70, 10, 19, 115127) JOE WILKINSON: Because we are eternally building.
('67', 70, 11, 20, 115177) G. Because we are eternally striving after perfection.
('67', 70, 11, 21, 115232) God alone is perfect, man is never perfect.
('67', 70, 12, 22, 115276) Harijan, 25 5 1935

('67', 72, 7, 10, 117143) 119. HARIJAN EDUCATION
('67', 72, 8, 11, 117166) The question of primary education is in many respects much more difficult than secondary and college education.
('67', 72, 8, 12, 117278) And Harijan education is the most difficult for all.
('67', 72, 8, 13, 117331) Be it in the crudest manner possible, a non Harijan child receives some home culture.
('67', 72, 8, 14, 117417) A Harijan child, being shunned by society, has none.
('67', 72, 8, 15, 117470) Even when, therefore, all primary schools are open to Harijan children, as they must be sooner or later and in my opinion sooner rather than later, preliminary schools will be needed for Harijan children if they are not to labour under a perpetual handicap.
('67', 72, 8, 16, 117728) The preliminary training can be discovered and tried in all the numerous Harijan schools conducted under the aegis of Harijan Sevak Sanghs scattered throughout India.
('67', 72, 8, 17, 117895) That preliminary training should consist in teaching Harijan children manners, good speech and good conduct.
('67', 72, 8, 18, 118004) A Harijan child sits anyhow; dresses anyhow; his eyes, ears, teeth, hair, nails, nose are often full of dirt; many never know what it is to have a wash.
('67', 72, 8, 19, 118157) I remember what I did when in 1915 I picked up a Harijan boy at Tranquebar and took him with me to Kochrab where the Ashram was then situated.
('67', 72, 8, 20, 118300) I had him shaved.
('67', 72, 8, 21, 118318) He was then thoroughly washed and given a simple dhoti, vest and a cap.
('67', 72, 8, 22, 118390) In a few minutes in appearance he became indistinguishable from any child from a cultured home.
('67', 72, 8, 23, 118486) His head, eyes, ears, nose were thoroughly cleaned.
('67', 72, 8, 24, 118538) His nails which had become
('67', 72, 9, 25, 118565) 1 The appeal is not reproduced here; it exhorted the municipalities to provide social amenities, such as housing facilities, better service conditions, provision for sick, casual and maternity leave, etc., to its sweepers and scavengers.
('67', 73, 0, 1, 118803) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 74
('67', 73, 1, 2, 118844) repositories of dirt were pared and cleaned.
('67', 73, 1, 3, 118889) His feet which were laden with dust were rubbed and cleaned out.
('67', 73, 1, 4, 118954) Such a process has to be gone through every day, if need be, with Harijan children attending schools.
('67', 73, 1, 5, 119056) Their lesson should begin for the first three months with teaching them cleanliness.
('67', 73, 1, 6, 119141) They should be taught also how to eat properly, though as I write this sentence I recall what I had seen during the walking pilgrimage 1 in Orissa.
('67', 73, 1, 7, 119289) Harijan boys and grown ups, who were fed at some of the stages, ate with much better cleanliness than the others who soiled their fingers, scattered about the savings and left their plates in a messy condition.
('67', 73, 1, 8, 119500) Harijans had no savings and their dishes were left thoroughly clean.
('67', 73, 1, 9, 119569) Their fingers, whilst they were eating, were after every morsel taken licked clean.
('67', 73, 1, 10, 119653) I know that all Harijan children do not eat so cleanly as the particular ones I have described.
('67', 73, 1, 11, 119749) If this preliminary training is to be given in all Harijan schools, pamphlets giving detailed instructions for teachers in their languages should be prepared and distributed and inspectors of schools be required during their inspection to examine teachers and pupils on this head and to send full reports of the progress made in this direction.
('67', 73, 1, 12, 120094) This programme involves care in the selection of teachers and the training of the present staff.
('67', 73, 1, 13, 120191) But all this is well worth the attention, if the Sangh is to discharge its trust by the thousands of Harijan children that are brought under its care.
('67', 73, 1, 14, 120342) Harijan, 18 5 1935

('67', 74, 4, 6, 121093) 121. LETTER TO VALLABHBHAI PATEL
('67', 74, 5, 7, 121126) WARDHA, May 18, 1935
('67', 74, 6, 8, 121147) BHAI VALLABHBHAI, While Mahadev was there, I was too lazy to write to you.
('67', 74, 6, 9, 121222) Then, owing to circumstances over which he had no control, he took two days to return.
('67', 74, 6, 10, 121309) The result was that I could not write to you.
('67', 74, 6, 11, 121355) What you say about Mohanlal Pandya is quite right.
('67', 74, 6, 12, 121406) 1 The memories of old days are quite vivid.
('67', 74, 6, 13, 121450) But what will it avail to grieve?
('67', 74, 6, 14, 121484) Co workers come and go.
('67', 74, 6, 15, 121508) You feel that they only go, don’t come.
('67', 74, 6, 16, 121548) Even if that be so, what does it matter?
('67', 74, 6, 17, 121589) God doesn’t disappear.
('67', 74, 6, 18, 121612) It is because He is, that we are.
('67', 74, 6, 19, 121646) Without Him, of what help could all others be to us?
('67', 74, 6, 20, 121699) They would be so many bodies without souls.
('67', 74, 6, 21, 121743) You should not, therefore, grieve over the passing of a co worker.
('67', 74, 6, 22, 121810) Our duty is to do the best that we can.
('67', 74, 6, 23, 121850) I won’t be free before the 21st.
('67', 74, 6, 24, 121883) I shall arrive in Bombay on the 22nd morning.
('67', 74, 6, 25, 121929) The 20th is Monday.
('67', 74, 6, 26, 121949) I must be here on the 21st.
('67', 74, 6, 27, 121977) Most probably I shall be accompanied only by Ba.
('67', 74, 6, 28, 122026) I will take along Mirabehn only if I cannot help it.
('67', 74, 6, 29, 122079) If she insists on coming I shall be obliged to take her and may also bring one more person.
('67', 74, 6, 30, 122171) For food, I will have goat’s milk, neem leaves and any fruit available locally.
('67', 74, 6, 31, 122251) Please don’t get anything from Bombay.
('67', 74, 6, 32, 122290) That is my diet here too.
('67', 74, 6, 33, 122316) In place of lime juice I take the juice of tamarind and in place of green vegetables crushed neem leaves.
('67', 74, 6, 34, 122422) These days I also eat mangoes which grow in the orchard here.
('67', 74, 6, 35, 122484) I have not as yet tasted Bombay mangoes this year.
('67', 74, 6, 36, 122535) I will do that in Bombay.
('67', 74, 6, 37, 122561) But positively not in Borsad.
('67', 74, 6, 38, 122591) I must leave Mahadev behind here.
('67', 74, 6, 39, 122625) I will send him, if necessary, after I return here.
('67', 74, 6, 40, 122677) The rest when we meet.
('67', 74, 6, 41, 122700) Blessings from BAPU [From Gujarati] Bapuna Patro 2: Sardar Vallabhbhaine, pp.

('67', 82, 1, 2, 133072) 136. INTERVIEW TO A CHRISTIAN STUDENT 1
('67', 82, 2, 3, 133112) [On or before May 21, 1935 ] 2
('67', 82, 3, 4, 133143) GANDHIJI: Why, service which has not the slightest touch of self in it is itself the highest religion.
('67', 82, 3, 5, 133246) [STUDENT:] But one must be devoted to someone?
('67', 82, 3, 6, 133293) Yes, to Truth.
('67', 82, 3, 7, 133308) I am devoted to none but Truth and I owe no discipline to anybody but Truth.
('67', 82, 4, 8, 133385) But how is one to get inspiration from this general idea?
('67', 82, 4, 9, 133443) That means to say that you want a God who has form.
('67', 82, 4, 10, 133495) Truth is too impersonal for you.
('67', 82, 4, 11, 133528) Well, idolatry is embedded in human nature.
('67', 82, 4, 12, 133572) But you may if you like worship God as Truth, if not Truth as God.
('67', 82, 4, 13, 133639) God is Truth, but God is many other things also.
('67', 82, 4, 14, 133688) That is why I prefer to say Truth is God.
('67', 82, 4, 15, 133730) But you need not go into what may sound like mystic lore; you may simply worship what you find to be the Truth, for Truth is known relatively.
('67', 82, 4, 16, 133873) Only remember that Truth is not one of the many qualities that we name.
('67', 82, 4, 17, 133945) It is the living embodiment of God, it is the only Life, and I identify Truth with fullest life, and that is how it becomes a concrete thing, for God is His whole Creation, the whole Existence, and service of all that exists.
('67', 82, 4, 18, 134171) Truth is service of God.
('67', 82, 5, 19, 134196) But how should we Christian students go to the villagers?
('67', 82, 5, 20, 134254) They might shun us because we are Christians.
('67', 82, 5, 21, 134300) You will tell them: ‘We are Christians, but don’t be alarmed, even as we are not alarmed because you are Hindus.
('67', 82, 5, 22, 134413) We have no designs on you, as we know that you have no designs on us.
('67', 82, 5, 23, 134483) We want you to be better Hindus, even as by reasons of our contact with you we know that we will better Chrisitains.’ That is the way of approach.
('67', 82, 5, 24, 134630) It is idle to talk of winning souls for God.
('67', 82, 5, 25, 134675) Is God so helpless that He cannot win souls for Himself?
('67', 82, 5, 26, 134732) Everyone’s religion is a personal matter with himself.
('67', 82, 5, 27, 134787) I cannot preach Hinduism, I can but practise it.
('67', 82, 6, 28, 134836) Harijan, 25 5 1935
('67', 82, 7, 29, 134855) 1 This is extracted from “Weekly Letter” by Mahadev Desai, who had explained: “A Christian student, who is now with us studying things and preparing to qualify himself for village work, asked Gandhiji whether there could be any service without religion.” 2 Gandhiji left Wardha on May 21, 1935 for Bombay, en route to Borsad.

('67', 83, 2, 17, 136232) But is the view I have held and enforced for years.
('67', 83, 2, 18, 136284) I enforced it in Mira’s and Nanavati’s cases when both bodies were said to be perishing.

('67', 84, 7, 9, 137363) 140. DISCUSSION WITH PIERRE CERESOLE 1
('67', 84, 8, 10, 137402) [May 21, 1935 ]
('67', 84, 9, 11, 137418) PIERRE CERESOLE: Could one lay down a rule of life for the wealthy?
('67', 84, 9, 12, 137486) 2 That is to say, could one define how much belongs to the rich and how much does not belong to them?
('67', 84, 10, 13, 137588) GANDHIJI: Yes.
('67', 84, 10, 14, 137603) Let the rich man take 5 per cent, or 10 per cent, or 15 per cent.
('67', 84, 11, 15, 137669) But not 85 per cent?
('67', 84, 11, 16, 137690) I was thinking of going up to 25 per cent!
('67', 84, 11, 17, 137733) but not even an exploiter must think of taking 85 per cent!
('67', 84, 11, 18, 137793) That is where I disagree with the communist.
('67', 84, 11, 19, 137838) 3 With me the ultimatetest is non violence.
('67', 84, 11, 20, 137882) We have always to remember that even we were one day in the same position as the wealthy man.
('67', 84, 11, 21, 137976) It has not been an easy process with us and as we bore with ourselves, even so should we bear with others.
('67', 84, 11, 22, 138083) Besides, I have no right to assume that I am right and he is wrong.
('67', 84, 11, 23, 138151) I have to wait until I convert him to my point of view.
('67', 84, 11, 24, 138207) In the meanwhile if he says, ‘I am prepared to keep for myself 25 per cent and to give 75 percent to charities’, I close with the offer.
('67', 84, 11, 25, 138344) For I know that 75 per cent voluntarily given is better than 100 per cent surrendered at the point of the bayonet, and by thus being
('67', 84, 12, 26, 138477) 1 This is extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “Weekly Letter”; Desai had explained that the discussion took place in the train on way to Bombay.

('67', 85, 0, 1, 139000) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 86
('67', 85, 1, 2, 139041) satisfied with 75 per cent I render unto Caesar the things that are Caesar’s.
('67', 85, 1, 3, 139119) Non violence must be the common factor between us.
('67', 85, 1, 4, 139170) You may argue that a man who surrenders by compulsion today will voluntarily accept the position tomorrow.
('67', 85, 1, 5, 139277) That, to my mind, is a remote possiblility on which I should not care to build much.
('67', 85, 1, 6, 139362) What is certain is that if I use violence today, I shall be doubtless faced with greater violence.
('67', 85, 1, 7, 139461) With non violence as the rule, life will no doubt be a series of compromises.
('67', 85, 1, 8, 139539) But it is better than an endless series of clashes.
('67', 85, 2, 9, 139591) How would you in a word describe the rich man’s legitimate position?
('67', 85, 2, 10, 139660) That of a trustee.
('67', 85, 2, 11, 139679) I know a number of friends who earn and spend for the poor and who do not regard themselves as anything but trustees of their wealth.
('67', 85, 3, 12, 139813) I too have a number of friends wealthy and poor.
('67', 85, 3, 13, 139862) I do not possess wealth but accept money from my wealthy friends.
('67', 85, 3, 14, 139928) How can I justify myself.
('67', 85, 3, 15, 139954) You will accept nothing for yourself personally.
('67', 85, 3, 16, 140003) That is to say, you will not accept a cheque to go to Switzerland for a change but you will accept a lakh of rupees for wells for Harijans or for schools and hospitals for them.
('67', 85, 3, 17, 140181) All self has got to be eliminated and the problem is simplified.
('67', 85, 4, 18, 140246) But what about my personal expense?
('67', 85, 4, 19, 140282) You have to act on the principle that a labourer is worthy of his hire.
('67', 85, 4, 20, 140354) You must not hesitate to accept your minimum wage.
('67', 85, 4, 21, 140405) Every one of us is doing the same thing.
('67', 85, 4, 22, 140446) Bhansali’s wage is just wheat flour and neem leaves.
('67', 85, 4, 23, 140499) We cannot all be Bhansalis, but we can try to approximate to that life.
('67', 85, 4, 24, 140571) Thus I will be satisfied with having my livelihood, but I must not ask a rich man to accommodate my son.
('67', 85, 4, 25, 140676) My only concern is to keep my body and soul together so long as I serve the community.

('67', 85, 5, 27, 140989) Oh yes, that is your duty.
('67', 85, 6, 28, 141016) But there are wealthy and wealthy.
('67', 85, 6, 29, 141051) There are some who may have made their pile from alcoholic traffic.
('67', 85, 6, 30, 141119) Yes, you will certainly draw a line.
('67', 85, 6, 31, 141156) But whilst you will not accept money from a brewer, I do not know what will happen if you have made an appeal for funds.
('67', 85, 6, 32, 141277) Will you tell the people that only those who have justly earned their money will pay?
('67', 85, 6, 33, 141363) I would rather withdraw the appeal than expect any money on those terms.
('67', 85, 6, 34, 141436) Who is to decide whether one is just or otherwise?
('67', 85, 6, 35, 141487) And justice too is a relative term.
('67', 85, 6, 36, 141523) If we will but ask ourselves, we will find that we have not been just all our
