('67', 86, 2, 5, 141847) 141. INTERVIEW TO “THE BOMBAY CHRONICLE”
('67', 86, 3, 6, 141888) [May 22, 1935 ] 1
('67', 86, 4, 7, 141906) GANDHIJI: That is quite right.
('67', 86, 4, 8, 141937) 2 Now, have you got your questions ready?
('67', 86, 4, 9, 141979) What is it you want me to tell?
('67', 86, 5, 10, 142011) REPRESENTATIVE: First and foremost I would like you to tell me something about the All India Village Industries Association.
('67', 86, 5, 11, 142136) What work has it been doing since it was started ten months ago?
('67', 86, 5, 12, 142201) G. The work of the Village Industries Association is going on steadily.
('67', 86, 5, 13, 142273) There is nothing heroic to report.
('67', 86, 5, 14, 142308) But not a moment is being wasted in the pursuit of the programme chalked out at the commencement.
('67', 86, 5, 15, 142406) Though we are having all the difficulties that were anticipated and others which were not anticipated, I still swear by the original programme.
('67', 86, 5, 16, 142550) I believe that on this earth there is no better instrument of progress than human flesh, and you cannot expect brilliant results if that flesh is weak, and is daily getting weaker, because of interior and exterior defects.
('67', 86, 5, 17, 142773) We are, therefore, tackling the question of food and that of sanitation.
('67', 86, 5, 18, 142846) And since charity begins at home, we are trying to reproduce at the centre conditions that we would like to see in use in every village of India.
('67', 86, 5, 19, 142992) Side by side with that we have selected a village nearest the centre for experiment.
('67', 86, 5, 20, 143077) I would like the Press to realize the deep significance of the movement and give its intelligent support.
('67', 86, 5, 21, 143183) By intelligent support I mean that important newspapers should have on their staff specialists who would regularly contribute instructive articles which the reader can profit by.
('67', 86, 5, 22, 143362) You will see that in the programme which to the superficial observer appears dry, but in reality is highly interesting, there is no room for difference of opinion.
('67', 86, 5, 23, 143526) all parties and persons must recognize the primary necessity of India’s millions getting nourishing food or a “balanced diet”, as Dr. Tilak calls it, and healthy surroundings.
('67', 86, 5, 24, 143702) I think that both these things are possible in spite of our corroding poverty.
('67', 86, 6, 25, 143781) 1 According to the reporter, the interview took place in Calcutta Mail, which was nearing Bombay early in the morning.
('67', 86, 6, 26, 143900) 2 The source had reported: “Before the interview commenced, the representa tive told Gandhiji that he had been instructed not to put him any questions about politics.”
('67', 87, 0, 1, 144068) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 88
('67', 87, 1, 2, 144109) When informed that though it had been ten months since the Association was started little was known about the work done on behalf of the Association excepting, possibly, about the work at Wardha and Panvel, Gandhiji said that silent work was being done all over the country.
('67', 87, 1, 3, 144384) The workers were finding out the depths to which the work could be carried on.
('67', 87, 1, 4, 144463) There was nothing much to report in the papers, day to day or week to week.
('67', 87, 1, 5, 144539) As workers of the right stamp were being found, the different questions were being tackled.
('67', 87, 2, 6, 144631) Asked whether it would not be necessary for him to undertake an all India tour in the near future, with a view to widen the scope and work of the Association, Gandhiji said that he did not think that it was necessary just yet.
('67', 87, 2, 7, 144858) He added: Undertaking an all India tour just now would be for tackling the extent instead of the depth.
('67', 87, 2, 8, 144962) There was no doubt that such a tour would bring money, and I will be giving superficial instructions about the work, that too without knowing anything of the difficulties that face village workers.
('67', 87, 2, 9, 145160) Just now I am endeavouring to concentrate at the centre and the neighbouring village to give myself and co workers first hand instructions.
('67', 87, 2, 10, 145300) Other workers in other centres are also carrying on work likewise.
('67', 87, 2, 11, 145367) When we have taken the preliminary training then I will go on an all India tour, if necessary.
('67', 87, 2, 12, 145462) Remember this is a question of a kind of adult education on a mass scale.
('67', 87, 2, 13, 145536) It cannot be given without previous preparation.
('67', 87, 2, 14, 145585) I have said all that I have to say about the All India Village Industries Association.
('67', 87, 2, 15, 145672) That is all.
('67', 87, 3, 16, 145685) Our representative told Gandhiji that he would ask him one or two brief questions and not disturb him after that.
('67', 87, 3, 17, 145799) Gandhiji was reminded about Dr. Tagore’s message to him regarding village arts and the A.I.V.I.A. in which the Poet had said that the Central Museum that is to be started by the Association should not be restricted only to industries.
('67', 87, 3, 18, 146034) The Poet had said: “.
('67', 87, 3, 19, 146056) the economic life of a nation is not such an isolated fact as Mahatmaji imagines, and today, side by side with economic poverty we are faced with cultural poverty which puts us to shame—shame that is in no way lessened when we consider what we once were.
('67', 87, 3, 20, 146311) Our art treasures are today found in museums outside India, and our village artists are dying out .
('67', 87, 3, 21, 146411) Please tell Mahatmaji that art is not a luxury of the well to do.
('67', 87, 3, 22, 146477) The poor man needs it as much and employs it as much in his cottage building, his pots, his floor decorations, etc.
('67', 87, 3, 23, 146593) If Mahatmaji’s men go round collecting specimens of village industries, why can they not look for and collect specimens of various indigenous arts spread all over our land and waiting to be re cherished.
('67', 87, 3, 24, 146797) .” Gandhiji said: Every message coming from Dr. Tagore must receive respectful attention from me.
('67', 87, 3, 25, 146895) I quite believe that we have got to take care of village arts and by his assistance we shall not neglect the arts.
('67', 87, 3, 26, 147010) He would not let us neglect, even if we forgot our duties.
('67', 87, 3, 27, 147069) He had lent the assistance of Sjt.
('67', 87, 3, 28, 147104) Surendranath Kar who has already paid a preliminary visit and I have discussed the whole thing with
('67', 88, 0, 1, 147204) VOL. 67: 25 APRIL, 1935 22 SEPTEMBER, 1935 89
('67', 88, 1, 2, 147250) Deenabandhu C.F. Andrews who will in turn discuss with Gurudev.
('67', 88, 2, 3, 147314) Gandhiji was asked if he wanted Hindustani, the Lingua Franca of India, to be written both in Devanagari and Urdu scripts.
('67', 88, 2, 4, 147437) Gandhiji replied: Hindustani will naturally be written by the vast masses in Devanagari, but Mussalmans will for a long time to come—or, it may be for all time—insist on writing in Urdu script.
('67', 88, 2, 5, 147631) Therefore, in the definition we have said that Hindustani is the language spoken by the people in the North and written either in Devanagari or Urdu script.
('67', 88, 2, 6, 147788) My hope, however, is that when religious differences have sunk and religious unity is accentuated, and friendship of the heart established between Hindus and Mussalmans, Devanagari, as the most scientific script of all the scripts of the world, will receive its due, that is, universal recognition in India.
('67', 88, 3, 7, 148096) At this stage, Sjt.
('67', 88, 3, 8, 148116) Mahadev Desai informed our representative that his time was up, and he should leave the seat he was occupying and Gandhiji observed that he would not have enough time to talk to his son if further questions were asked.
('67', 88, 3, 9, 148335) The Chronicle representative said that he would leave his seat immediately after he had got a reply for his last and only question that he would put, adding: “I know it is beyond the scope of my instructions to ask this question as it is definitely political.” Gandhiji said: Go ahead.
('67', 88, 3, 10, 148621) [R.] It was stated by Sjt.
('67', 88, 3, 11, 148648) Bhulabhai Desai the other day that everyone should try to get back Gandhiji into the congress and the politics.
('67', 88, 3, 12, 148760) When are you coming back to the Congress?
('67', 88, 3, 13, 148802) Gandhiji laughed and said: If you have direct access to God, ask him when I am coming back to the Congress.
('67', 88, 3, 14, 148910) I am saying this because I do not know it myself.

('67', 89, 1, 2, 149505) 142. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('67', 89, 2, 3, 149537) BOMBAY, May 22, 1935 You will wonder why I consented to have a prayer meeting in Bombay, when even the existence of God is with many a matter of doubt.
('67', 89, 2, 4, 149689) There are others who say: ‘If God is seated in the heart of everyone, who shall pray to whom, who shall invoke whom?’ I am not here to solve these intellectual puzzles.
('67', 89, 2, 5, 149858) I can only say that ever since my childhood prayer has been my solace and my strength.
('67', 89, 2, 6, 149945) I am told that there is despair and depression everywhere, that there is disappointment all round as the gateway to jail is closed.
('67', 89, 2, 7, 150077) People, I am told, do not know what to do.
('67', 89, 2, 8, 150120) I do not know why, when there is the whole of the constructive programme of work to do.
('67', 89, 2, 9, 150208) When the programme of jail going was on, there was room for hypocrisy, compulsion, violence.
('67', 89, 2, 10, 150301) he present constructive programme leaves no room for these.
('67', 89, 2, 11, 150361) And it leaves no room for disappointment and despair.
('67', 89, 2, 12, 150415) For them there is the name of God.
('67', 89, 2, 13, 150450) It is God’s covenant that whoever goes to Him in weakness and helplessness, him He will make strong.
('67', 89, 2, 14, 150551) ‘When I am weak, then I am strong.’ As the poet Surdas has sung, Rama is the strength of the weak.
('67', 89, 2, 15, 150650) This strength is not to be obtained by taking up arms or by similar means.
('67', 89, 2, 16, 150725) It is to be had by throwing oneself on His name.
('67', 89, 2, 17, 150774) Rama is but a synonym of God.
('67', 89, 2, 18, 150804) You may say God or Allah or whatever other name you like, but the moment you trust naught but Him, you are strong, all disappointment disappears.
('67', 89, 2, 19, 150950) The hymn alludes to the story of the Lord of elephants who was in the jaws of a crocodile and who had been all but drowned in water.
('67', 89, 2, 20, 151083) There was only the tip of his trunk left above water when he invoked God’s name and he was saved.
('67', 89, 2, 21, 151181) No doubt it is an allegory.
('67', 89, 2, 22, 151209) But it conceals a truth.
('67', 89, 2, 23, 151234) Over and over again in my life I have found it.
('67', 89, 2, 24, 151282) Even in darkest despair, when there seems no helper and no comfort in the wide wide world, His name inspires us with strength and puts all doubts and despair to flight.
('67', 89, 2, 25, 151451) The sky may be overcast today with clouds, but a fervent prayer to Him is enough to dispel them.
('67', 89, 2, 26, 151548) It is because of prayer that I have known no disappointment.
('67', 89, 2, 27, 151609) Though I have retired from the Congress, I have not closed my eyes or stopped my ears.
('67', 89, 2, 28, 151696) I know all that is happening about me, and if anyone must give way to despair, it should be I. But I have known no despair.
('67', 89, 3, 29, 151820) 1 This is extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “Weekly Letter”.
('67', 89, 3, 30, 151878) The meeting was held in the Congress House compound.
('67', 89, 3, 31, 151931) Thousands of men and women were found seated on house tops, balconies and terraces.
('67', 90, 0, 1, 152015) VOL. 67: 25 APRIL, 1935 22 SEPTEMBER, 1935 91
('67', 90, 1, 2, 152061) then should you give way to it?
('67', 90, 1, 3, 152093) Let us pray that He may cleanse our hearts of pettinesses, meannesses and deceit, and He will surely answer our prayers.
('67', 90, 1, 4, 152214) Many I know have always turned to that unfailing source of strength.
('67', 90, 1, 5, 152283) Swaraj is our birthright.
('67', 90, 1, 6, 152309) No one can deprive us of it, unless we forfeit it ourselves.
('67', 90, 1, 7, 152370) We have forfeited it and we have to win it back.
('67', 90, 1, 8, 152419) Swaraj does not depend on jail going.
('67', 90, 1, 9, 152457) If it did, there are thousands of prisoners in jail today.
('67', 90, 1, 10, 152516) It depends on everyone doing his or her own task.
('67', 90, 1, 11, 152566) That task has been shown to you.
('67', 90, 1, 12, 152599) Go to the villages, identify yourselves with villagers, befriend the untouchables, make Hindu Muslim unity a concrete fact.
('67', 90, 1, 13, 152723) Do not despair although there may be Hindu Muslim riots in the country, but go ahead with the work before you and be sure that He will pull you through.
('67', 90, 1, 14, 152876) Harijan, 1 6 1935; also The Bombay Chronicle, 23 5 1935

('67', 92, 4, 10, 156515) 145. LETTER TO KHUSHALCHAND GANDHI
('67', 92, 5, 11, 156550) May 23, 1935
('67', 92, 6, 12, 156563) RESPECTED BROTHER,
('67', 92, 7, 13, 156582) Narandas informs me that, though you have read and reflected a great deal, all that seems to be of little help now and your mind has become weak.
('67', 92, 7, 14, 156728) I am not surprised, for this happens to everybody.
('67', 92, 7, 15, 156779) I must say, however, that I have cherishd a different hope about you.
('67', 92, 7, 16, 156849) For one whose mind has turned Godward, there is no old age.
('67', 92, 7, 17, 156909) The body becomes weak but in that it but follows its law.
('67', 92, 7, 18, 156967) The mind need not become weak.
('67', 92, 7, 19, 156998) It may go on rising till at last it merges in God.
('67', 92, 7, 20, 157049) Isn't this the meaning of the verse:
('67', 92, 8, 21, 157086) This is the state, O Partha, of the man who rests in Brahman; having attained to it, he is not deluded.
('67', 92, 8, 22, 157190) He who abides in this state even at the hour of death passes into oneness with Brahman.
('67', 92, 9, 23, 157278) Isn’t the true brahmi state that which endures up to the end?
('67', 92, 9, 24, 157340) What should a mind that has become weak do to attain such a state?
('67', 92, 9, 25, 157407) The only reply is, constant repetition of the name.
('67', 92, 9, 26, 157459) I, therefore, pray that you should make a firm resolution and, withdrawing your mind from everything, merely go on repeating, after taking the Lord’s name, the following verse:
('67', 92, 10, 27, 157636) I desire neither earthly kingdom nor paradise no, not even release from birth and death .
('67', 92, 10, 28, 157726) I desire only release of the afflicted from misery.
('67', 92, 11, 29, 157778) If you cannot do this, repetition of the name will suffice.
('67', 92, 11, 30, 157838) If you fill your mind completely with strength and light, you will cease

('67', 95, 1, 2, 160572) 151. SPEECHES AT BORSAD VILLAGE 1
('67', 95, 2, 3, 160606) [On or after May 23, 1935] 2
('67', 95, 3, 4, 160635) Rats and fleas spread the infection and experts say that these have got to be exterminated.
('67', 95, 3, 5, 160727) But rats and fleas are messengers of God.
('67', 95, 3, 6, 160769) God speaks to us through them.
('67', 95, 3, 7, 160800) In villages where Nature has blessed you with the finest climate and the healthiest soil, as I can see with my own eyes, you have so infringed Nature’s rules that plague seems to have a knack of appearing again and again if you do not make your houses and surroundings inhospitable to them.
('67', 95, 3, 8, 161091) A man like me wedded to non violence would say rats and fleas have as much right to live as I, and there is no reason why I should not exterminate myself rather than that I exterminate them.
('67', 95, 3, 9, 161282) But I cannot reach that pitch of non violence in this lifetime, may be in several lifetimes, nor perhaps can you.
('67', 95, 3, 10, 161396) But you certainly can produce conditions where rats and fleas can never flourish.
('67', 95, 3, 11, 161478) I want you to create those conditions.
('67', 95, 3, 12, 161517) I want you to make the cleaning and scavenging campaign of these volunteers a permanent affair, and I want you to break up your floors, break up rat nests and rat burrows, and construct floors where rats cannot make their homes.
('67', 95, 4, 13, 161746) A plague infected man is worse than a plague infected rat or fleas and unless you make your bodies proofs against infection you cannot abolish these epidemics.
('67', 95, 4, 14, 161906) Nature has endowed us with enough capacity for the resistance of disease.
('67', 95, 4, 15, 161980) It is we who, careless of her laws, have ruined that capacity.
('67', 95, 4, 16, 162043) We have to regain it by healthy and hygienic ways of living and eating.
('67', 95, 5, 17, 162115) Harijan, 8 6 1935
('67', 95, 6, 18, 162133) 1 This is extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “Weekly Letter”.
('67', 95, 6, 19, 162191) Without mentioning either the date or the place of the meeting or meetings, Mahadev Desai had merely reported that “Gandhiji addressed about ten meetings in these villages and in the course of his speeches asked the people not to go to sleep over the flight of the enemy but to take permanent measures for banishing him.” 2 Gandhiji reached Borsad on May 23. 3 What follows was reported by Mahadev Desai as said by Gandhiji “in one of his speeches”.
('67', 95, 6, 20, 162641) Mahadev Desai had explained: “During his eight days’ stay at Borsad, Gandhiji got Dr. Bhaskar to issue a series of leaflets on the elements of rat proofing of houses and on the disease proofing of human bodies.”

('67', 96, 7, 10, 163332) 153. LETTER TO AGATHA HARRISON
('67', 96, 8, 11, 163363) WARDHA, 1 May 24, 1935
('67', 96, 9, 12, 163386) MY DEAR AGATHA,
('67', 96, 10, 13, 163402) Whilst C. F. A. is here I need not write at all.

('67', 96, 10, 16, 163626) The king there is, or may be, above party strife.

('67', 96, 10, 18, 163731) He is the ruler through his Viceroy.
('67', 96, 10, 19, 163768) The India Office laughs to see the paragraph which is so hopelessly out of touch with the reality.
('67', 96, 10, 20, 163867) And why should the Government release prisoners who bear no affection either towards the Emperor as such or his Empire?
('67', 96, 10, 21, 163987) I have never appreciated the agitation for the release of political prisoners.
('67', 96, 10, 22, 164066) I have understood the Government’s stubborn refusal.
('67', 96, 10, 23, 164119) It is consistent.

('67', 100, 6, 9, 168223) 161. WANTED ONE LAC RUPEES
('67', 100, 7, 10, 168250) The Central Board of the Harijan Sevak Sangh has already built many wells out of the fund that was placed at its disposal by Sheth Jugalkishore Birla.
('67', 100, 7, 11, 168401) That fund is exhausted and there is still a need for buiding wells for Harijans.
('67', 100, 7, 12, 168482) The orthodox opposition to the use by Harijans of common wells still continues in many places, and Harijans are obliged either to drink water out of cattle troughs or pay for water which people may for a consideration pour into their pots.
('67', 100, 7, 13, 168722) Every additional well built is therefore undoubtedly a great comfort to Harijans, but it is also an increase in the wealth of the country.
('67', 100, 7, 14, 168861) The Central Board of the Harijan Sevak Sangh has resolved to make an appeal for one lac of rupees for the purpose.
('67', 100, 7, 15, 168976) Figures are being prepared for presentation to the public showing the wants of the different provinces.
('67', 100, 7, 16, 169080) One lac is nothing in comparison to the need.
('67', 100, 7, 17, 169126) But the Sangh has not the resources to spend large sums on well construction.
('67', 100, 7, 18, 169204) It is slow work requiring special skill.
('67', 100, 7, 19, 169245) Not everyone can construct a well.
('67', 100, 7, 20, 169280) And the work being scattered makes it very difficult to provide effective supervision.
('67', 100, 7, 21, 169367) The policy of the Board is not to ask for what it cannot spend well and give a good account of to the public.
('67', 100, 7, 22, 169477) I hope the modest appeal will receive prompt and adequate response.
('67', 100, 8, 23, 169545) Harijan, 25 5 1935
('67', 100, 9, 24, 169564) 1 From the reference to Mary Barr to whom Gandhiji had written on May 24; vide “Letter to F. Mary Barr”, 24 5 1935.

('67', 102, 8, 17, 171356) 166. LETTER TO BHAGWANJI P. PANDYA
('67', 102, 9, 18, 171391) BORSAD, May 26, 1935
('67', 102, 10, 19, 171412) BHAGWANJI,
('67', 102, 11, 20, 171423) Your letter was put into my hands at 3.30 a.m., and after reading it I have immediately sat down to reply to it.
('67', 102, 11, 21, 171536) Shedding tears will not help us to remove the hardships of Savli’s women.
('67', 102, 11, 22, 171610) It can be proved that the condition of the Harijan women of Savli is not as bad as you believe it to be.
('67', 102, 11, 23, 171715) Your imagination can carry you too far.
('67', 102, 11, 24, 171755) That faculty needs to be kept under control.
('67', 102, 11, 25, 171800) This world is a sea of misery.
('67', 102, 11, 26, 171831) If we keep thinking of it only we would get drowned in it.
('67', 102, 11, 27, 171890) We should remember that God, who created this world and who rules it is just and, therefore, the sufferings that we imagine do not exist and that, on the balance, happiness reigns, that is, truth alone triumphs.
('67', 102, 11, 28, 172102) Knowing this, we should keep our minds light.
('67', 102, 11, 29, 172148) That will also help us in removing the sufferings.
('67', 102, 11, 30, 172199) If, on the contrary, we magnify the sufferings, we would sink into moha 2 and become incapable of relieving them.
('67', 102, 12, 31, 172313) 1 Satis Chandra Das Gupta 2 Ignorant attachment
('67', 103, 0, 1, 172361) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 104
('67', 103, 1, 2, 172403) I will certainly inquire regarding Salvi.
('67', 103, 1, 3, 172445) But I will say one thing.
('67', 103, 1, 4, 172471) It is surely a matter of satisfaction that whereas before the women earned nothing, through spinning they earn something now, however little it may be.
('67', 103, 1, 5, 172623) They do have other income.
('67', 103, 1, 6, 172650) A woman is but one member of a family.
('67', 103, 1, 7, 172689) There are others, too, who earn.
('67', 103, 1, 8, 172722) There are countless women in this country much poorer than they.
('67', 103, 1, 9, 172787) Instead of shedding tears over their poverty, we would steel our hearts while thinking about it and devise measures to eradicate it.
('67', 103, 2, 10, 172920) Blessings from BAPU

('67', 109, 9, 24, 182879) 181. SPEECH AT BORSAD 2
('67', 109, 10, 25, 182903) May 27, 1935 It is a shame that plague should have been endemic here for four years.
('67', 109, 10, 26, 182988) Borsad proper has only a population of 13,000, and the taluka has a population of 1,44,000 to deal with.
('67', 109, 10, 27, 183093) It should not be impossible to abolish plague both from the town and the taluka.
('67', 109, 11, 28, 183174) 1 Vide “Letter to H. L. Sharma”, 20 5 1935 2 This is extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “Weekly Letter”.
('67', 110, 0, 1, 183275) VOL. 67: 25 APRIL, 1935 22 SEPTEMBER, 1935 111
('67', 110, 1, 2, 183322) you cannot do so with only six scavengers for the whole of the town.
('67', 110, 1, 3, 183391) Unless you convert yourselves into Bhangis, unless all of you become voluntary scavengers, plague must come gain, the Sardar’s and his volunteers’ efforts notwithstanding.
('67', 110, 1, 4, 183563) In fact the voluntary relief work that has now come to an end adds considerably to your responsibility.
('67', 110, 1, 5, 183667) Unless you follow up the work it will be wasted.
('67', 110, 1, 6, 183716) I have in the past come to you to congratulate you on the pluck with, which you had fought during the civil disobedience movement and on your sufferings and sacrifice.
('67', 110, 1, 7, 183884) But I have come to tell you today that it is not those who can fight the Government that can govern themselves, but those who can show themselves to be equal to calamities like this.
('67', 110, 1, 8, 184067) Let me tell you that ever since I learnt the word ‘swaraj’, I have been interesting myself in work of this kind.
('67', 110, 1, 9, 184180) Ever since 1893 when my public life began my principal interest has been this kind of constructive work.
('67', 110, 1, 10, 184285) The fight with the Government came at a very late stage in life.
('67', 110, 1, 11, 184350) But it may be said to be an edifice built on the sure foundation of solid constructive work done through several years.
('67', 110, 1, 12, 184470) I have obeyed and respected every municipal and civic law to the best of my ability, and even the Government that has often imprisoned me knows my capacity for obedience.
('67', 110, 1, 13, 184641) I learnt scavenging for the first time in South Africa, and have ever been laying the greatest stress on the fact that it is work of this kind that qualifies one for swaraj.
('67', 110, 1, 14, 184815) You will not say that after you have won swaraj you can go to sleep, unmindful of these problems.
('67', 110, 1, 15, 184913) Swaraj is not absence of rule.
('67', 110, 1, 16, 184944) You will have to tackle all these problems successfully even after you have won swaraj.
('67', 110, 1, 17, 185032) Remember that the man who made the call for civil disobedience is making the call for work of this essential character.
('67', 110, 1, 18, 185152) Even constructive work like production of khadi and revival of village industries cannot be done unless you have made your bodies and your homes proof against disease, and therefore this sanitation work is the very foundation of all constructive work.
('67', 110, 2, 19, 185404) Harijan, 8 6 1935; also The Bombay Chronicle, 28 5 1935.

('67', 112, 4, 4, 186835) Why did you have to keep waiting for forty five minutes?

('67', 112, 4, 9, 187168) I am unable to say anything about Aurobindobabu.

('67', 112, 4, 11, 187307) I can only say that my path has borne fruit for me.
('67', 112, 4, 12, 187359) Let us not make ourselves judges of the whole world.
('67', 112, 4, 13, 187412) We should admit that among the slim?
('67', 112, 4, 14, 187449) I can only say that my path has borne fruit for me.
('67', 112, 4, 15, 187501) Let us not make ourselves judges of the whole world.
('67', 112, 4, 16, 187554) We should admit that among thetwo hundred persons living under his wing there are several whose lives have undergone a great transformation through his influence.
('67', 112, 4, 17, 187717) Everybody follows his own natural bent.
('67', 112, 4, 18, 187757) It is not quite correct to say that in the West they do not recognize the necessity of purity in private life, nor is it correct to say that here everybody recognizes it.
('67', 112, 4, 19, 187928) We ourselves not only recognize it, but go further and believe that the actions prompted by a reason not purified inwardly will not endure, however attractive they may appear.
('67', 112, 4, 20, 188104) Such actions cannot be judged from their immediate results.
('67', 112, 4, 21, 188164) It is true, of course, that actions which have no connection with morality do not require inward purity.
('67', 112, 4, 22, 188269) A dissolute carpenter will be able to make a right angled table.
('67', 112, 4, 23, 188334) But a person lacking in purity will not be able to eradicate untouchability or turn the people to the spinning wheel, for both these tasks require qualities of the heart.
('67', 112, 4, 24, 188505) In such activities calculations of time count for little.
('67', 112, 4, 25, 188563) We should have no doubt at all that actions performed with sincere and truthful motives are bound to have certain results.
('67', 112, 4, 26, 188686) If we do not have such faith, we shall never be able to adhere to moral principles.
('67', 112, 4, 27, 188770) God is beyond the reach of human thought.
('67', 112, 4, 28, 188812) The God, therefore, whom we worship is a creation of our imagination.
('67', 112, 4, 29, 188882) Nobody has seen the real God.
('67', 112, 4, 30, 188912) If anybody has seen Him, he has not been able to describe Him.
('67', 112, 4, 31, 188975) It is difficult to say which Form of Him is dearest to
('67', 113, 0, 1, 189030) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 114
('67', 113, 1, 2, 189072) The Form, however, which I worship is known as Truth.
('67', 113, 1, 3, 189126) He both has a manifest form and has none.
('67', 113, 1, 4, 189168) He manifests Himself in innumerable ways.
('67', 113, 1, 5, 189210) How can imperfect man see perfect truth?

('67', 119, 1, 2, 199282) 193. SPEECH AT INAUGURATION OF BAL MANDIR, NADIAD
('67', 119, 2, 3, 199332) May 31, 1935
('67', 119, 3, 4, 199345) I feel it is necessary to say two things before we begin our programme for the day.
('67', 119, 3, 5, 199429) Today, on this occasion, I feel the absence of Fulchand 1 and Mohanlal Pandya 2—the onion thief.
('67', 119, 3, 6, 199526) I came into contact with both these persons when I was staying at the Nadiad orphanage in 1918 and that relationship lasted till they died.
('67', 119, 3, 7, 199666) I have preserved in my memory many sweet recollections of both.
('67', 119, 3, 8, 199730) I received a heart rending letter from Sardar at the time of Mohanlal’s death.
('67', 119, 3, 9, 199809) Ordinarily, Sardar has a heart of steel, he can harden his heart to put up with any kind of suffering that befalls him.
('67', 119, 3, 10, 199929) Nevertheless when I came across heart rending phrases in his letter, I realized how much he must have felt at the loss of such a colleague.
('67', 119, 3, 11, 200069) Not only this district, but the entire Gujarat feels his loss.
('67', 119, 3, 12, 200132) These two workers embodied my ideal of silent volunteers.
('67', 119, 3, 13, 200190) Both gave up their lives thinking of their own work.
('67', 119, 3, 14, 200243) I have visited the Bal Mandir which has been built in memory of Fulchand.
('67', 119, 3, 15, 200317) It is natural that you should wish to have a memorial for Mohanlal as well.
('67', 119, 3, 16, 200393) However, it is better if we do not beguile ourselves with such small memorials.
('67', 119, 3, 17, 200473) If we wish to erect a permanent memorial, it cannot be done by spending money on buildings of brick and mortar.
('67', 119, 3, 18, 200585) This does not mean that such memorials should not be built.
('67', 119, 3, 19, 200645) Only we must understand what we intend through the memorial.
('67', 119, 3, 20, 200706) We cannot sit by saying, now he is gone and where are we to find the like of him?
('67', 119, 3, 21, 200788) We are bound to feel sorry at the loss of such workers but their loss should be made good.
('67', 119, 3, 22, 200879) Just as at the death of a king his throne does not remain vacant and we say “the king is dead, long live the king”, similarly the institution built by workers who are no longer alive should continue to function.
('67', 119, 3, 23, 201091) And a successive line of workers belonging to these should continue.
('67', 119, 3, 24, 201160) Both Fulchand and Mohanlal Pandya were institutions by themselves.
('67', 119, 3, 25, 201227) What would happen to a person like myself if such institutions did not function?
('67', 119, 3, 26, 201308) Or, in other words, no sooner a person who is prepared to face the gallows has departed, than another such person should be ready.
('67', 119, 3, 27, 201439) I would,
('67', 119, 4, 28, 201448) 1 Fulchand Bapuji Shah died on April 19, 1934 2 Mohanlal Kameshvar Pandya died on May 18, 1934.

('67', 120, 1, 2, 201591) therefore, suggest that if we wish to perpetuate the memory of Fulchand and Mohanlal Pandya we may certainly erect buildings but before doing that our task should be to resolve to make all efforts to become like them.
('67', 120, 1, 3, 201809) The poet Shakespeare has said: “The evil that men do lives after them, the good is oft interred with their bones.” The poet has not expressed a universal truth in this but has reproached the world.
('67', 120, 1, 4, 202007) As a matter of fact, Nature does not store rubbish.
('67', 120, 1, 5, 202059) It continues to give out its fragrance after burying or burning up filth.
('67', 120, 1, 6, 202133) Similarly, we should bury any faults in our elders and departed leaders and preserve their virtues.
('67', 120, 1, 7, 202233) The reason is that it is not the former but the latter which is our wealth.
('67', 120, 1, 8, 202309) We are not guilty of any injustice to those like Mohanlal Pandya if we believe that we can excel them.
('67', 120, 1, 9, 202412) Each one of us is born with his own faults.
('67', 120, 1, 10, 202456) It is the dharma of every one of us to rid ourselves of these and to develop our virtues and preserve them.
('67', 120, 1, 11, 202564) To the extent that the world has not been regularly practising this dharma, it has not done credit to its heritage.
('67', 120, 1, 12, 202680) This morning, I visited the Bal Mandir started in memory of Fulchand.
('67', 120, 1, 13, 202750) I was informed by the persons who run it that the transport charges for bringing the children to the school every day came to fifty rupees per month.
('67', 120, 1, 14, 202900) I am acquainted with child education and the Montessori system.
('67', 120, 1, 15, 202964) I have met 1 the learned Madam Montessori.
('67', 120, 1, 16, 203007) I have not taken a single lesson from her and yet she has publicly awarded a certificate to me saying that I fully understand her system and have been practising it.
('67', 120, 1, 17, 203173) This certificate was not by way of false flattery.
('67', 120, 1, 18, 203224) For I had given a certificate to myself at the very outset.
('67', 120, 1, 19, 203284) So, with full knowledge as to what child education is, I say that this expense of fifty rupees seems preposterous to me.
('67', 120, 1, 20, 203405) Spending fifty rupees for making cripples of children is not the Montessori system.
('67', 120, 1, 21, 203489) Those who blindly imitate in this country the way it is practised in Europe are fools.
('67', 120, 1, 22, 203576) And how far will you carry out that imitation?
('67', 120, 1, 23, 203623) According to that system, it is necessary to have a garden along with the school.
('67', 120, 1, 24, 203705) In this school I did not find a garden.
('67', 120, 1, 25, 203745) When I enquired about the distance of the school from the children’s homes, I was informed that it would not be more than a mile.
('67', 120, 1, 26, 203875) I would ask the parents and the teachers to save these fifty rupees.

('67', 121, 4, 15, 205122) 195. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS
('67', 121, 5, 16, 205150) May 31, 1935
('67', 121, 6, 17, 205163) Answering several questions, Gandhiji said that plague was practically exterminated from Borsad.
('67', 121, 6, 18, 205260) The conversation next turned to the village industries work.
('67', 121, 6, 19, 205321) Asked as to why he selected Wardha as his headquarters Gandhiji said: Because Wardha is in the centre of India, and it was in Wardha that I was able to get a rich piece of land with buildings and plenty of water, land worth over two lakhs.
('67', 121, 6, 20, 205561) There are nearly 700 fruit trees on the land.
('67', 121, 6, 21, 205607) I selected Wardha also because Sheth Jamnalal Bajaj was most anxious that the land which he had contemplated as donation for Maganlal Gandhi Memorial should be taken up by the All India Village Industries Association.
('67', 121, 6, 22, 205825) Lastly, Wardha is a half village and half town, and my own desire and that of my associates was that the headquarters should not be selected in any presidency town.
('67', 121, 7, 23, 205990) 1 Gopaldas Vithaldas Desai 2 Gandhiji issued the statement after meeting Khan Abdul Ghaffar Khan in Sabarmati Jail in the afternoon.
('67', 122, 0, 1, 206123) VOL. 67: 25 APRIL, 1935 22 SEPTEMBER, 1935 123
('67', 122, 1, 2, 206170) was an additional attraction of Vinoba and his band of workers already trained at the Wardha Ashram.
('67', 122, 1, 3, 206271) These were sufficient inducements for all of us for selecting Wardha as headquarters.
('67', 122, 2, 4, 206357) Answering further questions, Gandhiji said that he did not propose to move out of Wardha as far as possible in order that the work might go on in his presence, as the conception was his.
('67', 122, 2, 5, 206544) Moreover, it was advisable that all office bearers of the Association should be in close touch with him and that he might be available,
('67', 122, 3, 6, 206680) whenever any of them wanted his guidance at Wardha.
('67', 122, 3, 7, 206732) They met daily for one and a half hours except on Mondays.
('67', 122, 4, 8, 206791) Asked as to whether it was a fact that he had left Gujarat because he was dissatisfied with her, Gandhiji said that that was altogether a wrong notice.
('67', 122, 4, 9, 206943) [He said:] It is not without considerable pain that I am just now physically cut off from Gujarat, though, in other respects, I am in constant touch with her work.
('67', 122, 5, 10, 207107) Replying to another question, Gandhiji said that he wished he could stay in Gujarat for the Village Industries work, but he was afraid that Gujarat was far too commercialized for doing spade work with better prospects of success than elsewhere.
('67', 122, 5, 11, 207352) Gandhiji was of opinion that villages in Gujarat were more touched by that commercial spirit than elsewhere.
('67', 122, 5, 12, 207461) The Bombay Chronicle, 1 6 1935
('67', 122, 6, 13, 207492) 196. ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS 1
('67', 122, 7, 14, 207520) May 31, 1935
('67', 122, 8, 15, 207533) What should be the attitude of a woman towards her family?
('67', 122, 8, 16, 207592) To what extent can she maintain her individuality in the family?
('67', 122, 8, 17, 207657) There is not the slightest doubt that wives have all the rights which husbands enjoy.
('67', 122, 8, 18, 207743) Their duties are different but their rights are the same.
('67', 122, 8, 19, 207801) If a woman sets out in shirt and trousers with a gun in her hand, a man has no right to stop her.

('67', 124, 3, 15, 212173) 197. STRUGGLES OF A WORKER
('67', 124, 4, 16, 212200) I am conducting, with the co operation of some comrades, an ashram; its object is to so train ourselves as to be transformed into ideal peasants, so that we may be able to completely identify ourselves with village people and village society, and thus be able to serve them by being actually of them.
('67', 124, 4, 17, 212501) With this end in view, agriculture has been taken up as the chief means of support with spinning and weaving as supplementary .
('67', 124, 5, 18, 212629) While starting the ashram, it had been conceived that along with the working out of the ideal of ourselves living a self supporting peasant life, we should also serve the villagers by doing Harijan work, by introducing spinning and in other possible ways.
('67', 124, 5, 19, 212885) But we have been entirely disappointed in this respect, for we have not been as yet able to find a suitable locality for the ashram.
('67', 124, 5, 20, 213018) In the locality wherein the ashram is at present situated the hamlets consist of one or two houses; and these hamlets are separated from one another by a distance of from half a mile to one mile.
('67', 124, 6, 21, 213214) Another thing that has seriously impeded the progress of the ashram is that I committed grave blunders, as I now find them to be, in the matter of diet.
('67', 124, 6, 22, 213367) In what now seems to be a mere over enthusiasm for the ideal of poverty, the standard of diet was kept very low.
('67', 124, 6, 23, 213480) The ashram, for instance, did not even use vegetables regularly .
('67', 124, 6, 24, 213546) Milk and milk products were considered a luxury .
('67', 124, 6, 25, 213596) All this has seriously crippled the health of the inmates.
('67', 124, 6, 26, 213655) The ashram started with twelve inmates; we are now only five .
('67', 124, 7, 27, 213718) The ashram has up till now stuck to the ideal of maintaining itself by manual labour .
('67', 124, 8, 28, 213805) Friends and sympathizers as well as critics set this our insistence on the Tolstoyan idea of bread labour in opposition to the ideal of social service, and argue
('67', 125, 0, 1, 213967) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 126
('67', 125, 1, 2, 214009) that the ashram has thus deprived society of the benefits of the many services that the ashram workers would have been otherwise in a position to render to it.
('67', 125, 1, 3, 214169) How and when, if at all, can one be justified in compromising the principle of bread labour for the sake of rendering ‘social service’?
('67', 125, 1, 4, 214305) Is not, most often, the conflict between ‘being’ and ‘doing’ only apparent and superficial, while in truth, ‘being’ is ‘doing’ in the real sense?
('67', 125, 2, 5, 214451) the board per head per month has been Rs. 3 and other expenses including clothing Re.
('67', 125, 2, 6, 214537) 1 per head per month.
('67', 125, 2, 7, 214559) This is from a letter 1 addressed to Shri Kishorelal Mashruwala by a highly educated selfless worker.
('67', 125, 2, 8, 214661) It depicts the struggles of a sincere worker and is likely to help all who are trying to lead a life of service.
('67', 125, 2, 9, 214774) The effort is noble.
('67', 125, 2, 10, 214795) The writer and his co workers do not hesitate to own and mend mistakes when they discover any.
('67', 125, 2, 11, 214890) I do not know how Shri Kishorelal has answered the queries put by his correspondent.
('67', 125, 2, 12, 214975) I must try to answer them in order to help the general reader who is interested in the questions of the type that puzzle the writer of the letter.
('67', 125, 2, 13, 215122) There seems to be some confusion about the principle of bread labour.
('67', 125, 2, 14, 215192) It is never opposed to social service.
('67', 125, 2, 15, 215231) Intelligent bread labour is any day the highest form of social service.
('67', 125, 2, 16, 215303) For what can be better than that a man should by his personal labour add to the useful wealth of the country?
('67', 125, 2, 17, 215413) ‘Being’ is ‘doing’.
('67', 125, 2, 18, 215433) The adjective ‘intelligent’ has been prefixed to ‘labour’ in order to show that labour to be social service must have that definite purpose behind it.
('67', 125, 2, 19, 215584) Otherwise every labourer can be said to render social service.
('67', 125, 2, 20, 215647) He does in a way, but what is meant here is something much more than that.
('67', 125, 2, 21, 215722) A person who labours for the general good of all serves society and is worthy of his hire.
('67', 125, 2, 22, 215813) Therefore, such bread labour is not different from social service.
('67', 125, 2, 23, 215880) What the vast mass of mankind does for self or at best for family, a social servant does for general good.
('67', 125, 2, 24, 215987) These seven members today find that they have hardly time left for service other than that of slaving for their daily bread.
('67', 125, 2, 25, 216112) This need not be so if they were proficient in their work.
('67', 125, 2, 26, 216171) In fact they are not.
('67', 125, 2, 27, 216193) As field labourers, they are no match for the ordinary labourers.
('67', 125, 2, 28, 216259) As artisans too they are novices.
('67', 125, 2, 29, 216293) Every worker, thank God, now knows that with intelligent use of his tools a spinner can easily double his output in a given time.
('67', 125, 2, 30, 216423) That means doubling the income from the wheel.
('67', 125, 2, 31, 216470) This is true of most things.
('67', 125, 2, 32, 216499) In agriculture, the field for development with the same tools is so vast that unless Nature
('67', 125, 3, 33, 216591) 1 Only extracts are reproduced here.
('67', 126, 0, 1, 216628) VOL. 67: 25 APRIL, 1935 22 SEPTEMBER, 1935 127
('67', 126, 1, 2, 216675) interferes, a farmer can by the use of his intelligence any day quadruple his income, working the same number of hours per day.
('67', 126, 1, 3, 216803) This means that for the same amount of income he need not labour so much as he is now doing.
('67', 126, 1, 4, 216896) These workers can, therefore, when they have acquired proficiency, earn their bread in much less time than they need now, and will have energy set free for special Harijan or other service.
('67', 126, 1, 5, 217086) The problem becomes complicated for householders who have many calls on their purses, but a self denying worker whose needs amount to Rs. 4 per month has any day ample time at his disposal for work beyond labour that would bring him Rs. 4 per month.
('67', 126, 1, 6, 217336) But will three rupees per month needed out of four for food give a person enough to feed himself?
('67', 126, 1, 7, 217434) If Dr. Tilak’s figure for Bombay, i.e., Rs. 5 per month, is good, Rs. 3 for village life is certainly good.
('67', 126, 1, 8, 217542) And when I add my own experience to Dr. Tilak’s prescription there is no difficulty.
('67', 126, 1, 9, 217627) Dr. Tilak erases powdered milk from the village menu.
('67', 126, 1, 10, 217681) But as he says there is no escape from milk.
('67', 126, 1, 11, 217726) The inmates were wrong in eliminating milk from their dietary.
('67', 126, 1, 12, 217789) It is true that millions get not a drop of milk.
('67', 126, 1, 13, 217838) But they do not get many other things without which we dare not do if we are to live to serve.
('67', 126, 1, 14, 217933) We must therefore take those bare necessaries which we have to strive every villager to produce for himself.
('67', 126, 1, 15, 218042) Whole cereal, whether wheat, rice, bajri, juwar or the like, green edible leaves uncooked, milk, and any village fruit when in season such as mango, amrood, jamun, ber, etc., are indispensable for healthy life.
('67', 126, 1, 16, 218253) The prince among edible leaves is perhaps neem leaves, to be had for the picking everywhere in India; and there are many edible grasses of which we have no knowledge.
('67', 126, 1, 17, 218420) And tamarind fruit which is also obtainable everywhere is not to be despised.
('67', 126, 1, 18, 218498) There is, however, a prejudice against tamarind which is difficult to understand.
('67', 126, 1, 19, 218580) I have been using it liberally in the place of the expensive lemon with the greatest advantage.
('67', 126, 1, 20, 218676) Diet reform is a limitless field of research, fraught with the greatest consequences for the world and more especially for the famishing millions of India.
('67', 126, 1, 21, 218832) It means both health and wealth which according to Ruskin are one and the same thing.
('67', 126, 1, 22, 218918) The members of the little ashram are right in thinking that they will do the greatest social service by living right all along the line.
('67', 126, 1, 23, 219055) They will infect their surroundings whose limit may in course of time be the whole of India and then the universe.
('67', 126, 1, 24, 219170) In this service the welfare of one is the welfare of all.
('67', 126, 2, 25, 219228) Harijan, 1 6 1935

('67', 133, 7, 21, 228748) 210. LETTER TO S. L. SOKHEY
('67', 133, 8, 22, 228776) WARDHA, June 5, 1935
('67', 133, 9, 23, 228797) DEAR COL.
('67', 133, 9, 24, 228807) SOKHEY 2,
('67', 133, 10, 25, 228817) As you may be aware, in company with Sardar Patel I visited several villages of Borsad Taluka and saw the houses in those villages specially with a view to test the possibility of effectively using calcid for the destruction of rats and fleas.
('67', 133, 10, 26, 229061) I could see at a glance that such destruction was well nigh impossible unless you hold that calcid pumped into brick houses with storeys which are not air proof will reach every nook and corner and the burrows under floors.
('67', 133, 10, 27, 229285) Nor is it
('67', 133, 11, 28, 229295) 1 Vithaldas Jerajani 2 Director, Haffkine Institute, Bombay
('67', 134, 0, 1, 229355) VOL. 67: 25 APRIL, 1935 22 SEPTEMBER, 1935 135
('67', 134, 1, 2, 229402) possible to denude the houses of huge earthen or mud jars under and round which mice and rats take shelter.
('67', 134, 1, 3, 229510) The only thing effective in these cases seems to me to make the floors of all houses rat proof.
('67', 134, 1, 4, 229606) This was the method devised successfully in South Africa when the plague made its first appearance there.
('67', 134, 1, 5, 229712) The device was to tear open all cutcha floors without disturbing the super structure and make them pucka and rat proof.
('67', 134, 1, 6, 229832) This was easily and cheaply done by a liberal use of stone or brick and cement.
('67', 134, 1, 7, 229912) Dr. Bhasker Patel has [after] consultation with an experienced house contractor devised several cheap methods of floor renewal so as to make floors rat proof.
('67', 134, 1, 8, 230071) Leaflets have already been issued for the purpose.
('67', 134, 1, 9, 230122) If you can approve of the method, it will receive additional impetus and might be perfected under your kind guidance.
('67', 134, 1, 10, 230240) If you have anything further to say on behalf of the use of calcid or to criticize the method adopted of making houses rat proof you will please not hesitate to send your criticism freely.
('67', 134, 1, 11, 230429) Both the Sardar and I would welcome any criticism or advice you may have to offer.
('67', 134, 1, 12, 230512) I may add that the agent for calcid who went to Borsad whilst I was there opined to Dr. Patel after visiting a few houses that the calcid treatment is not applicable to them.
('67', 134, 1, 13, 230687) I discovered too that a judicious use of the special emulsion prepared by Dr. Bhasker Patel followed by sulphur fumigation had proved most effective for the destruction [of] fleas.
('67', 134, 1, 14, 230868) I must not omit to mention how grateful both Sardar and I were to you for showing us round the Institute with so much care.
('67', 134, 2, 15, 230992) Yours sincerely,
('67', 134, 3, 16, 231009) From a copy: Pyarelal Papers.

('67', 136, 1, 2, 233036) 213. LET US PRAY
('67', 136, 2, 3, 233053) WARDHAGANJ June 6, 1935 1
('67', 136, 3, 4, 233079) When a man is down, he prays to God to lift him up.
('67', 136, 3, 5, 233131) He is the Help of the helpless, says a Tamil proverb.
('67', 136, 3, 6, 233185) The appalling disaster 2 in Quetta paralyses one.
('67', 136, 3, 7, 233235) It baffles all attempt at reconstruction.
('67', 136, 3, 8, 233277) The whole truth about the disaster will perhaps never be known.
('67', 136, 3, 9, 233341) The dead cannot be recalled to life.
('67', 136, 3, 10, 233378) Human effort must be there always.
('67', 136, 3, 11, 233413) Those who are left behind must have help.
('67', 136, 3, 12, 233455) Such reconstruction as is possible will no doubt beundertaken.
('67', 136, 3, 13, 233518) All this and much more along the same line can never be a substitute for prayer.
('67', 136, 3, 14, 233599) But why pray at all?
('67', 136, 3, 15, 233620) Does not God, if there be One, know what has happened?
('67', 136, 3, 16, 233675) Does He stand in need of prayer to enable Him to do His duty?
('67', 136, 3, 17, 233737) No, God needs no reminder.
('67', 136, 3, 18, 233764) He is within everyone.
('67', 136, 3, 19, 233787) Nothing happens without His permission.
('67', 136, 3, 20, 233827) Our prayer is a heart search.
('67', 136, 3, 21, 233857) It is a reminder to ourselves that we are helpless without His support.
('67', 136, 3, 22, 233929) No effort is complete without prayer, without a definite recognition that the best human endeavour is of no effect if it has not God’s blessing behind it.
('67', 136, 3, 23, 234084) Prayer is a call to humility.
('67', 136, 3, 24, 234114) It is a call to self purification, to inward search.
('67', 136, 3, 25, 234167) I must repeat what I said at the time of the Bihar disaster 3. There is a divine purpose behind every physical calamity.
('67', 136, 3, 26, 234288) That perfected science will one day be able to tell us beforehand when earthquakes will occur, as it tells us today of eclipses, is quite possible.
('67', 136, 3, 27, 234436) It will be another triumph of the human mind.
('67', 136, 3, 28, 234482) But such triumphs even indefinitely multiplied can bring about no purification of self without which nothing is of any value.
('67', 136, 3, 29, 234608) Of course we will forget this latest calamity as we have forgotten the Bihar one.
('67', 136, 3, 30, 234690) I ask those who appreciate the necessity of inward purification to join in the prayer that we may read the purpose of God behind such visitations, that they may humble us and prepare us to face our Maker whenever the call comes, and that we may be ever ready to share the sufferings of our fellows whoever they may be.
('67', 136, 3, 31, 235009) Harijan, 8 6 1935
('67', 136, 4, 32, 235027) 1 From The Bombay Chronicle, 7 6 1935 2 Earthquake on May 31, 1935 3 Earthquake on January 15, 1934
('67', 137, 0, 1, 235127) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 138
('67', 137, 1, 2, 235169) 214. LETTER TO PRIVATE SECRETARY TO VICEROY 1
('67', 137, 2, 3, 235215) WARDHA, June 6, 1935
('67', 137, 3, 4, 235236) DEAR MR. MIEVILLE.
('67', 137, 4, 5, 235255) All differences vanish in the midst of the awful calamity in Quetta 2 following almost in the wake of Bihar.
('67', 137, 4, 6, 235364) I got the enclosed from Hyderabad today to which I sent a reply 3, copy of which is also enclosed herewith.
('67', 137, 4, 7, 235472) Hardly had I sent the reply when the voice within told me that I must enforce in my own action what I had advised Shri Jairamdas and Prof.
('67', 137, 4, 8, 235611) Kripalani—both Congress secretaries.
('67', 137, 4, 9, 235648) Hence this private approach to the highest authority.
('67', 137, 4, 10, 235702) If I am permitted, I should love to proceed to Quetta myself and do whatever is possible.
('67', 137, 4, 11, 235792) My submission is that a small relief committee should be formed comprising all sections to concert measures of relief.
('67', 137, 4, 12, 235911) In my opinion it is necessary to take the public into confidence about everything that may be done regarding alleviation of distress.
('67', 137, 4, 13, 236045) Will you please put this before His Excellency and if possible wire reply as to permission for me to proceed to Quetta?
('67', 137, 4, 14, 236165) If the permission is granted, it should include sufficient member[s] to enable me to do effective work.
('67', 137, 5, 15, 236269) E. C. MIEVILLE, ESQ.
('67', 137, 5, 16, 236290) PRIVATE SECRETARY TO H. E. THE VICEROY

('67', 142, 1, 2, 243462) 224. LETTER TO AMRIT KAUR
('67', 142, 2, 3, 243488) June 7, 1935
('67', 142, 3, 4, 243501) MY DEAR AMRIT, I see why your body wears itself out.
('67', 142, 3, 5, 243554) You insist on doing everything thoroughly.
('67', 142, 3, 6, 243597) Of course it is the right thing for any seeker.
('67', 142, 3, 7, 243645) But there is no warrant for any seeker taking over more than he or she can well manage.
('67', 142, 3, 8, 243733) I wonder whether I was right in letting you come into my movements.
('67', 142, 3, 9, 243801) God will take care of you.
('67', 142, 3, 10, 243828) You must cut down the social functions of Simla even though it may involve some seeming sacrifice of the good you might do to the movements you may be in.
('67', 142, 3, 11, 243983) No movement designed for the multitude will suffer by your conserving your time and energy by cutting down many social functions.
('67', 142, 3, 12, 244113) Now for khadi.
('67', 142, 3, 13, 244128) All Punjab shops are not run at a loss.
('67', 142, 3, 14, 244168) The Simla one has always been.
('67', 142, 3, 15, 244199) Management is no doubt defective.
('67', 142, 3, 16, 244233) But the people in Simla look down upon khadi and there is a class that is afraid to wear it.
('67', 142, 3, 17, 244326) The wearers become marked men.
('67', 142, 3, 18, 244357) Your idea of having a swadeshi mart on the Mall is attractive but its execution is risky.
('67', 142, 3, 19, 244447) However good swadeshi articles may be, they must suffer in comparison.
('67', 142, 3, 20, 244518) And I doubt the utility of aiming at gaudiness.
('67', 142, 3, 21, 244566) I differentiate between art and gaudiness.
('67', 142, 3, 22, 244609) What one sees in fashionable shop windows is by no means all art.
('67', 142, 3, 23, 244675) To produce things of real beauty and hope to put them side by side with the showy things of the Mall in Simla is an expensive ambition which we had better suppress at least for this season.
('67', 142, 3, 24, 244865) Do what you can with the shop as it is.
('67', 142, 3, 25, 244905) Convert it into something better.
('67', 142, 3, 26, 244939) Let there be swadeshi articles in it.
('67', 142, 3, 27, 244977) Arrange it after your taste and gain experiencebefore you take expensive quarters.
('67', 142, 3, 28, 245060) We must have this as one of the topics of discussion when you come down in July or August—the earlier the better.
('67', 142, 3, 29, 245174) You will read what I have felt and done about the Quetta disaster.
('67', 142, 3, 30, 245241) 1 You will read my letter 2 to Charlie.
('67', 142, 3, 31, 245281) He should know that one swallow does not make a summer.
('67', 142, 3, 32, 245337) He will have to trace me in Orissa or some such place when I take up walking again.
('67', 142, 3, 33, 245421) Meantime I accept 12 miles on the hills as a fair beginning.
('67', 142, 3, 34, 245482) I am waiting for the analysis of falsa 3.

('67', 143, 11, 28, 246639) BHAI PURUSHOTTAMDAS,
('67', 143, 12, 29, 246660) I understand what you say.

('67', 144, 1, 2, 247345) I will not involve you in the problem of village industries.
('67', 144, 1, 3, 247406) I give you this assurance, however, that that programme will not interfere with the movement for the protection of gold and silver.
('67', 144, 2, 4, 247538) Vandemataram from MOHANDAS
('67', 144, 3, 5, 247565) From Gujarati: Purushottamdas Thakurdas Papers, File No.
('67', 144, 3, 6, 247622) 159/1935. Courtesy: Nehru Memorial Museum and Library.
('67', 144, 4, 7, 247677) 227. TRUE KINSHIP
('67', 144, 5, 8, 247695) Those educated men who are conducting ashrams or are desirous of living in villages and have their physical constitutions disabled or ruined for want of use and find it difficult to do work involving physical labour and would yet be village workers, complain that unless they have at least one companion with them, they would feel lonely.
('67', 144, 5, 9, 248034) Those who would turn ashrams into colonies of farmers, dairymen and artisans, would do well to employ labour and treat the men and women so employed as if they were members of the ashram.
('67', 144, 5, 10, 248222) Thus they will understand the domestic and economic condition of their employees and will take them only if the wages paid would at all meet their wants.
('67', 144, 5, 11, 248376) They would interest themselves in their lives as they would if they were ashramites.
('67', 144, 5, 12, 248461) Labourers thus treated are likely to more than repay the wages taken by them.
('67', 144, 5, 13, 248539) It will be found that under such treatment the labourers will respond to the affection so lavishly bestowed upon them.
('67', 144, 5, 14, 248658) Under this scheme the founder will live his own life and the labourers theirs.
('67', 144, 5, 15, 248737) I have observed that the common kitchen often taxes the best resources of the ashram and becomes also a theatre for quarrels and heart burnings between the members.
('67', 144, 5, 16, 248902) This will be altogether avoided when the labourers alone are employed.
('67', 144, 5, 17, 248973) Labourers are used to food which they won’t leave and upon which they flourish.
('67', 144, 5, 18, 249053) Educated men’s tastes have become different and often artificial.
('67', 144, 5, 19, 249119) They would collapse if they attempted to live on labourers’ rations.
('67', 144, 5, 20, 249188) This is not to say that a common kitchen is a failure.
('67', 144, 5, 21, 249243) It is a necessity where the ideals are common and full kinship is a mutually recognized obligation.
('67', 144, 5, 22, 249343) This is not to be expected for many a year to come from the labourers.
('67', 145, 0, 1, 249414) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 146
('67', 145, 1, 2, 249456) The proposed scheme reduces chances of hypocrisy to a minimum and enables a natural union between intelligence and labour to be established.
('67', 145, 1, 3, 249597) Each will be complementary of the other.
('67', 145, 1, 4, 249638) There is, too, a chance of the ashram so conducted becoming immediately self supporting and rapidly developing.
('67', 145, 1, 5, 249750) This is all very well for the imaginary ashram or the ashrams which would experiment with the new scheme, but what about the village worker who becomes a villager for the first time in his life?
('67', 145, 1, 6, 249945) My scheme applies to him with necessary changes.
('67', 145, 1, 7, 249994) He must not regard himself as a different species from those in whose midst he is to go.
('67', 145, 1, 8, 250083) He must regard the villagers amidst whom he will work as friends and fellow workers.
('67', 145, 1, 9, 250168) According to his wants he will employ the willing labour of those whose services he may need.
('67', 145, 1, 10, 250262) And if he has enough intelligence that would suit the villagers, he may need the paid services of all the villagers who have enforced leisure and who would gladly employ it if they can.
('67', 145, 2, 11, 250448) Harijan, 8 6 1935

('67', 157, 7, 28, 266940) 253. TALK WITH A HARIJAN SEVAK 3
('67', 157, 8, 29, 266973) [Before June 15, 1935]
('67', 157, 9, 30, 266996) What are four years in the life of a nation, and what is even a lifetime in the vast space of eternity, when one remembered that one had to conquer the prejudices of centuries?
('67', 157, 9, 31, 267173) And have we tried enough and suffered enough?
('67', 157, 9, 32, 267219) Look at Booker T. Washington 4. Have any of
('67', 157, 10, 33, 267263) 1 Viyogi Hari 2 Lakshmi Marutidas Sharma 3 This is extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “Weekly Letter”.
('67', 157, 10, 34, 267362) The Harijan sevak had failed to get enought money for his institutions from the Harijan Sevak Sangh and was also unable to enlist the sympathies of young men during the four years of his service.
('67', 157, 10, 35, 267558) 4 American Negro educator, founder of the Tuskegee Institute.
('67', 157, 10, 36, 267620) He had to suffer great hardships as a youth.
('67', 158, 0, 1, 267665) VOL. 67: 25 APRIL, 1935 22 SEPTEMBER, 1935 159
('67', 158, 1, 2, 267712) us suffered as much as he did?
('67', 158, 1, 3, 267743) We narrate the woes of Harijans but do we ever share with them those woes?
('67', 158, 1, 4, 267818) They are sharp witted enough to see that we do not starve whilst it is they who have to starve, we have plenty of clean water to drink whereas they have dirty pools to depend upon.
('67', 158, 1, 5, 267999) The Harijan Sevak Sangh does not give you money.
('67', 158, 1, 6, 268048) Well, it is right from its point of view.
('67', 158, 1, 7, 268090) We have begun at the wrong end; we rely on outside assistance instead of relying on our own strength.
('67', 158, 1, 8, 268192) The time has come when we must cease to be spoonfed.
('67', 158, 1, 9, 268245) Why not teach the boys in the verandahs or their own sheds and make the school a natural growth from the soil?
('67', 158, 1, 10, 268356) Why not get them help you in growing your own grain and your vegetables and thus reduce the expenses of the boarding house?
('67', 158, 1, 11, 268480) It is preposterous for a school, say in Trivandrum, to depend on Delhi.
('67', 158, 1, 12, 268552) It is so unnatural.
('67', 158, 1, 13, 268572) It may have been necessary in the initial stages, but it should be no longer necessary now.
('67', 158, 1, 14, 268664) The man in charge of the school depending for his salary on Delhi is a foreigner there.
('67', 158, 1, 15, 268752) If he completely identifies himself with Harijans, they will share with him their meagre fare and will certainly not allow him to starve.
('67', 158, 1, 16, 268890) It is no use looking up to the Central Board every now and then.
('67', 158, 1, 17, 268955) The Central Board will keep the whole show nicely moving, but the sinews should come from the offshoots, the provincial boards.
('67', 158, 1, 18, 269083) But my mind is daily making so many discoveries that I feel that we might even dispense with collections.
('67', 158, 1, 19, 269189) If we have no money we have other resources, if only we knew the art of discovering them.
('67', 158, 1, 20, 269279) And why should the Harijans be the cause of despair?
('67', 158, 1, 21, 269332) Show me many people who can keep their pledges.
('67', 158, 1, 22, 269380) Have we kept all our pledges?
('67', 158, 1, 23, 269410) And why do we make so much of their carrion eating?
('67', 158, 1, 24, 269462) We want them to give it up no doubt, but it is no use getting impatient with them.
('67', 158, 1, 25, 269545) If many savarna Hindus eat flesh, naturally they will eat carrion.
('67', 158, 1, 26, 269612) There is hardly any chemical difference between meat and carrion.
('67', 158, 1, 27, 269678) You will remember Dr. Deshmukh wrote to me that he would find it impossible to distinguish between fresh meat and fresh carrion.
('67', 158, 1, 28, 269807) And the logic at least is with the Harijans.
('67', 158, 1, 29, 269852) A rich Hindu may afford to have a goat killed for himself, but what is a poor Harijan to do?
('67', 158, 1, 30, 269945) You will give him no live goat, and you will not allow him to eat a dead goat’s flesh that chance throws in his way.
('67', 158, 1, 31, 270062) No, We must realize that there is no vice among the Harijans that is not traceable to us.
('67', 158, 1, 32, 270152) It is we who have to do all the penance.
('67', 158, 1, 33, 270193) If crores of savarna Hindus will give up meat eating, Harijans will today give up carrion.
('67', 159, 0, 1, 270284) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 160
('67', 159, 1, 2, 270326) QUESTION: Could we ask them to leave their wretched abodes and settle in our midst?
('67', 159, 2, 3, 270410) ANSWER: This is more easily said than done.
('67', 159, 2, 4, 270454) If all caste Hindus become reformers your question won’t arise.
('67', 159, 2, 5, 270518) Today the reformers would be powerless to defend Harijans from molestation if they settled in savarna quarters.
('67', 159, 2, 6, 270630) But I would advocate exodus by Harijans from where they are persistently persecuted, as by the Nattars for example.
('67', 159, 3, 7, 270746) Q. What about making them go through an Upanayana 1 ceremony?
('67', 159, 4, 8, 270808) A. No; it involves the assumption that they are low and that they have got to be raised to a higher status.
('67', 159, 4, 9, 270916) There is nothing low about them.
('67', 159, 4, 10, 270949) Whatever appears to be low in them is a reflection of our own terrible lowness.
('67', 159, 4, 11, 271029) Supposing I have a diseased child, what shall I do with it?
('67', 159, 4, 12, 271089) Shall I discard it, shall I consider it low?
('67', 159, 4, 13, 271134) No, I shall have to remind myself that it is suffering for my sins, and that therefore it deserves extra care from me.
('67', 159, 4, 14, 271253) But here with the Harijans, let me tell you that I literally hold that they are far superior to us.
('67', 159, 4, 15, 271353) They have remained with us in spite of our persecution, and they are still clinging on to us.
('67', 159, 4, 16, 271447) It is a marvel of marvels to me that they continue to hold on to a religion, of which some of the adherents say that it has no place for them.
('67', 159, 4, 17, 271590) No, we must come down from the high pedestal we have occupied all these years and take our natural place with them.
('67', 159, 5, 18, 271706) Harijan, 15 6 1935
('67', 159, 6, 19, 271725) 254. IMPLICATIONS OF PRAYER
('67', 159, 7, 20, 271753) The few lines that I wrote 2 inviting the people to prayer and repentance on the Quetta disaster have given rise to some private correspondence.
('67', 159, 7, 21, 271898) One of the correspondents asks:
('67', 159, 8, 22, 271930) At the time of the Bihar quake you had no hesitation in saying that it was to be taken by savarna Hindus as a fit punishment for the sin of untouchability.
('67', 159, 8, 23, 272086) For what sin must the more terrible quake of Quetta be?
('67', 159, 8, 24, 272142) The writer had the right to put the question.
('67', 159, 8, 25, 272188) What I said about Bihar was deliberately said even as the lines on Quetta were deliberately written.
('67', 159, 8, 26, 272289) This call to prayer is a definite yearning of the soul.
('67', 159, 8, 27, 272345) Prayer is a sign of repentance, a desire to beocme better, purer.
('67', 159, 8, 28, 272411) A man of prayer regards what are known as physical calamities as divine chastisement.
('67', 159, 8, 29, 272497) It is a chastisement alike for individuals and for
('67', 159, 9, 30, 272548) 1 Wearing the sacred thread 2 Vide “ Let us Pray”, 6 6 1935
('67', 160, 0, 1, 272608) VOL. 67: 25 APRIL, 1935 22 SEPTEMBER, 1935 161
('67', 160, 1, 2, 272655) natioins.
('67', 160, 1, 3, 272665) All chastisements do not equally startle people.
('67', 160, 1, 4, 272714) Some affect only individuals, some others affect groups or nations only mildly.
('67', 160, 1, 5, 272794) Disasters like Quetta stun us.
('67', 160, 1, 6, 272825) Familiarity with ordinary everyday calamities breeds contempt for them.
('67', 160, 1, 7, 272897) If earthquakes were a daily occurrence, we would take no notice of them.
('67', 160, 1, 8, 272970) Even this Quetta one has not caused in us the same disturbance that the Bihar one did.
('67', 160, 1, 9, 273057) But it is the universal experience that every calamity brings a sensible man down on his knees.
('67', 160, 1, 10, 273153) He thinks that it is God’s answer to his sins and that he must henceforth behave better.
('67', 160, 1, 11, 273242) His sins have left him hopelessly weak, and in his weakness he cries out to God for help.
('67', 160, 1, 12, 273332) Thus have millions of human beings used their personal calamities for self improvement.
('67', 160, 1, 13, 273420) Nations too have been known to invoke the assistance of God when calamities have overtaken them.
('67', 160, 1, 14, 273517) They have abased themselves before God and appointed days of humiliation, prayer and purification.
('67', 160, 1, 15, 273616) I have suggested nothing new or original.
('67', 160, 1, 16, 273658) In these days of fashionable disbelief, it does need some courage to call men and women to repentance.
('67', 160, 1, 17, 273761) But I can claim no credit for courage.
('67', 160, 1, 18, 273800) For my weaknesses or idiosyncrasies are well known.
('67', 160, 1, 19, 273852) If I had known Quetta, as I know Bihar and Biharis, I would certainly have mentioned the sins of Quetta, though they might be no more its specialities than untouchability was Bihar’s.
('67', 160, 1, 20, 274036) But we all—the rulers and the ruled— know that we have many sins, personal and national, to answer for.
('67', 160, 1, 21, 274140) The call is to all these to repentance, prayer and humiliation.
('67', 160, 1, 22, 274204) True prayer is not a prelude to inaction.
('67', 160, 1, 23, 274246) It is a spur to ceaselesss, selfless action.
('67', 160, 1, 24, 274291) Purification is never for the selfishly idle, it accrues only to the selflessly industrious.
('67', 160, 2, 25, 274384) Harijan, 15 6 1935

('67', 161, 5, 9, 274797) 256. THE EVIL OF GAMBLING
('67', 161, 6, 10, 274823) A friend has been persistently asking me to draw public attention to the species of gambling prevalent in Bombay among the so called high class people.
('67', 161, 6, 11, 274975) Whilst I have been heart and soul with the friend in deploring the evil, I have not had the courage to write about it.
('67', 161, 6, 12, 275094) I felt that whatever I said would be a waste of effort, as I had no hope of following up my writing by some organized constructive effort to combat the evil.
('67', 161, 6, 13, 275252) Whilst I was thus debating as to writing on the evil, I had to go to Borsad in answer to the Sardar’s summons.
('67', 161, 6, 14, 275363) There in Borsad the Sardar and his volunteers poured into my ears harrowing tales of the havoc that gambling was working in the villages of Gujarat.
('67', 161, 6, 15, 275512) It is spreading like grass fire of a windy night.
('67', 161, 6, 16, 275562) Everybody is in a hurry to be rich without working.
('67', 161, 6, 17, 275614) ‘Somebody will have made the correct guess as to the ruling price for the day of some commodity.
('67', 161, 6, 18, 275711) Why not I?’—argues the gambler and rushes to his ruin.
('67', 161, 6, 19, 275766) Peace is being destroyed in the once happy homes of Gujarat.
('67', 161, 6, 20, 275827) There is no doubt that whatever one calls it, this gambling is as old as Adam, and that though the form and the name may have changed, the substance has not changed at all.
('67', 161, 6, 21, 276000) The law must be against this gambling.
('67', 161, 6, 22, 276039) But it is of no avail if public opinion is not behind it.
('67', 161, 6, 23, 276097) It is therefore necessary for workers to
('67', 161, 7, 24, 276138) 1 The letter is not reproduced here.
('67', 161, 7, 25, 276175) The correspondent had drawn attention to the primitive process of oil pressing which resulted in much wastage.
('67', 161, 7, 26, 276286) He had mentioned that villagers did not even make use of the cake and those who used “unginned cotton on the adhi system threw away the cotton seeds”.
('67', 161, 7, 27, 276437) He had suggested to A.I.S.A. workers there to set up a ghani to be made available to the villagers “at no cost or for a part of the cake”.
('67', 162, 0, 1, 276576) VOL. 67: 25 APRIL, 1935 22 SEPTEMBER, 1935 163
('67', 162, 1, 2, 276623) bestir themselves as they did during the plague or as they have done for the earthquake relief.
('67', 162, 1, 3, 276719) They must not be satisfied till the evil is rooted out.
('67', 162, 1, 4, 276775) In a way it is worse than the plague or the quake.
('67', 162, 1, 5, 276826) For it destroys the soul within.
('67', 162, 1, 6, 276859) A person without the soul is a burden upon the earth.
('67', 162, 1, 7, 276913) No doubt war against gambling is not so simple as war against plague or earthquake distress.
('67', 162, 1, 8, 277006) In the latter there is more or less co operation from the sufferers.
('67', 162, 1, 9, 277075) In the former the sufferers invite and hug their sufferings.
('67', 162, 1, 10, 277136) To wean the gambler from his vice is like weaning the drunkard from the drink habit.
('67', 162, 1, 11, 277221) This war against gambling is therefore an uphill task.
('67', 162, 1, 12, 277276) But it must be tackled, if the evil is not dealt with in time.
('67', 162, 1, 13, 277339) It is bad enough in Bombay.
('67', 162, 1, 14, 277367) Its inroad upon the villages is a danger signal which no lover of the country can dare ignore.
('67', 162, 2, 15, 277462) Harijan, 15 6 1935
('67', 162, 3, 16, 277481) 257. LETTER TO S. AMBUJAMMAL

('67', 162, 5, 18, 277532) AMBUJAM,
('67', 162, 6, 19, 277541) I have your letter.
('67', 162, 6, 20, 277561) I hope that Kichi 1 is out of fever.
('67', 162, 6, 21, 277598) What is the matter with him?
('67', 162, 6, 22, 277627) When you are not there, with whom does he stay?
('67', 162, 6, 23, 277675) How does he pass his time?
('67', 162, 6, 24, 277702) Does he interest himself in any thing or person?
('67', 162, 6, 25, 277751) Kamala has written to me.
('67', 162, 6, 26, 277777) How nice it would be if you could come with her.
('67', 162, 6, 27, 277826) 2 But I know you must not leave Father or Kichi just now.

('67', 164, 7, 11, 280130) I have your letter.
('67', 164, 7, 12, 280150) The point you raised cannot be discussed in the pages of the Harijan.
('67', 164, 7, 13, 280220) I think that Dr. Gopichand’s opinion is quite sound.
('67', 164, 7, 14, 280273) Only I would go a step further and say that as Sangh we ought not to carry on any agitation regarding what may be done by the Government.
('67', 164, 7, 15, 280411) Our scope is confined to such work as we can do without the assistance of the Government.
('67', 164, 7, 16, 280501) We should appreciate every step that the Government may take.
('67', 164, 7, 17, 280563) It is open to us to give co operation to the Government if and when they seek it.
('67', 164, 7, 18, 280645) But it is outside our province to criticize the Government or to carry on platform agitation with a view to secure measures from the Government.
('67', 164, 7, 19, 280790) This is not conceived as a permanent policy but for the moment I have not doubt that it is the only sound policy for us to follow.
('67', 164, 7, 20, 280921) We must recognize that Harijans at the present moment are undecided as to what they should do.
('67', 164, 7, 21, 281016) We must deserve their absolute confidence before we can hope to influence the Government along the lines that we may desire.
