('67', 172, 8, 21, 293621) 275. AN AWARD 1
('67', 172, 9, 22, 293637) June 18, 1935
('67', 172, 10, 23, 293651) With the consent of both the parties concerned, I have been involved in the grievances of the workers of the Bombay bhandar of the All India Spinners’ Association against their local agent.
('67', 172, 10, 24, 293841) I have gone through the papers presented by both parties.
('67', 172, 11, 25, 293899) 1 Vide also the following two items.
('67', 173, 0, 1, 293936) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 174
('67', 173, 1, 2, 293978) The notice served on Mr. Ganatra was improper.
('67', 173, 1, 3, 294025) This defect can be overcome by giving him additional salary.
('67', 173, 1, 4, 294086) The conduct of the workers and their written memoranda after the notice had been served were rude and not befitting those who serve the cause of khadi.
('67', 173, 1, 5, 294238) Such conduct cannot keep any institution going.
('67', 173, 1, 6, 294286) Hence, the agent is justified in dismissing the workers who misbehaved.
('67', 173, 1, 7, 294358) However, if the workers give a written apology as suggested in the appendix, the agent should reinstate everyone including Shri Ganatra without any deductions from their salaries.
('67', 173, 1, 8, 294538) If the workers do not hand in the letter of apology within seventy two hours of this resolution reaching Shri Ratubhai Desai,the representative of the workers, they would not be able to join their duty and the notice they have been served with will hold good permanently.
('67', 173, 1, 9, 294810) The agent is of the opinion that the bhandar does not have the capacity to bear the burden of the number of workers employed there.
('67', 173, 1, 10, 294942) The award I have given above does not preclude any changes in the bhandar, reduction in the number of workers engaged or in their present salaries.
('67', 173, 1, 11, 295090) I myself wish to make some suggestions regarding the way in which all khadi bhandars are being run, and it has become necessary to state them now.
('67', 173, 1, 12, 295237) It is my hope that the workers will willingly sign the letter of apology and return to their duty in the bhandar.
('67', 173, 1, 13, 295351) In case all the dismissed workers do not accept the above decision, the agent shall take back those who do so.
('67', 173, 2, 14, 295462) M. K. GANDHI
('67', 173, 3, 15, 295475) APPENDIX
('67', 173, 4, 16, 295484) After Shri Ganatra received the notice of dismissal, his and our behaviour was not worthy of the khadi workers.
('67', 173, 4, 17, 295596) The letters we wrote were rude.
('67', 173, 4, 18, 295628) We are sorry for such conduct.
('67', 173, 4, 19, 295659) Hereafter we shall ceaselessly endeavour not to behave in that manner.

('67', 176, 5, 12, 299002) Unrevised WARDHA, June 19, 1935 MY DEAR AMRIT, The frank admission of one’s proved helplessness does not make one a coward but may be the beginning of bravery.
('67', 176, 5, 13, 299162) I am taking you at your word and dictating.
('67', 176, 5, 14, 299206) Writing with the left hand is a pleasure to me but I cannot do it with the same ease and quickness as with right hand.

('67', 176, 5, 25, 299858) If you cannot secure good steel, they can be made of any iron.

('67', 176, 5, 27, 299971) A weak spindle spins as well as any other, so long as it remains true.

('67', 182, 7, 15, 310955) 290. DISCUSSION WITH A VISITOR FROM QUETTA 1
('67', 182, 8, 16, 311000) [Before June 22, 1935]

('67', 183, 3, 10, 312574) 291. A DISCUSSION 1
('67', 183, 4, 11, 312594) [Before June 22, 1935]
('67', 183, 5, 12, 312617) GANDHIJI: Is not this wheel a machine?
('67', 183, 6, 13, 312656) [SOCIALIST:] I do not mean this machine, but I mean bigger machinery.
('67', 183, 6, 14, 312726) Do you mean Singer’s sewing machine?
('67', 183, 6, 15, 312763) That too is protected by the village industries movement, and for that matter any machinery which does not deprive masses of men of the opportunity to labour, but which helps the individual and adds to his efficiency, and which a man can handle at will without being its slave.
('67', 183, 7, 16, 313041) But what about the great inventions?
('67', 183, 7, 17, 313078) You would have nothing to do with electricity?
('67', 183, 7, 18, 313125) Who said so?
('67', 183, 7, 19, 313138) If we could have electricity in every village home, I should not mind villagers plying their implements and tools with the help of electricity.
('67', 183, 7, 20, 313282) But then the village communities or the State would own power houses, just as they have their grazing pastures.
('67', 183, 7, 21, 313394) But where there is no electricity and no machinery, what are idle hands to do?
('67', 183, 7, 22, 313473) Will you give them work, or would you have their owners cut them down for want of work?
('67', 183, 7, 23, 313561) I would prize every invention of science made for the benefit of all.
('67', 183, 7, 24, 313631) There is a difference between invention and invention.
('67', 183, 7, 25, 313686) I should not care for the asphyxiating gases capable of killing masses of men
('67', 183, 8, 26, 313764) 1 This is extracted from “Weekly Letter” by Mahadev Desai, who had reported: “A socialist holding a brief for machinery asked Gandhiji if the village industries movement was not meant to oust all machinery.” 2 Gandhiji was just then spinning.
('67', 184, 0, 1, 314007) VOL. 67: 25 APRIL, 1935 22 SEPTEMBER, 1935 185
('67', 184, 1, 2, 314054) at a time.
('67', 184, 1, 3, 314065) The heavy machinery for work of public utility which cannot be undertaken by human labour has its inevitable place, but all that would be owned by the State and used entirely for the benefit of the people.

('67', 184, 2, 15, 314905) 292. NOTES
('67', 184, 3, 16, 314916) HELPLESS WIDOWS A bereaved friend sends a pathetic letter describing the plight of a 17 year old girl, who has lost in Quetta her husband, two months old child, father in law and her husband’s younger brother, that is to say everybody in her father in law’s house.
('67', 184, 3, 17, 315181) My correspondent adds that she escaped unhurt and returned with only her clothes on.
('67', 184, 3, 18, 315266) She is his uncle’s daughter and he does not know how to console her or what to do with her.
('67', 184, 3, 19, 315358) She herself is not undamaged.
('67', 184, 3, 20, 315388) Her leg has been injured, though fortunately the bone remains intact.
('67', 184, 3, 21, 315458) The correspondent concluded by saying:
('67', 184, 4, 22, 315497) I have left her with her mother in Lahore.
('67', 184, 4, 23, 315540) I gently mentioned to her and other relatives whether the girl might not be remarried.
('67', 184, 4, 24, 315627) Some listened to me sympathetically and some resented the proposal.
('67', 184, 4, 25, 315695) I have no doubt that many a girl must have suffered the same fate as this cousin of mine.
('67', 184, 4, 26, 315785) Will you say a word of encouragement to these unfortunate widows?
('67', 184, 4, 27, 315851) I do not know what my pen or voice can do in matters in which age long prejudices are concerned.
('67', 184, 4, 28, 315948) I have repeatedly said that every widow has as much right to remarry as every widower.
('67', 184, 4, 29, 316035) Voluntary widowhood is a priceless boon in Hinduism; enforced widowhood is a curse.
('67', 184, 4, 30, 316119) And I very much feel that many young widows if they were absolutely free, not so much from the fear of physical restraint as from the opprobrium of Hindu public opinion, would remarry
('67', 185, 0, 1, 316303) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 186
('67', 185, 1, 2, 316345) without the slightest hesitation.
('67', 185, 1, 3, 316379) All the young widows, therefore, who are in the unfortunate position of this bereaved sister from Quetta should have every inducement given to them to remarry, and should be sure that no blame would be attached to them if they chose to remarry, and every effort should be made to select for them suitable matches.
('67', 185, 1, 4, 316693) This is not work that can be done by any institution.
('67', 185, 1, 5, 316747) This work has got to be done by individual reformers whose relatives have become widows, and they have to carry on a vigorous, dignified and restrained propaganda in their own circles, and whenever they succeed they should give the widest publicity to the event.
('67', 185, 1, 6, 317010) Thus, and only thus, there is likely to be tangible relief provided for the girls who might have become widows during the earthquake.
('67', 185, 1, 7, 317144) It is possible that the public sympathy can be easily mobilized whilst the memory of the tragedy is fresh in mind, and if once the reform takes place on a large scale, the girls who may have become widows in the natural course will also find it easy to get married if they are willing to do so.
('67', 185, 2, 8, 317439) THE THREE SERVICES Khadi service, village service and Harijan service are all one in reality, though three in name.
('67', 185, 2, 9, 317555) They are purely humanitarian services with no other aim than that of serving Daridranarayana.
('67', 185, 2, 10, 317649) Harijans are the most down trodden among the millions of Daridranarayanas.
('67', 185, 2, 11, 317724) Their service necessarily includes that of all.
('67', 185, 2, 12, 317772) A cup of water served to a Harijan in the name of God is a cup served to all the neglected ones of humanity.
('67', 185, 2, 13, 317881) With services so conceived it is wrong to associate ideas of capital and labour.
('67', 185, 2, 14, 317962) From the unpaid chairmen to the salaried bearers all are servants.
('67', 185, 2, 15, 318029) The funds belong to the respective trusts.
('67', 185, 2, 16, 318072) All the servants, whether paid or unpaid, are subject to the rules framed from time to time by the respective boards.
('67', 185, 2, 17, 318190) Where the whole idea is one of duty, there is no question of privilege.
('67', 185, 2, 18, 318262) Anyone therefore in these services who thinks of privileges and rights is doomed some day or other to disappointment.
('67', 185, 2, 19, 318380) For in these services there is no gradual betterment of the economic condition; on the contrary, there is or there soon will be a progressive renunciation of material advantage.
('67', 185, 2, 20, 318558) ‘Duty will be merit when debt becomes a donation.’ Duty done is its own reward.
('67', 185, 2, 21, 318638) Satisfaction there undoubtedly is in these services.
('67', 185, 2, 22, 318691) But it is that of having done one’s duty.
('67', 185, 2, 23, 318733) It is true that all have not approached their tasks in the spirit of pure service.
('67', 185, 2, 24, 318816) Hence there have been exhibitions of distemper now and then in the oldest of the three services.
('67', 185, 2, 25, 318913) The only way to avoid a repetition of these distempers is to
('67', 186, 0, 1, 318974) VOL. 67: 25 APRIL, 1935 22 SEPTEMBER, 1935 187
('67', 186, 1, 2, 319021) remind ourselves that we are in these services merely to discharge our obligations to Daridranarayana, not to seek privileges.
('67', 186, 1, 3, 319148) We own no master but Daridranarayana, and if for the time being we own human superiors, we do so voluntarily, well knowing that no organization can be carried on without discipline.
('67', 186, 1, 4, 319330) Discipline presupposes an organizing head.
('67', 186, 1, 5, 319373) He is only the first among equals.
('67', 186, 1, 6, 319408) And being purely a servant, in order to be the head, he has to be the humblestof all his co servants.
('67', 186, 1, 7, 319510) He is there on sufferance.
('67', 186, 1, 8, 319537) But whilst he is there, he is entitled to the whole hearted allegiance and uncomplaining obedience of all the fellow servants.
('67', 186, 2, 9, 319664) Harijan, 22 6 1935
('67', 186, 3, 10, 319683) 293. ALL LIFE IS ONE
('67', 186, 4, 11, 319704) During my brief visit to Borsad last month in several of my speeches I had said that, although I believed that even plague stricken rats and fleas were my kindred and had as much right to live as I had, I had no hesitation in endorsing Dr. Bhaskar Patel’s campaign against rats and fleas.
('67', 186, 4, 12, 319993) A reporter who was struck by this claim to kinship with rats and fleas, but not interested in the context in which I had said it, telegraphed to his paper the interesting claim I had advanced.
('67', 186, 4, 13, 320186) The Sardar’s eagle eye caught the paragraph and wanted me to correct the mischief it was likely to do.
('67', 186, 4, 14, 320289) Being immersed in the work he had entrusted me with, I excused myself by saying that the people concerned would not misunderstand me.
('67', 186, 4, 15, 320423) But perhaps the Sardar was right.
('67', 186, 4, 16, 320457) For the paragraph containing the half truth was wired to London.
('67', 186, 4, 17, 320522) Those who are jealous about my European reputation were agitated, though they had realized that my claim to kinship must have had large qualifications.
('67', 186, 4, 18, 320674) They have sent me the clipping containing the paragraph.
('67', 186, 4, 19, 320731) I am bound now, if only for the sake of these loving friends, to clear the position though the half truth having had a start cannot be overtaken at once.
('67', 186, 4, 20, 320885) I was in the midst of a population which would not kill wild animals that daily destroy their crops.
('67', 186, 4, 21, 320986) Before the Sardar threw the whole weight of his tremendous influence into the campaign of the destruction of rats and fleas, the people of the Borsad Taluka had not destroyed a single rat or flea.
('67', 186, 4, 22, 321183) But they could not resist the Sardar to whom they had owed much, and Dr. Bhaskar Patel was allowed to
('67', 187, 0, 1, 321285) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 188
('67', 187, 1, 2, 321327) carry on wholesale destruction of rats and fleas.
('67', 187, 1, 3, 321377) I was in daily touch with what was going on in Borsad.
('67', 187, 1, 4, 321432) The Sardar had invited me naturally to endorse what had been done.
('67', 187, 1, 5, 321499) For the work had still to continue, though henceforth with the people’s own unaided effort.
('67', 187, 1, 6, 321591) Therefore, in order to emphasize my endorsement, I redeclared in the clearest possible terms my implicit belief in ahimsa, i.e., sacredness and kinship of all life.
('67', 187, 1, 7, 321756) But why this contradiction between belief and action?
('67', 187, 1, 8, 321810) Contradiction is undoubtedly there.
('67', 187, 1, 9, 321846) Life is an aspiration.
('67', 187, 1, 10, 321869) Its mission is to strive after perfection which is self realization.
('67', 187, 1, 11, 321938) The ideal must not be lowered because of our weaknesses or imperfections.
('67', 187, 1, 12, 322012) I am painfully conscious of both in me.
('67', 187, 1, 13, 322052) The silent cry daily goes out to Truth to help me to remove these weaknesses and imperfections of mine.
('67', 187, 1, 14, 322156) I own my fear of snakes, scorpions, lions, tigers, plague stricken rats and fleas, even as I must own fear of evil looking robbers and murderers.
('67', 187, 1, 15, 322302) I know that I ought not to fear any of them.
('67', 187, 1, 16, 322347) But this is no intellectual feat.
('67', 187, 1, 17, 322381) It is a feat of the heart.
('67', 187, 1, 18, 322408) It needs more than a heart of oak to shed all fear except the fear of God.
('67', 187, 1, 19, 322483) I could not in my weakness ask the people of Borsad not to kill deadly rats and fleas.
('67', 187, 1, 20, 322570) But I knew that it was a concession to human weakness.
('67', 187, 1, 21, 322625) Nevertheless there is that difference between a belief in ahimsa and a belief in himsa which there is between north and south, life and death.
('67', 187, 1, 22, 322768) One who hooks his fortunes to ahimsa, the law of love, daily lessens the circle of destruction and to that extent promotes life and love; he who swears by himsa, the law of hate, daily widens the circle of destruction and to that extent promotes death and hate.
('67', 187, 1, 23, 323030) Though, before the people of Borsad, I endorsed the destruction of rats and fleas, my own kith and kin, I preached to them without adulteration the grand doctrine of the eternal Law of love of all life.
('67', 187, 1, 24, 323233) Though I may fail to carry it out to the full in this life, my faith in it shall abide.
('67', 187, 1, 25, 323321) Every failure brings me nearer the realization.
('67', 187, 2, 26, 323369) Harijan, 22 6 1935
('67', 187, 3, 27, 323388) 294. FAECES AS CATTLE FOOD
('67', 187, 4, 28, 323415) I have seen in childhood in Porbandar cows freely eating human faeces.
('67', 187, 4, 29, 323486) The practice appeared to me to be revolting and the feeling has persisted to this day.
('67', 187, 4, 30, 323573) But a correspondent wrote telling me that in Satara district it was the usual thing for gwalis to pay for the right of
('67', 188, 0, 1, 323692) VOL. 67: 25 APRIL, 1935 22 SEPTEMBER, 1935 189
('67', 188, 1, 2, 323739) getting access to the pekhanas of people so that their cattle may eat the faeces from day to day.
('67', 188, 1, 3, 323837) The correspondent said that the feeding of cow with faeces increased the yield of milk.
('67', 188, 1, 4, 323925) Having no reason to doubt my correspondent’s veracity I asked a medical friend to obtain an expert’s opinion on the statement.
('67', 188, 1, 5, 324052) Here is the startling opinion:
('67', 188, 2, 6, 324083) Normal faeces contain some nutritive material in the form of cellulose and nitrogenous material.
('67', 188, 2, 7, 324180) The main substance in the faeces which might produce some physiological action on the animal feeding on them is vitamin B. “That vitamin B is present in the faeces was shown by Cooper (1914).
('67', 188, 2, 8, 324372) He cured polyneuritic pigeons by administering an alcoholic extract of faeces.
('67', 188, 2, 9, 324451) There seems to be general agreement that the nursing animal requires an increased amount of vitamin B in order to suckle her young successfully.” (Vide Monograph on Vitamins published by Pickett Thomson Research Laboratory, London.)
('67', 188, 3, 10, 324684) It is quite possible that animals feeding on faeces get a liberal supply of this vitamin which ensures a copious secretion of milk from the active mammary gland.
('67', 188, 4, 11, 324846) Lack of appetite and deficient utilization of food are well marked characteristics of vitamin B deficiency in the diet, and it is quite likely that cows that feed on faeces along with other vegetable foodstuffs will put on fat owing to stimulation of appetite by vitamin B and greater utilization of carbohydrate food which is mostly transformed into fat in herbivorous animals.
('67', 188, 5, 12, 325225) As regards the bacteria, etc., which are normally to be found in the stools of human beings, it may be said that most of them are dead or dying bacteria and that the few that survive are killed by the gastric juice in the cow’s stomach.
('67', 188, 5, 13, 325462) Thus though the chemical evidence in favour of human excreta as good food for cattle may be said to be established, the psychological objection will persist.
('67', 188, 6, 14, 325620) Harijan, 22 6 1935

('67', 191, 7, 10, 329197) 300. LETTER TO MOOLCHAND AGRAWAL
('67', 191, 8, 11, 329230) June 23, 1935
('67', 191, 9, 12, 329244) BHAI MOOLCHAND,
('67', 191, 10, 13, 329260) I have your letter.
('67', 191, 10, 14, 329280) Yours is a sad tale, but you can make it a means of dharma.
('67', 191, 10, 15, 329340) Compassion subserves dharma.
('67', 191, 10, 16, 329369) Dharma is put to test in adversity.
('67', 191, 10, 17, 329405) When a wife does not follow the husband, how can she become his help mate?
('67', 191, 10, 18, 329480) She has a right to follow a different dharma and so has the husband.
('67', 191, 10, 19, 329549) But when a wife follows an opposite dharma, she should not expect co operation or cohabitation from the husband.
('67', 191, 10, 20, 329662) She has every right to get maintenance from the husband.
('67', 191, 10, 21, 329719) A husband who can be passionless towards his wife, and who remains and would remain passionless towards other women, has a right to part with his wife under such circumstances.
('67', 191, 10, 22, 329896) So she should have complete freedom to stay away from you and live her own life.
('67', 191, 10, 23, 329977) There is no cause for anger here.
('67', 191, 10, 24, 330011) Let no harsh word be said to the wife.
('67', 191, 10, 25, 330050) She should be reminded of her dharma affectionately; and non co operation should follow.
('67', 191, 10, 26, 330139) Then comes the problem of the children.

('67', 192, 4, 5, 330500) You cannot do social service by neglecting your duty to your father, mother and wife.
('67', 192, 4, 6, 330586) This duty is not opposed to social service.
('67', 192, 4, 7, 330630) It is necessary to understand the nature and scope of one’s duty to one’s mother and father.
('67', 192, 4, 8, 330723) It is the duty of a husband to provide for his wife and to live with her, with due restraint, as long as she can tread the same path of duty.
('67', 192, 4, 9, 330865) If the mother and father are invalid or poor and if they have no other son, it becomes one’s duty to provide for them and to serve them.
('67', 192, 4, 10, 331002) I take goat’s milk as I was driven to it.
('67', 192, 4, 11, 331044) My vow prevented me from taking cow’s or buffalo’s milk.
('67', 192, 4, 12, 331101) I resorted to a narrow interpretation of the vow and secured the freedom to take goat’s milk.

('67', 201, 1, 2, 343431) 321. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('67', 201, 2, 3, 343462) WARDHA, June 27, 1935
('67', 201, 3, 4, 343484) NARANDAS, If I am routing all my letters to Harilal through you, there is some purpose behind it, viz., to enable you to know what your relationship with Harilal should be although you may not take part in the inquiry.
('67', 201, 3, 5, 343703) This question has become one of very great importance to me, as you will see from my letters to him.
('67', 201, 3, 6, 343804) Still, even after reading all these letters, you are free to form your own impression of Harilal and act accordingly.
('67', 201, 3, 7, 343922) If you have to feed him, you may give him any work to do which involves no risk.
('67', 201, 3, 8, 344003) But this does not mean that you are bound to maintain relations with him or give him work.
('67', 201, 3, 9, 344094) The bond of blood relationship also has its limits.
('67', 201, 3, 10, 344146) It shouldn’t make us violate moral principles.
('67', 201, 3, 11, 344193) Harilal cannot have greater claims on you than a stranger placed in similar circumstances.
('67', 201, 3, 12, 344284) We should rather be more generous towards a stranger and more miserly towards Harilal.
('67', 201, 3, 13, 344371) That is, the more intimate the blood relationship, the stricter should our attitude be.
('67', 201, 3, 14, 344459) Only thus can we do pure justice.
('67', 201, 4, 15, 344493) Blessings from BAPU
('67', 201, 5, 16, 344513) From a photostat of the Gujarati: M.M.U./II.
('67', 201, 5, 17, 344558) Also C.W. 8456. Courtesy: Narandas Gandhi

('67', 206, 0, 1, 351528) VOL. 67: 25 APRIL, 1935 22 SEPTEMBER, 1935 207
('67', 206, 1, 2, 351575) 329. DUTY OF BREAD LABOUR
('67', 206, 2, 3, 351601) Brahma created his people with the duty of sacrifice laid upon them and said: ‘By this do you flourish.
('67', 206, 2, 4, 351705) Let it be the fulfiller of all your desires.’ He who eats without performing this sacrifice eats stolen bread.
('67', 206, 2, 5, 351816) Thus says the Gita.
('67', 206, 2, 6, 351836) “Earn thy bread by the sweat of thy brow”, says the Bible.
('67', 206, 2, 7, 351895) Sacrifices may be of many kinds.
('67', 206, 2, 8, 351928) One of them may well be bread labour.
('67', 206, 2, 9, 351966) If all laboured for their bread and no more, then there would be enough food and enough leisure for all.
('67', 206, 2, 10, 352071) Then there would be no cry of over population, no disease, and no such misery as we see around.
('67', 206, 2, 11, 352167) Such labour will be the highest form of a sacrifice.
('67', 206, 2, 12, 352220) Men will no doubt do many other things either through their bodies or through their minds, but all this will be labour of love, for the common good.
('67', 206, 2, 13, 352369) There will then beno rich and no poor, none high and none low, no touchable and no untouchable.
('67', 206, 2, 14, 352465) This may be an unattainable ideal.
('67', 206, 2, 15, 352500) But we need not, therefore, cease to strive for it.
('67', 206, 2, 16, 352552) Even if without fulfilling the whole law of sacrifice, that is, the law of our being, we performed physical labour enough for our daily bread, we should go a long way towards the ideal.
('67', 206, 2, 17, 352738) If we did so, our wants would be minimized, our food would be simple.
('67', 206, 2, 18, 352808) We should then eat to live, not live to eat.
('67', 206, 2, 19, 352853) Let anyone who doubts the accuracy of this proposition try to sweat for his bread, he will derive the greatest relish from the productions of his labour, improve his health and discover that many things he took were superfluities.
('67', 206, 2, 20, 353084) May not men earn their bread by intellectual labour?
('67', 206, 2, 21, 353137) The needs of the body must be supplied by the body.
('67', 206, 2, 22, 353189) “Render unto Caesar that which is Caesar’s” perhaps applies here well.
('67', 206, 2, 23, 353260) Mere mental, that is, intellectual labour is for the soul and is its own satisfaction.
('67', 206, 2, 24, 353347) It should never demand payment.
('67', 206, 2, 25, 353379) In the ideal State, doctors, lawyers and the like will work solely for the benefit of society, not for self.
('67', 206, 2, 26, 353488) Obedience to the law of bread labour will bring about a silent revolution in the structure of society.
('67', 206, 2, 27, 353591) Man’s triumph will consist in substituting the struggle for existence by the struggle for mutual service.
('67', 206, 2, 28, 353697) The law of the brute will be replaced by the law of man.
('67', 207, 0, 1, 353754) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 208
('67', 207, 1, 2, 353796) Return to the villages means a definite voluntary recognition of the duty of bread labour and all it connotes.
('67', 207, 1, 3, 353907) But says the critic, “millions of India’s children are today living in the villages and yet they are living a life of semi starvation”.
('67', 207, 1, 4, 354043) This, alas, is but too true.
('67', 207, 1, 5, 354072) Fortunately we know that theirs is not voluntary obedience.
('67', 207, 1, 6, 354132) They would perhaps shirk body labour if they could, and even rush to the nearest city if they could be accommodated in it.
('67', 207, 1, 7, 354255) Compulsory obedience to a master is state of slavery, willing obedience to one’s father is the glory of sonship.
('67', 207, 1, 8, 354368) Similarly compulsory obedience to the law of bread labour breeds poverty, disease and discontent.
('67', 207, 1, 9, 354466) It is a state of slavery.
('67', 207, 1, 10, 354492) Willing obedience to it must bring contentment and health.
('67', 207, 1, 11, 354551) And it is health which is real wealth, not pieces of silver and gold.
('67', 207, 1, 12, 354621) The Village Industries Association is an experiment in willing bread labour.
('67', 207, 2, 13, 354698) Harijan, 29 6 1935
('67', 207, 3, 14, 354717) 330. IMPROVEMENT IN SPINNING
('67', 207, 4, 15, 354746) Investigations made in Savli, one of the good centres of khadi production, reveal the fact that the spinners there earn no more than one pie per hour on an average.
('67', 207, 4, 16, 354911) Fortunately they have other sources of income or they are members of families whose other members are following some more remunerative occupations.
('67', 207, 4, 17, 355059) But a khadi servant cannot afford to be satisfied with this knowledge.
('67', 207, 4, 18, 355130) He must devise means of increasing the spinners’ wage.
('67', 207, 4, 19, 355185) There are three ways of doing it: (1) By paying a higher wage and increasing the price of commercial khadi.
('67', 207, 4, 20, 355293) (2) By inviting the ginners, carders and weavers to divide their wages with the spinners.
('67', 207, 4, 21, 355383) (3) By making improvements in the existing wheels and by teaching the spinners to be more careful than they are.
('67', 207, 4, 22, 355496) If this last was not possible, one of the first two alternatives would be obligatory, but improvement in the existing machines and in the spinners’ manners is undoubtedly possible.
('67', 207, 4, 23, 355677) Had Messrs Kirloskars’ efforts come up to mark, the spinners’ wage would easily have gone up to nine pies per hour.
('67', 207, 4, 24, 355793) But that was not to be.
('67', 207, 4, 25, 355817) Though it was easily the best among all the attempts submitted to the A. I. S. A., it was not considered by the judges to satisfy the tests laid down for a cottage machine.
('67', 207, 4, 26, 355990) It could not replace the existing machines.
('67', 207, 4, 27, 356034) Let us hope that neither Kirloskar Bros.
('67', 207, 4, 28, 356075) nor other inventors will give up the
('67', 208, 0, 1, 356112) VOL. 67: 25 APRIL, 1935 22 SEPTEMBER, 1935 209
('67', 208, 1, 2, 356159) attempt.
('67', 208, 1, 3, 356168) Though the prize has been withdrawn, I have no doubt that the Association will always be prepared to examine any promising effort and give the full reward if a really handy, easy working machine is forthcoming.
('67', 208, 1, 4, 356379) But till that happy time comes, if it ever does, improvements in the existing machines must not be despised.
('67', 208, 1, 5, 356488) Shri Shankerlal Banker has been concentrating on one essential improvement, speed of the spindle.
('67', 208, 1, 6, 356586) The revolutions of the spindle have been found to be as low as 35 to 1 of the turning wheel.
('67', 208, 1, 7, 356679) The result has been that the average output is not more than 150 yards per hour, if not even 100 yards.
('67', 208, 1, 8, 356783) The highest attained has been over 800 yards.
('67', 208, 1, 9, 356829) If the speed of the spindle can be improved, the average and therefore the wage can be easily doubled.
('67', 208, 1, 10, 356932) This can be effected by using thinner spindles, thinner mals (wheel strings) and reducing the circumference of the little pulley round the spindle.
('67', 208, 1, 11, 357080) These are but illustrations of the way in which improvements can be easily made.
('67', 208, 1, 12, 357161) But no improvement is possible unless khadi workers master the science of spinning.
('67', 208, 1, 13, 357245) They must know both the theory and the practice.
('67', 208, 1, 14, 357294) They must study the incredibly simple construction of the existing machines and the function of each part.
('67', 208, 1, 15, 357401) They must themselves be expert ginners, carders and spinners.
('67', 208, 1, 16, 357463) And they must take a lively interest in the welfare of the spinners.
('67', 208, 1, 17, 357532) This means overhauling the khadi service.
('67', 208, 1, 18, 357574) The sooner it is done, the better it will be for all concerned.
('67', 208, 1, 19, 357638) We must not be satisfied with the indifferent work of spinners, when we know that better is easily possible.
('67', 208, 2, 20, 357747) Harijan, 29 6 1935

('67', 209, 2, 9, 358744) GUR Testimony in favour of gur over sugar is daily accumulating.
('67', 209, 2, 10, 358809) Shri Shankerlal Banker who is touring in the Ooty regions sends the following analysis prepared for him by a chemist friend, showing the copper content in milligrams in one kilogram each of the samples submitted for analysis: Singanallur sugar 0.61 Aska sugar 1.93 Gur Anakapalli 7.48 Gur Singanallur 7.67 Molasses 5.70 Sugar Candy (cane) 4.98 Palmyra Candy 7.40 Thus it is a double waste of money to use sugar instead of gur.

('67', 215, 6, 27, 369886) Looking at the matter thus, when we do not know definitely what bit a person, we must assume that it was a serpent and apply remedies accordingly.
('67', 215, 6, 28, 370033) We may take him to a doctor, or, if we do not do that, we can bi nd the vein so as to stop the flow of blood, cut open the spot where we suspect the person to have been bitten and put permanganate in the wound, apply a mud pack and keep him conscious anyhow.

('67', 215, 6, 30, 370321) This can be done by thrusting one’s fingers into the throat or by making the person drink warm water mixed with salt.

('67', 226, 11, 29, 386812) 1. Normally we can say that ‘s’ is used for living things and ‘of’ for non living things; e.g., ‘a man’s leg’ but ‘a leg of a table’.
('67', 226, 11, 30, 386946) 2. ‘Had’ is used for an action which is already over before another; e.g., ‘He had eaten when I went to him’; but ‘He ate at 10 o'clock’.
('67', 226, 11, 31, 387084) ‘Had eaten’ is past perfect tense; ‘ate’ is simple past tense.
('67', 226, 12, 32, 387147) 1 Wife of Maruti Sharma 2 What follows is given on the margin of the addressee’s letter.
('67', 227, 0, 1, 387236) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 228
('67', 227, 1, 2, 387278) 3. ‘Have’ is used as an auxiliary verb as well as the main verb.
('67', 227, 1, 3, 387343) As the main verb it denotes possession or relationship, e.g., ‘He has a box.’—possession; ‘He has a son.’—relationship.
('67', 227, 1, 4, 387463) When an action is complete, forms of ‘have’ are used but when it is intended merely to suggest the past tense, forms of ‘be’ are used.
('67', 227, 1, 5, 387598) For examples, see the second note.

('67', 228, 5, 10, 389628) 362. HARIJAN CONFERENCE
('67', 228, 6, 11, 389652) On 16th June a Conference of workers in the Harijan cause was organized in Mysore under the auspices of the Mysore State Harijan Sevak Sangh.
('67', 228, 6, 12, 389794) Shrimati Rameshwari Nehru presided.
('67', 228, 6, 13, 389830) The following message was sent by the Dewan, Sir Mirza Ismail:
('67', 228, 7, 14, 389893) I am very glad to hear that the Mysore State Harijan Sevak Sangh is Organizing a conference of workers engaged in the noble cause of the uplift of the Depressed Classes, better known as Harijans, to review the result of the past year’s work and to settle future lines of action.
('67', 228, 7, 15, 390172) I need hardly say that I wish the conference all possible success.
('67', 228, 7, 16, 390239) The keen solicitude of His Highness the Maharaja and his Government for the well being and prosperity of the people extends, as is well known, to his subjects irrespective of their caste, creed or race.
('67', 228, 7, 17, 390442) The social and educational uplift of the Harijans, who form no small section of His Highness’s subjects, is therefore a matter which has received and will continue to receive the active sympathy and support of His Highness’s Government.
('67', 228, 7, 18, 390679) Various measures have been adopted by Government in recent years to ameliorate the conditions of this community.
('67', 228, 7, 19, 390792) In this task the co operation of the public and of such organizations as the Harijan Sevak Sangh of Bangalore is to be welcomed.
('67', 228, 7, 20, 390921) I wish this Sangh all success in its labours to create a higher tone in the social life of the community and to enable it to play its part in the public life of the State.
('67', 228, 8, 21, 391093) 1 Wife of Moolchand Agrawal 2 Vide “Letter to Moolchand Agrawal”, 23 6 1935

('67', 229, 13, 15, 392496) 363. MISSION OF KHADI
('67', 229, 14, 16, 392518) The mission of khadi is not merely to supply the townspeople with fashionable khadi that will vie with the mill manufactures and thus like other industries supply a few artisans with employment, but is to become a supplementary industry to agriculture.
('67', 229, 14, 17, 392771) This mission still remains unfulfilled.
('67', 229, 14, 18, 392811) In order that it may fulfil this mission, it has to be self sustained and its use must spread in the villages.
('67', 229, 14, 19, 392922) Just as the villagers cook their own roti or rice so must they make their own khadi for personal use.
('67', 229, 14, 20, 393024) The surplus, if any, they may sell.
('67', 229, 14, 21, 393060) This mission cannot be delivered unless the khadi service changes its complexion and the Spinners’ Association its policy.
('67', 229, 14, 22, 393183) Every member of the khadi service should know the processes through which cotton passes before it becomes khadi.
('67', 230, 0, 1, 393296) VOL. 67: 25 APRIL, 1935 22 SEPTEMBER, 1935 231
('67', 230, 1, 2, 393343) When emphasis is put on self sufficient khadi, commercial production will be restricted to the real wants of townspeople.
('67', 230, 1, 3, 393465) It will then pass into the hands of private businessmen instead of being centralized in the hands of the Association.
('67', 230, 1, 4, 393583) In trying to commercialize khadi, the Association has been hitherto dominated by the ruling prices.
('67', 230, 1, 5, 393683) Thus the spinnings wage has been the worst of all the wages for any form of labour.
('67', 230, 1, 6, 393767) They have also varied with provinces.
('67', 230, 1, 7, 393805) Therefore the prices of khadi too have varied with the provinces.
('67', 230, 1, 8, 393871) It is all very well for more profiteering bodies to countenance and even stimulate cut throat competition, but associations whose sole purpose is to serve the pauper millions cannot afford to join such competition.
('67', 230, 1, 9, 394086) There is no reason why a spinner in Bihar should get less than her sister in Gujarat.
('67', 230, 1, 10, 394172) No doubt prices vary in different provinces because the standard of living varies.
('67', 230, 1, 11, 394255) But the Association cannot afford to take things as they are.
('67', 230, 1, 12, 394317) It has to change them, if they are unjust.
('67', 230, 1, 13, 394360) There is no reason why the price of one hour’s labour in spinning should be less than one in weaving.
('67', 230, 1, 14, 394462) There is more skill involved in spinning than in simple weaving.
('67', 230, 1, 15, 394527) Simple weaving is a purely mechanical process.
('67', 230, 1, 16, 394574) Simplest spinning requires the cunning of the hand.
('67', 230, 1, 17, 394626) Yet the spinner gets one pie per hour against the weaver’s minimum of six; the carder too does better, almost as well as the weaver, There are historical reasons for this state of things.
('67', 230, 1, 18, 394814) But they are not just merely because they are historical.
('67', 230, 1, 19, 394872) Time has come for the Association to equalize if not also to stabilize the prices of all labour regulated by it.
('67', 230, 1, 20, 394985) This, in many cases, will mean inviting the weaver to lower his scale of wages where he gets more than one anna per hour.
('67', 230, 1, 21, 395107) Time may never come when all the weavers will voluntarily consent to the equalization process.
('67', 230, 1, 22, 395202) But if the doctrine of equality of wages for all productive labour is sound, the Association must strive to approach the ideal as near as may be.
('67', 230, 1, 23, 395348) Unless the whole jump is taken at once, the beginning must be made with raising the wages of spinners to a decent level for a decent hour’s work.
('67', 230, 1, 24, 395494) Vinoba is experimenting with spinning at the rate of nearly nine hours per day at the same time that he is taking his classes.
('67', 230, 1, 25, 395621) His output per hour should be regarded as the standard output per hour entitling the spinner to the standard wage.
('67', 230, 1, 26, 395736) I hope to publish shortly the results of Vinoba’s labours.
('67', 230, 1, 27, 395795) My scheme presupposes living contact with the spinners’ life.
('67', 230, 1, 28, 395857) A body that would give an unexpected rise in wages will watch the course of the nickel pieces that may be distributed.
('67', 230, 1, 29, 395976) It will be useless to
('67', 231, 0, 1, 395998) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 232
('67', 231, 1, 2, 396040) raise wages gratuitously if they are to be wasted in drink or extravagant marriage or other feasts.
('67', 231, 1, 3, 396140) The mission of khadi is almost like that of untouchability.
('67', 231, 1, 4, 396200) The so called higher classes have for ages utterly neglected the lower classes with the result that the latter do not know the art of living.
('67', 231, 1, 5, 396342) They think that they are mere ‘hewers of wood and drawers of water’.
('67', 231, 1, 6, 396411) The so called upper classes have not escaped the punishment of their misdeeds, for they too do not know the art of living and would perish today if they had no help from the ‘lower classes’.
('67', 231, 1, 7, 396602) The mission of khadi is to correct this double evil by inviting the ‘upper classes’ to [do] penance towards the ‘lower classes’.
('67', 231, 1, 8, 396731) Let the village industries workers, too, see to it that the villagers occupied in the various industries organized by them get the minimum wage that may be fixed by the Association.
('67', 231, 2, 9, 396913) Harijan, 6 7 1935
('67', 231, 3, 10, 396931) 364. ON DIARY WRITING1
('67', 231, 4, 11, 396954) Your diary must contain every particular about your health.
('67', 231, 4, 12, 397014) It must also contain the particulars of work done every hour, if the work could be so divided.
('67', 231, 4, 13, 397109) You might also make it a mirror of your own mind, recording your thoughts and dreams, good and bad, and you must also make it a record of your acts, good and bad.
('67', 231, 4, 14, 397272) This mirror of the self is helpful for a purification of one’s self.
('67', 231, 4, 15, 397341) One’s bowels must move regularly in order to keep one in a fit condition.
('67', 231, 4, 16, 397415) That is physical purification.
('67', 231, 4, 17, 397446) Just as this physical purification is necessary for the health of the body, even so spiritual purification is necessary for the health of the soul.
('67', 231, 4, 18, 397594) In fact the necessity for physical cleanliness is in inverse proportion to the necessity for spiritual cleanliness.
('67', 231, 4, 19, 397710) That is to say, spiritual cleanliness means automatic physical cleanliness.
('67', 231, 4, 20, 397786) Have we not heard that a yogi’s body emits a fragrant smell?
('67', 231, 4, 21, 397847) The ‘fragrant’ smell means here the absence of bad smell.
('67', 231, 5, 22, 397905) Harijan, 6 7 1935
('67', 231, 6, 23, 397923) 1 This is extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “Weekly Letter”.
('67', 231, 6, 24, 397981) Gandhiji, who was examining the diaries of Ashram members, gave this advice when one of them asked him "what particulars he should enter in the diary and what not”.

('67', 232, 1, 2, 398193) 365. NOTES
('67', 232, 2, 3, 398204) HARIJAN WELLS FUNDS
('67', 232, 3, 4, 398224) This week is published an estimate of wells required in the Province of Delhi for Harijans.
('67', 232, 3, 5, 398316) The reader will note what the wells mean to sweeper class Harijans.
('67', 232, 3, 6, 398384) They are debarred from using even the wells set apart for the other classes of Harijans.
('67', 232, 3, 7, 398473) Of course this is not peculiar to the Delhi Province.
('67', 232, 3, 8, 398527) The reiteration of the grievance emphasizes the importance of this special charity.
('67', 232, 3, 9, 398611) I hope that the heads of provincial Sanghs will make local collections which may be earmarked for use in their own provinces to the extent required.
('67', 232, 4, 10, 398760) TAMIL HOLY BOOK
('67', 232, 5, 11, 398776) Thiruvalluvar was a Tamil Saint.
('67', 232, 5, 12, 398809) Tradition says that he was a Harijan weaver.
('67', 232, 5, 13, 398854) He is said to have lived in the first century of the Christian era.
('67', 232, 5, 14, 398922) He gave us the famous Thirukural—holy maxims described by the Tamilians as the Tamil Veda and by M. Ariel as ‘one of the highest and purest expressions of human thought’.
('67', 232, 5, 15, 399093) The maxims number 1,330. These have been translated into many languages.
('67', 232, 5, 16, 399166) There are several English translations.
('67', 232, 5, 17, 399206) The late V.V.S. Iyer, who founded the Sharmadevi Ashram for the service of Harijans among others, produced the latest translation.
('67', 232, 5, 18, 399337) He died leaving Sharmadevi and his book to the nation.
('67', 232, 5, 19, 399392) Sharmadevi now belongs to the Harijan Sevak Sangh.
('67', 232, 5, 20, 399443) There are about 1,000 copies still left of the second edition of the translation.
('67', 232, 5, 21, 399525) The price of the book was Rs. 5 originally.
('67', 232, 5, 22, 399569) It has now been reduced to Rs. 2/8. The book has a substantial preface written by the translator.
('67', 232, 5, 23, 399667) The proceeds will be utilized for the Harijan service.
('67', 232, 5, 24, 399722) To whet the reader’s appetite I quote two maxims at random:
('67', 232, 6, 25, 399782) Take not away from any living thing the life that is sweet unto all, even if it be to save thine own.
('67', 232, 6, 26, 399884) Compare Goldsmith’s:
('67', 232, 7, 27, 399905) No flocks that range the valley free
('67', 232, 8, 28, 399942) To slaughter I condemn,
('67', 232, 9, 29, 399966) Taught by the Power that pities me
('67', 232, 10, 30, 400001) I learn to pity them.
('67', 232, 10, 31, 400023) The other selection is:
('67', 233, 0, 1, 400047) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 234
('67', 233, 1, 2, 400089) Death is like unto sleep and life is like the waking after that sleep.
('67', 233, 1, 3, 400160) Compare Wordsworth’s:
('67', 233, 2, 4, 400182) Death is but a sleep and a forgetting.
('67', 233, 2, 5, 400221) The book can be had on application to the Secretary, Tamil Nad Harijan Sevak Sangh, Teppakulam, Trichinopoly.

('67', 233, 12, 19, 401265) MANILAL AND SUSHILA,
('67', 233, 13, 20, 401286) I have your letters.
('67', 233, 13, 21, 401307) I understand the difficulty about eradicating malaria.
('67', 233, 13, 22, 401362) The task is certainly difficult if all around the place there are plantations of sugarcane.
('67', 233, 13, 23, 401454) But one thing about mosquitoes is that they do not fly beyond a certain distance.

('67', 233, 13, 26, 401734) Since the houses are on top of a hill, there is no possibility, either, of water accumulating around them.

('67', 234, 1, 6, 402027) I think with the help of these precautions you can keep off malaria.
('67', 234, 1, 7, 402096) I was surprised to learn that Lakshmi could send khadi made from the yarn spun by me.
('67', 234, 1, 8, 402182) May I take it then that I need not send anything now?
('67', 234, 1, 9, 402236) If you two cannot spare any time to teach Sita, then I should think that there is some big defect somewhere in your life.
('67', 234, 1, 10, 402358) If, willingly or unwillingly, you accept the responsibility of parenthood, then it also becomes your duty to train the children’s body, mind, etc., and you ought to spare some time for that, however busy your life may be.
('67', 234, 1, 11, 402580) Thanks to God’s kindness, children do get some education from parents whether they know it or not.
('67', 234, 1, 12, 402679) Whether you want it or not, your children are bound to imitate your manners and thoughts.
('67', 234, 1, 13, 402769) Even for that reason, parents are obliged to keep their thoughts and actions absolutely pure.
('67', 234, 1, 14, 402863) If your speech is pure, that of your children will be pure.
('67', 234, 1, 15, 402923) If you pray regularly, your children also will do the same.
('67', 234, 1, 16, 402983) Whatever things and in whatever manner you eat, your children will do the same.
('67', 234, 1, 17, 403063) What remains then is instruction in letters.
('67', 234, 1, 18, 403108) How much time can it consume?
('67', 234, 1, 19, 403138) With a little care, you can easily impart that to children while they are playing about.
('67', 234, 1, 20, 403227) But then, there should be a firm determination on your part to impart education to your children yourselves.
('67', 234, 1, 21, 403336) You should first acquire in some measure the knowledge that you want to impart to your children.
('67', 234, 1, 22, 403433) And the result will be that your children will get valuable knowlege in the normal course of their daily life, such as they can never get in schools.
('67', 234, 1, 23, 403583) If you spend your time in this way instead of in idle gossip, then you will increase your knowledge also and, what is more, your whole life will become more disciplined.
('67', 234, 1, 24, 403753) Forget Sorabji and his conduct.

('67', 234, 1, 26, 403860) You should learn to get entertainment even from such malicious stories.

('67', 244, 7, 16, 418994) 385. ADVICE TO KEISHO 1
('67', 244, 8, 17, 419018) [Before July 13, 1935]
('67', 244, 9, 18, 419041) It is indeed swadeshi cloth for you, but not the cloth that you should go in for in India.
('67', 244, 9, 19, 419132) “In Rome do as the Romans do” is not a meaningless saying.
('67', 244, 9, 20, 419191) We must try to observe the manners and customs of the country whose salt we eat.
('67', 244, 9, 21, 419272) When I was in Africa, I tried to use as many things as I could, made by African hands.
('67', 244, 9, 22, 419359) So unless you have any special objection, I would ask you to use khadi, Khadi is no doubt dearer, but then you may try to do with less cloth than you need.
('67', 244, 10, 23, 419515) Harijan, 13 7 1935
('67', 244, 11, 24, 419534) 1 This is extracted from “Weekly Letter” by Mahadev Desai who had explained that the advice was given when Keisho, a Japanese monk staying at the Ashram, purchased Japanese cloth.
('67', 244, 11, 25, 419714) Vide also “Speech at Ashram, Wardha”, Before 20 7 1935.
('67', 245, 0, 1, 419770) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 246
('67', 245, 1, 2, 419812) 386. IDEALS AND PRACTICE 1
('67', 245, 2, 3, 419839) There is an eternal struggle going on in us between the powers of light and powers of darkness, those of truth and of untruth, between God and the Devil.
('67', 245, 2, 4, 419993) We have to carry on the struggle as best as we may, but we have always to be conscious of our limitations.
('67', 245, 2, 5, 420100) Arjuna was on the point of forgetting his limitations and Lord Krishna prevented him from doing so.
('67', 245, 2, 6, 420200) Ahimsa is the law of life, but if I have not shed the fear of serpents what am I to do?
('67', 245, 2, 7, 420288) My mind has already killed the serpent, only the flesh is weak.
('67', 245, 2, 8, 420352) Your duty says: ‘Kill it.
('67', 245, 2, 9, 420378) Give up the vain attempt of refraining from killing it.’ The same is the case about brahmacharya and grihasthashrama.
('67', 245, 2, 10, 420496) Lifelong brahmacharya is a consummation devoutly to be wished, but he who cannot control his passions, whose mind and sense lust after the flesh, must enter grihasthashrama and a pure householder’s life.
('67', 245, 2, 11, 420700) For him the attempt at lifelong brahmacharya is vain.
('67', 245, 2, 12, 420754) He will not give up his faith in the ideal, but he will approach it by gradual practice in self restraint.
('67', 245, 3, 13, 420861) Harijan, 13 7 1935
('67', 245, 4, 14, 420880) 387. PUNJAB HARIJANS AND WELLS
('67', 245, 5, 15, 420911) I gladly publish the foregoing 2. I am asking Lala Mohanlal, the Secretary of the Punjab Harijan Sevak Sangh, to deal with the letter.
('67', 245, 5, 16, 421046) All the needs of Harijans in the matter of wells that come under the observation of the local Sangh will certainly be brought to the notice of the Punjab Sanitary Board.
('67', 245, 5, 17, 421216) The Harijan Sevak Sangh’s policy is not to duplicate the work done by the Government but wherever
('67', 245, 6, 18, 421314) 1 This is extracted from “Weekly Letter” by Mahadev Desai, who had explained: “In a recent article entitled “All Life Is One” , 22 6 1935Gandhiji answered all questions directed at some of the seeming contradictions between his belief and action.
('67', 245, 6, 19, 421561) In reply to similar questions addressed to him privately he sent a reply [presumably “Letter to Krishnachandra”, 3 7 1935 which makes his position and those of aspirants clearer, if possible.” 2 This was a letter dated June 28, 1935, from K. A. Rahman, Secretary, Sanitary Board, Punjab, not reproduced here.
('67', 245, 6, 20, 421870) The addressee, who had read an article about drinking water for Harijans in the Punjab in Civil and Military Gazette, dated June 27, 1935, had pointed out that “in recent years lakhs of rupees have been spent in providing good drinking water for villagers” and that there was no “distinction between Harijans and non Harijans”.
('67', 246, 0, 1, 422198) VOL. 67: 25 APRIL, 1935 22 SEPTEMBER, 1935 247
('67', 246, 1, 2, 422245) possible to supplement it.
('67', 246, 1, 3, 422272) The Sangh is building wells only where necessity is proved.
('67', 246, 1, 4, 422332) I may mention here, that though in law everywhere in British India public wells are open to Harijans in common with the others, in practice it has been found that Harijans are forcibly debarred from their use by caste Hindus and sometimes even others.
('67', 246, 1, 5, 422584) Harijans dare not use these wells without inviting severe corporal punishment from caste Hindus.
('67', 246, 1, 6, 422681) So far as my information goes, things are not very different in the Punjab.

('67', 246, 3, 8, 422776) 388. NEED FOR A STANDARD WAGE
('67', 246, 4, 9, 422806) The following questionnaire to its agents and others has been issued by the A.I.V.I.A. 1, the answers to reach the Central Office, Wardha, before 1st August next:
('67', 246, 5, 10, 422969) It has been proposed that we should insist on the village artisan getting an adequate return for his labour in connection with all articles produced or sold under the aegis of the A.I.V.I.A. For this purpose it will be necessary to fix a working wage standard.
('67', 246, 5, 11, 423230) Such standard should be the same for either sex for equal quantity of work.
('67', 246, 5, 12, 423306) It may be based on an eight hour day with a prescribed minimum output.
('67', 246, 5, 13, 423377) Such wage will enter into the cost and the price should be fixed in relation to this.
('67', 246, 5, 14, 423463) Ordinarily we may not be able to fix the prices in the competitive market, but we may do so for articles which do not enter into competition and for goods chosen for their special virtues which are appreciated by the consumers.
('67', 246, 6, 15, 423691) This questionnaire is sent out to inivite your opinion on the following points:
('67', 246, 7, 16, 423771) 1. Do you think it feasible to fix a minimum daily wage and ensure it to the workers by fixing prices?
('67', 246, 8, 17, 423874) 2. Should we fix our ultimate standard and work up towards it, or should we start with a low minimum and then raise it as we proceed?
('67', 246, 9, 18, 424008) 3. On what basis should it be arrived at?
('67', 246, 9, 19, 424050) Can you suggest a subsistence wage taking into consideration only food for the time being, as clothing should be made by personal effort?
('67', 246, 9, 20, 424188) Will half an anna per hour be too low?
('67', 246, 9, 21, 424227) Associations like the A.I.S.A. 2, and the A.I.V.I.A., and such philanthropic institutions may not follow the commercial maxim of buying in the cheapest market and selling in the dearest.
('67', 246, 9, 22, 424414) The A.I.S.A. has certainly tried to buy in the cheapest market.
('67', 246, 9, 23, 424478) Of this however in
('67', 246, 10, 24, 424497) 1 All India Village Industries’ Association 2 All India Spinners’ Association
('67', 247, 0, 1, 424575) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 248
('67', 247, 1, 2, 424617) another column.
('67', 247, 1, 3, 424633) 1 Wishing to give the A.I.V.I.A. the benefit of my experience of the evolution of khadi, I initiated a discussion about the wages received by the artisans working under its influence.
('67', 247, 1, 4, 424817) The result was the questionnaire.
('67', 247, 1, 5, 424851) It has already been discovered that the tendency among agents is to produce the required articles at as low prices as possible.
('67', 247, 1, 6, 424979) Where may the axe be laid if not upon the artisan’s earnings?
('67', 247, 1, 7, 425041) Unless, therefore, a minimum rate be fixed, there is every danger of the village artisan suffering, though it is for his sake that the A.I.V.I.A. has been brought into being.
('67', 247, 1, 8, 425216) We have exploited the poor patient villagers for too long.
('67', 247, 1, 9, 425275) Let not A.I.V.I.A. intensify the exploitation under the guise of philanthropy.
('67', 247, 1, 10, 425354) Its aim is not to produce village articles as cheap as possible; it is to provide the workless villagers with work at a living wage.
('67', 247, 1, 11, 425487) It has been argued that anything that may raise the prices of articles made in the villages will defeat the purpose for which the A.I.V.I.A. has been brought into being, for, it is said, nobody will buy the village articles if the prices are too high.
('67', 247, 1, 12, 425739) Why should the price of an article be considered too high, if it only provides a living wage for the manufacturer?
('67', 247, 1, 13, 425854) The buying public has to be instructed to know the abject condition of the people.
('67', 247, 1, 14, 425937) If we are to do justice to the toiling millions we must render to them their due; we must pay them a wage that will sustain them; we must not take advantage of their helplessness and pay wage that would hardly give them one full meal.
('67', 247, 1, 15, 426172) It is quite clear that the Association must refuse to compete with mill manufactures.
('67', 247, 1, 16, 426258) We may not take part in a game in which we know we must lose.
('67', 247, 1, 17, 426320) In terms of metal, the big combines, whether foreign or indigenous, will always be able to outbid the effort of the human hand.
('67', 247, 1, 18, 426448) What the Association seeks to do is to substitute false and non human economics by the true and human.
('67', 247, 1, 19, 426551) Not killing competition, but life giving co operation, is the law of the human being.
('67', 247, 1, 20, 426637) Ignoring the emotion is to forget that man has feelings.
('67', 247, 1, 21, 426694) Not the good of the few, not even the good of the many, but it is the good of all that we are made to promote, if we are ‘made in His own image’.
('67', 247, 1, 22, 426840) A philanthropic body like the A.I.V.I.A. cannot shirk a consideration of the problems involved in the questionnaire.
('67', 247, 2, 23, 426957) 1 Vide the following item.
('67', 248, 0, 1, 426984) VOL. 67: 25 APRIL, 1935 22 SEPTEMBER, 1935 249
('67', 248, 1, 2, 427031) true solution appears to be impracticable, it must be its endeavour to make it practicable.
('67', 248, 1, 3, 427123) Truth is ever practicable.
('67', 248, 1, 4, 427150) Thus considered the programme of the Association may fittingly be called adult education.
('67', 248, 1, 5, 427240) And if the Association is to secure for the artisan under its care a living wage, it must also pry into his domestic budget, and trace the course of every coin that is paid.
('67', 248, 1, 6, 427414) The most difficult question to determine would be the minimum of the living wage.
('67', 248, 1, 7, 427496) I have suggested eight annas for eight hours’ strenuous labour converted into a given quantity of the particular goods turned out by an artisan of good ability.
('67', 248, 1, 8, 427657) Eight annas is a mere token representing a certain quantity of necessaries of life.
('67', 248, 1, 9, 427741) If in a family of five there are two full workers they would earn at the proposed rate Rs. 30 per month allowing no holiday and no sickness gap.
('67', 248, 1, 10, 427886) Thirty rupees per month is no extravagant income for five mouths.
('67', 248, 1, 11, 427952) The method here proposed necessarily ignores the distinction of sex or age.
('67', 248, 1, 12, 428028) But every referee will draw upon his own personal experience and report accordingly.
('67', 248, 2, 13, 428113) Harijan, 13 7 1935
('67', 249, 0, 1, 428132) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 250
('67', 249, 1, 2, 428174) 389. ALL INDIA SPINNERS’ ASSOCIATION
('67', 249, 2, 3, 428211) What is true of the artisans working through the A.I.V.I.A., is equally true of those who are working through the A.I.S.A. Only the A.I.V.I.A. has to write on a clean slate.
('67', 249, 2, 4, 428385) The A.I.S.A. has to undo a tradition of fifteen years’ standing if it has to introduce a uniform minimum.
('67', 249, 2, 5, 428491) In helping the numerous spinners, it has also to deal with weavers, one tenth of the number of spinners, besides carders, ginners and others.
('67', 249, 2, 6, 428633) The wages of each class vary.
('67', 249, 2, 7, 428663) The difference between those earned by weavers and those earned by spinners would appear to be too great to admit of equality.
('67', 249, 2, 8, 428790) Whereas a spinner gets two pies per hour, a weaver gets one anna at the lowest and not unoften two.
('67', 249, 2, 9, 428890) To bring the spinners to 12 pies from two is a very big problem, especially when it is remembered that they number nearly one lac and half.
('67', 249, 2, 10, 429030) But the Association to be worthy of its trust has to develop enough courage to do the right thing.
('67', 249, 2, 11, 429129) Difficulties are there to be faced, not to cower us.
('67', 249, 2, 12, 429182) We must trust those who buy khadi for the love of Daridranarayana to pay a higher price for it than they have donehitherto.
('67', 249, 2, 13, 429306) If the trust is misplaced we must face a fall, however big, in sales.
('67', 249, 2, 14, 429376) Those who love khadi will buy it at any cost if they know that ninety five rupees out of one hundred go into the pockets of the Daridranarayana.
('67', 249, 2, 15, 429521) But after all the commercial use of khadi is its secondary and least use.
('67', 249, 2, 16, 429595) Not more than one crore persons, i.e., city people, would need to buy khadi.
('67', 249, 2, 17, 429672) These can be easily and comfortably clothed by twenty lacs of full time artisans.
('67', 249, 2, 18, 429754) The primary use of khadi is to find supplementary employment for the peasantry.
('67', 249, 2, 19, 429834) They have to be taught to spin their own yarn and even weave it themselves or have it woven.
('67', 249, 2, 20, 429927) They become their producers and buyers or rather users even as they are their own cooks and eaters.
('67', 249, 2, 21, 430027) This work we have hardly touched seriously as yet.
('67', 249, 2, 22, 430078) Shri Banker is quietly and slowly organizing the change.
('67', 249, 2, 23, 430135) Whilst that is being done, it is as well to set ourselves right by the spinners by offering them an adequate wage.
('67', 249, 2, 24, 430250) Is it to be eight annas per day or less?
('67', 249, 2, 25, 430291) Whatever the limit, what is to be the quantity of yarn expected in one hour to qualify the spinner to receive the given wage?
('67', 249, 2, 26, 430417) The same question has to be solved for ginners, carders, weavers and all those who are today working in the manufacture of khadi.
('67', 250, 0, 1, 430547) VOL. 67 : 25 APRIL, 1935 22 SEPTEMBER, 1935 251
('67', 250, 1, 2, 430595) Will those who are interested in khadi and are at all conversant with the science favour me with their views on the proposed change in the scale of wages?
('67', 250, 1, 3, 430750) If they favour the change, they will also say what minimum they will fix.
('67', 250, 2, 4, 430824) Harijan, 13 7 1935
('67', 250, 3, 5, 430843) 390. MEMBERS BEWARE
('67', 250, 4, 6, 430863) Kumarappa sends me the following for publication:
('67', 250, 5, 7, 430913) The ordinary members are reminded that they are required to send in their reports to the Secretary regularly every quarter under the Bye Law No.
('67', 250, 5, 8, 431058) 11 which reads as follows:
('67', 250, 6, 9, 431085) “Every ordinary member of the Association shall send to the Secretary a report of the work done by him every quarter so as to reach the Central Office not later than one month after the expiry of the quarter.
('67', 250, 6, 10, 431294) If no report is received for three consecutive quarters from any ordinary member, such member shall cease to be a member of the Association.”
('67', 250, 7, 11, 431436) Such ordinary members as have not sent in their reports hitherto are requested to submit an account of their work done up to 30th June, 1935 without further delay.
('67', 250, 7, 12, 431600) Kumarappa is a vigilant Secretary and so is the Chairman Sjt.
('67', 250, 7, 13, 431662) Jajooji.
('67', 250, 7, 14, 431671) They both believe that the rules of an institution should be enforced or repealed.
('67', 250, 7, 15, 431754) As there is no likelihood of the above reasonable rule being repealed, it is to be hoped that the members will carry out the rule both in the spirit and to the letter.

('67', 250, 9, 17, 431941) 391. LETTER TO CHHAGANLAL JOSHI
('67', 250, 10, 18, 431973) WARDHA, July 13, 1935
('67', 250, 11, 19, 431995) CHHAGANLAL (JOSHI),

('67', 254, 7, 9, 436165) 399. LETTER TO LILAVATI ASAR
('67', 254, 8, 10, 436194) July 15, 1935
('67', 254, 9, 11, 436208) 1. When ‘have’ means to get we can in many cases use ‘get’; e.g., ‘I must have it’ or ‘I must get it.’ 2. There is very little difference between ‘must’ and ‘have’.
('67', 254, 9, 12, 436373) 3. We can say either ‘If you had done this’ or ‘Had you done this’, i.e., if we use ‘had’ in the place of ‘if’ the meaning remains unchanged.
('67', 254, 9, 13, 436515) You will understand this better when you use it.
('67', 254, 9, 14, 436564) 4. The article ‘a’ must be used before a noun denoting countable things.
('67', 254, 9, 15, 436637) ‘A’ is taken to mean as one, therefore ‘the’ is used for the plural.
('67', 254, 9, 16, 436706) Where ‘that’ is used, we can use ‘the’; e.g., ‘The or that man whom you know is here.’ If there are more persons, then ‘The or those men whom you know are here.’ You must have calmed down now.
('67', 254, 9, 17, 436899) I had stomach ache one day for a short while as I had taken neem juice in excess.
('67', 254, 9, 18, 436981) It had subsided very soon.
('67', 254, 11, 19, 437008) From a phototstat of the Gujarati: G. N. 9254. Also C.W. 10101. Courtesy: Lilavati Asar

('67', 259, 10, 16, 443131) 411. SPEECH AT ASHRAM, WARDHA 2
('67', 259, 11, 17, 443163) [Before July 20, 1935]
('67', 259, 12, 18, 443186) I rarely say anything on the occasion of the departure of our visitors, but I do so today, first, because he is a visitor from Japan, but secondly and principally, because of the noble example he has set to us all by the way in which he lived in our midst.
('67', 259, 12, 19, 443443) 3 He has been with us for four or five months, but no one has worked with such devotion to his task and in such self abnegation.
('67', 259, 12, 20, 443572) He has worked away so mutely that we rarely noticed his presence.
('67', 259, 12, 21, 443638) His absorption in his prayers was a thing to charm anyone.
('67', 259, 12, 22, 443697) To repeat one mantra over and over again for
('67', 259, 13, 23, 443742) 1 The source has this in Hindi 2 The speech is extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “Weekly Letter”.
('67', 259, 13, 24, 443837) 3 Keisho, the Japanese monk, was leaving the Ashram to take the place of another disciple at Calcutta
('67', 260, 0, 1, 443939) VOL. 67 : 25 APRIL, 1935 22 SEPTEMBER, 1935 261
('67', 260, 1, 2, 443987) four hours in the day, not in a haphazard or perfunctory way, but with zest, devotion and concentration is an extraordinary thing.
('67', 260, 1, 3, 444118) Knowing no language of India and not even English, he must have found himself an utter stranger in our midst when he came.
('67', 260, 1, 4, 444241) But stranger he would be none.
('67', 260, 1, 5, 444272) He began the study of Hindi and learnt it soon enough to be able to speak with us somewhat.
('67', 260, 1, 6, 444364) But what I prize most is the radiance of his joy all the days he has been with us.
('67', 260, 1, 7, 444447) Fancy yourself in a strange land where you know no one, where everything, including the language, manners, customs, is strange, and ask yourself if you can live as this friend has lived in the midst of us.
('67', 260, 1, 8, 444653) I fancy I could not do so, nor can any one of you.
('67', 260, 1, 9, 444704) He derived his joy from the inner self, I should say.
('67', 260, 1, 10, 444758) For I am sure the sourroundings in the midst of which he found himself were no source of such joy for him.
('67', 260, 1, 11, 444865) None of us has ever seen him ruffled, ever sour or bitter.
('67', 260, 1, 12, 444924) His presence everywhere radiated joy which we prize.
('67', 260, 1, 13, 444977) That is why we will all miss him.
('67', 260, 1, 14, 445011) We bid him a very hearty farewell and hope that he will be back in our midst as soon as he can.

('67', 260, 3, 16, 445126) 412. REMARKS ON THIRD CLASS TRAVELLING 1
('67', 260, 4, 17, 445167) [Before July 20, 1935] You simply cannot have a clean seat in an upper class with its paddings and its cushions.
('67', 260, 4, 18, 445280) These absorb dirt and dust and perspiration as nothing else can, and because they afford a comfortable seat you sit on them as a matter of course.
('67', 260, 4, 19, 445427) These seats are or can be washed daily and you could clean them yourself as often as you like.
('67', 260, 5, 20, 445522) Harijan, 20 7 1935
('67', 260, 6, 21, 445541) 413. MEANING OF NON VIOLENCE
('67', 260, 7, 22, 445570) An English friend sends me the following letter:
('67', 260, 8, 23, 445619) Will you please see the attached copy of a report in the Madras Mail, and very kindly let me know whether it reproduces your words accurately?
('67', 260, 8, 24, 445762) And if it
('67', 260, 9, 25, 445772) 1 This is extracted from ‘Weekly Letter’ by Mahadev Desai, who had reported that Gandhiji made these remarks during his talk with a friend who had never travelled third class but wanted to do so against the protests of his friends and relations because “one could never improve the lot of third class passengers except by travelling with them”.
('67', 261, 0, 1, 446117) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 262
('67', 261, 1, 2, 446159) does, would you be so good as to explain how you reconcile the view here expressed with your more usual statements?
('67', 261, 1, 3, 446275) It seems to me the most dangerous doctrine yet recorded.
('67', 261, 1, 4, 446332) It invites anyone to take law into his own hands, and do murder or other violence, on the sole pretext that he is afraid, or that the only alternative to violence is a cowardice that is worse.
('67', 261, 1, 5, 446525) Hurrah for General Dyer, in that case!
('67', 261, 2, 6, 446564) The following is the cutting from the Madras Mail dated 7th instant:
('67', 261, 3, 7, 446633) Replying to a letter from a prominent Congressman, who had described the Hindu Muslim tension in a village in Andhradesha and the reported aggressive attitude exhibited by Muslims of the village, and who sought his advice in the circumstances, Mr. Gandhi in a private communication, says:
('67', 261, 4, 8, 446922) “DEAR FRIEND,
('67', 261, 5, 9, 446936) “The condition described by hyou is regrettable.
('67', 261, 5, 10, 446985) If the people fear their Muslim brethren they have every right to defend themselves by physical resistance.
('67', 261, 6, 11, 447093) “Not to do so will be cowardice which can in no way be described as non violence.
('67', 261, 6, 12, 447175) Cowardice is a species of violence worse than open and armed violence.”
('67', 261, 7, 13, 447247) Though I have no copy of my letter, what is claimed to be a reproduction of it substantially represents my views.
('67', 261, 7, 14, 447361) I cannot recall the name of my correspondent.
('67', 261, 7, 15, 447407) He is unknown to me.
('67', 261, 7, 16, 447428) If he is a prominent Congressman, I fancy, I would know him.
('67', 261, 7, 17, 447489) As stated by the Madras Mail correspondent, my letter was a private communication in reply to an enquiry.
('67', 261, 7, 18, 447595) My reply should, therefore, be read together with the circumstances which prompted it.
('67', 261, 7, 19, 447682) If I had preserved the letter, I would have reproduced the main contents.
('67', 261, 7, 20, 447756) It was a long letter.
('67', 261, 7, 21, 447778) The writer gave in detail the condition of the villagers.
('67', 261, 7, 22, 447836) The Hindu inhabitants were described as helpless and panic stricken.
('67', 261, 7, 23, 447905) They knew nothing of non violence.
('67', 261, 7, 24, 447940) The writer wanted to know what the villagers so situated were to do in the face of daily increasing violence on the part of the Muslims of the village supported by others coming from other villages.
('67', 261, 7, 25, 448139) The advice I gave has been the advice I have always given in such circumstances.
('67', 261, 7, 26, 448220) When I was travelling with the Ali Brothers in 1920, wanton acts of violence by the police near Bettiah were reported to have been done.
('67', 261, 7, 27, 448357) I dealt with the matter in a public speech delivered in Bettiah and wrote on it in the columns of Young

('67', 262, 1, 2, 448509) India of 15th December 1920. 1 The relevant paragraph from it is reproduced at the end of this article.
('67', 262, 1, 3, 448613) Non violence cannot be taught to a person who fears to die and has no power of resistance.
('67', 262, 1, 4, 448704) A helpless mouse is not non violent because he is always eaten by pussy.
('67', 262, 1, 5, 448777) He would gladly eat the murderess if he could, but he ever tries to flee from her.
('67', 262, 1, 6, 448860) We do not call him a coward, because he is made by nature to behave no better than he does.
('67', 262, 1, 7, 448952) But a man who, when faced by danger, behaves like a mouse, is rightly called a coward.
('67', 262, 1, 8, 449039) He harbours violence and hatred in his heart and would kill his enemy if he could without being hurt himself.
('67', 262, 1, 9, 449149) He is a stranger to non violence.
('67', 262, 1, 10, 449183) All sermonizing on it will be lost on him.
('67', 262, 1, 11, 449226) Bravery is foreign to his nature.
('67', 262, 1, 12, 449260) Before he can understand non violence he has to be taught to stand his ground and even suffer death in the attempt to defend himself against the aggressor who bids fair to overwhelm him.
('67', 262, 1, 13, 449447) To do otherwise would be to confirm his cowardice and take him further away from non violence.
('67', 262, 1, 14, 449542) Whilst I may not actually help anyone to retaliate, I must not let a coward seek shelter behind non violence so called.
('67', 262, 1, 15, 449662) Not knowing the stuff of which non violence is made many have honestly believed that running away from danger every time was a virtue compared to offering resistance especially when it is fraught with danger to one’s life.
('67', 262, 1, 16, 449885) As a teacher of non violence I must, so far as it is possible for me, guard against such an unmanly belief.
('67', 262, 1, 17, 449993) Non violence is the greatest force at the disposal of mankind.
('67', 262, 1, 18, 450056) It is mightier than the mightiest weapon of destruction devised by the ingenuity of man.
('67', 262, 1, 19, 450145) Destruction is not the law of the humans.
('67', 262, 1, 20, 450187) Man lives freely only by his readiness to die, if need be, at the hands of his brother, never by killing him.
('67', 262, 1, 21, 450297) Every murder or other injury, no matter for what cause, committed or inflicted on another is a crime against humanity.
('67', 262, 1, 22, 450416) But I see quite clearly that this truth about non violence cannot be delivered to the helpless.
('67', 262, 1, 23, 450512) They must be taught to defend themselves.
('67', 262, 1, 24, 450554) The sceptic then argues: “You cannot teach non violence to the weak and you dare not take it to the powerful.
('67', 262, 1, 25, 450664) Why not admit that it is a futile creed?” The answer is, non violence can be effectively taught only by living it.
('67', 262, 1, 26, 450779) When there is an unmistakable demonstration of its
('67', 262, 2, 27, 450830) 1 Vide “Satyagraha in South Africa” and “Satyagraha in South Africa”, Chapter XIX, sub title “Indian Opinion”

('67', 263, 1, 2, 450982) power and efficacy the weak will shed their weakness and the mighty will quickly realize the valuelessness of might and becoming meek acknowledge the sovereignty of non violence.
('67', 263, 1, 3, 451161) It is my humble effort to show that this is no unattainable goal even in mass action.
('67', 263, 1, 4, 451247) With critics like the English friend, I plead for patience.
('67', 263, 1, 5, 451307) The deduction that the friend draws from my letter to the Andhra correspondent is in my opinion wholly unwarranted.
('67', 263, 1, 6, 451423) Even without the letter to which mine was a reply, it is clear that there would be no occasion to defend oneself when police aid is at hand.
('67', 263, 1, 7, 451564) The police won’t, if they are faithful to their trust, allow open aggression or violence.
('67', 263, 1, 8, 451654) Resistance in self defence is allowed in law.
('67', 263, 1, 9, 451700) I was dealing with circumstances which were assumed to be beyond the reach of law or police.
('67', 263, 1, 10, 451793) They punish more often than they prevent, much less detect, crime.
('67', 263, 1, 11, 451860) Self defence, then, is the only honourable course where there is unreadiness for self immolation.
('67', 263, 2, 12, 451958) And in future, if and when such incidents happen, they must be prepared to defend themselves.
('67', 263, 2, 13, 452052) It is better if they can manfully stand persecution and allow themselves to be robbed, instead of hitting in defence of their persons or property.
('67', 263, 2, 14, 452199) That would indeed be their crowning triumph.
('67', 263, 2, 15, 452244) But such forbearance can only be exercised out of strength and not out of weakness.
('67', 263, 2, 16, 452328) Till that power is acquired, they must be prepared to resist the wrongdoer by force.
('67', 263, 2, 17, 452413) Whena policeman comes not to arrest but to molest, he travels beyond his authority.
('67', 263, 2, 18, 452497) The citizen has then the inalienable right of treating him as a robber and dealing with him as such.
('67', 263, 2, 19, 452598) He will therefore use sufficient force to prevent him from robbing.
('67', 263, 2, 20, 452666) He will most decidedly use force in order to defend the honour of his women.
('67', 263, 2, 21, 452743) The doctrine of non violence is not for the weak and the cowardly; it is meant for the brave and the strong.
('67', 263, 2, 22, 452852) The bravest man allows himself to be killed without killing.
('67', 263, 2, 23, 452913) And he desists from killing or injuring, because he knows that it is wrong to injure.

('67', 263, 2, 25, 453034) They flee from the police.

('67', 263, 2, 27, 453138) They gain no merit of non violence but on the contrary incur the reproach of cowardice and unmanliness; they stand condemned before Government and man.
