('67', 271, 1, 2, 462425) 429. DISCUSSION WITH MARY CHESLEY AND MIRABEHN 1
('67', 271, 2, 3, 462474) [Before July 22, 1935] 2
('67', 271, 3, 4, 462499) GANDHIJI: But why do you object to it?
('67', 271, 4, 5, 462538) MARY CHESLEY: Because it is English.
('67', 271, 5, 6, 462575) G. But why should I not adopt whatever is best in English dress?
('67', 271, 5, 7, 462640) I would not mind doing so, though Englishmen may look with contempt on Indian dress and disdain to adopt any part of it.
('67', 271, 6, 8, 462761) M.C. It is so inartistic.
('67', 271, 6, 9, 462787) The English shorts go ill with the flowing Indian
('67', 271, 7, 10, 462837) shirts.
('67', 271, 8, 11, 462845) G. Then I suppose you would be horrified if I asked people to wear the sola hat.
('67', 271, 9, 12, 462926) Here Mirabehn took up the battle on behalf of the friend and said it would
('67', 271, 10, 13, 463001) certainly shock her.
('67', 271, 10, 14, 463022) The sola hat was most expensive and extremely unportable.
('67', 271, 11, 15, 463080) G. That only shows that the hat you wore when you were in England was a misfit.
('67', 271, 12, 16, 463160) MIRABEHN: No.
('67', 271, 12, 17, 463174) I had the best hats available in those days, but I never liked
('67', 271, 13, 18, 463237) They cramp one’s head and give one an ache.
('67', 271, 14, 19, 463281) G. Then perhaps your head was so ill shaped.
('67', 271, 14, 20, 463326) What I do seriously feel is that the sola hat is a good protection from the sun.
('67', 271, 15, 21, 463407) M. I would any day wear an Indian puggree in preference to the hat.
('67', 271, 15, 22, 463475) It does keep
('67', 271, 16, 23, 463488) off the sun as well.
('67', 271, 17, 24, 463509) G. It does not.
('67', 271, 18, 25, 463525) M. Well, well.
('67', 271, 18, 26, 463540) But these shorts are bad.
('67', 271, 18, 27, 463566) Between the loin cloth that you wear
('67', 271, 19, 28, 463603) and the shorts these people wear there is all the difference between heaven and hell.
('67', 271, 20, 29, 463689) Then you will explain why it is so shocking.

('67', 279, 8, 21, 476242) 444. HOW TO BEGIN
('67', 279, 9, 22, 476260) Whether it is to be a standard rate or a minimm for khadi artisans, a change seems to be a certainty.
('67', 279, 9, 23, 476362) With the exception of one dissentient of the many opinions so far received, none has opposed my proposal for fixing an increased rate.
('67', 279, 9, 24, 476497) No one has yet been found to endorse the eight anna proposal.
('67', 279, 9, 25, 476559) 3 Some of the writers regard the
('67', 279, 10, 26, 476592) 1 The source is illegible here.
('67', 279, 10, 27, 476624) 2 This is extracted from Mahadev Desai's “Weekly Letter”.
('67', 279, 10, 28, 476682) Gandhiji, who had substituted oil cake for dal in the Ashram diet, “asked everyone to express in writing what he or she felt about it”.
('67', 279, 10, 29, 476818) Three members disapproved of the move and dal was immediately restored.
('67', 279, 10, 30, 476890) But the “little slip of paper” signed by them “served Gandhiji as a peg on which to hang a sermon”.
('67', 279, 10, 31, 476990) 3 Vide “Need for a Standard wage”, 13 7 1935
('67', 280, 0, 1, 477035) VOL. 67 : 25 APRIL, 1935 22 SEPTEMBER, 1935 281
('67', 280, 1, 2, 477083) eight anna proposal as fatal to khadi.
('67', 280, 1, 3, 477122) The price of khadi will, in that case, have to be so far advanced, they say, that there will be very few buyers.
('67', 280, 1, 4, 477235) Be that as it may, in any change worthy of the name some conditions will have to be fulfilled.
('67', 280, 1, 5, 477330) It will therefore be wise to take time by the forelock and enforce the following immediatly wherever it is at all possible:
('67', 280, 2, 6, 477454) 1. The workers should master all the processes from cotton picking to weaving so as to be able to teach others.
('67', 280, 2, 7, 477566) 2. Organizers should make a register of all the carders, spinners, weavers, etc., within their circle or jurisidiction.
('67', 280, 2, 8, 477686) 3. They should know the variety of cotton used by their spinners, and see that they do not attempt to spin a higher count than it is capable of.
('67', 280, 2, 9, 477831) 4. Spinners and the other artisans should be warned that unless they use khadi in their own households, they may not get any work.
('67', 280, 2, 10, 477962) 5. The artisans so warned should have facilities put in their way, so as to enable them always to get their khadi for their labour.
('67', 280, 2, 11, 478094) 6. Every hank of yarn received should be examined for its strength and evenness, all uneven and weak yarn being rejected, even as underbaked bread would be.
('67', 280, 2, 12, 478251) 7. As a rule, each spinner’s yarn should be stocked separately and woven when there is enough for a piece.
('67', 280, 2, 13, 478358) This will ensure durability of khadi and an all round improvement in the texture and appearance.
('67', 280, 2, 14, 478455) 8. All pieces thus prepared should have labels attached to them giving the names of ginners, carders, spinners and weavers where they are all different.
('67', 280, 2, 15, 478608) 9. Where artisans are members of families, the latter should be induced and encouraged to have all the processes in their own homes.
('67', 280, 2, 16, 478741) This will be easy when the wages are equalized or nearly so.
('67', 280, 2, 17, 478802) 10. The lives and budgets of families coming under the influence of the workers should be carefully studied and those who spend their earnings judiciously should be helped.
('67', 280, 2, 18, 478975) 11. If ever it becomes necessary to restrict the number of artisans served by the Association, by reason of shortage of custom, those who have other means of livelihood should be first eliminated.
('67', 280, 2, 19, 479172) At present, I understand, in several provinces, it is not only the
('67', 281, 0, 1, 479239) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 282
('67', 281, 1, 2, 479281) neediest who spin but also the thrifty women who want a little money for themselves to buy a few trifles, rather than to have better food or to pay debts.
('67', 281, 1, 3, 479436) 12. In every case the workers will have to closely examine the carding bows and the wheels, especially the latter with reference to the spindles and their revolutions.
('67', 281, 1, 4, 479604) For the proposed increase will never be a rise pure and simple.
('67', 281, 1, 5, 479668) It will be partly earned by greater and better output in the same time and partly there will be pure increase.
('67', 281, 1, 6, 479779) No spinner who refuses to make any improvement in her or his manner of work is likely to get any increase unless the demand for khadi increases.
('67', 281, 1, 7, 479924) 13. It follows from the last paragraph that new machines or parts will have to be supplied by the associations on easy terms in the first instance.
('67', 281, 1, 8, 480072) In many cases alterations in the mal (string) and the spindle will automatically increase and improve the quality of the output.
('67', 281, 1, 9, 480201) All these conditions can be fulfilled only if the workers realize that they have a grand mission and that they are but humble units in a vast family of artisans and labourers who are semi starved or underfed.
('67', 281, 1, 10, 480410) I have not touched the question of cotton growing.
('67', 281, 1, 11, 480461) So far I have dealt with the khadi that is manufactured for the market.
('67', 281, 1, 12, 480533) Some different rules will govern self sufficient khadi.
('67', 281, 1, 13, 480589) It will never succeed without cotton being grown by spinners themselves or practically in every village.
('67', 281, 1, 14, 480694) It means decentralization of cotton cultivations so far at least as self sufficient khadi is concerned.
('67', 281, 1, 15, 480798) For this we shall need a census of the villages served.
('67', 281, 1, 16, 480854) For not every spinner or weaver has a plot (ever so tiny) of land, where he or she can grow cotton.
('67', 281, 1, 17, 480954) Self sufficient khadi is a much bigger proposition, for which alone can the existence of the A. I.S.A. be justified.
('67', 281, 1, 18, 481071) It is a field as yet untouched by it on any scale worth mentioning.
('67', 281, 2, 19, 481139) Harijan, 27 7 1935
('67', 281, 3, 20, 481158) 445. NOTES
('67', 281, 4, 21, 481169) NEED FOR CORRECTNESS Professor Malkani has been kindly sending me copies of the notices he has been issuing to the Provincial Sanghs on the necessity of compliance with the rules framed by the Central Board for the proper management of the wonderful organizations that have been
('67', 282, 0, 1, 481448) VOL. 67 : 25 APRIL, 1935 22 SEPTEMBER, 1935 283
('67', 282, 1, 2, 481496) brought into being in the provinces.
('67', 282, 1, 3, 481533) They cannot function well or in co ordination with one another and with the Central Board unless they strictly carry out all the rules and instructions issued by the Central Board from time to time.
('67', 282, 1, 4, 481732) Failure to comply with requirements regarding budgets or preparation of accounts must result in bad finance—a very serious matter for a Board having numerous branches which have control of large funds.
('67', 282, 1, 5, 481934) Failure to send in regular reports of work done must leave the Centre in the dark and impair the efficiency of work.
('67', 282, 1, 6, 482051) Failure to attend meetings must bring work of the Sangh to a standstill resulting in stagnation and finally disruption.
('67', 282, 1, 7, 482171) If attention to rules and instructions is held to be essential in business organizations, how much more must it be so in the working of a voluntary, philanthropic or penitential institution?It is to be hoped, therefore, that all the component parts of the Sangh will respond to the requirements from the Centre and thus by correct behaviour hasten the disappearance of the canker of untouchability from our midst.
('67', 282, 2, 8, 482585) A PLEA FOR PURITY A correspondent, himself an editor, sends me cuttings from one single newspaper owned or managed by a public worker of approved merit.
('67', 282, 2, 9, 482738) They were with one exception about medicine.
('67', 282, 2, 10, 482783) In my opinion they were highly objectionable.
('67', 282, 2, 11, 482829) They contained indecent suggestions calculated to excite and promote animal passion in man.
('67', 282, 2, 12, 482921) These advertisements were taken from recent issues of the newspaper concerned.
('67', 282, 2, 13, 483000) They were all claimed to possess the virtue of rejuvenating their users.
('67', 282, 2, 14, 483073) The description was revolting.
('67', 282, 2, 15, 483104) Some of them were manifest lies.
('67', 282, 2, 16, 483137) My correspondent tells me that the newspaper from which he had taken the cuttings was by no means the sole offender.
('67', 282, 2, 17, 483254) He could send me similar cuttings from others known to be popular and respectable.
('67', 282, 2, 18, 483337) The proprietors of such newspapers probably do not know that their sheets contain indecent advertisements.
('67', 282, 2, 19, 483444) Perhaps they have not even read them.
('67', 282, 2, 20, 483482) Let me hope that the editors and managers of newspapers will study their advertisements and remove those that are without doubt objectionable.
('67', 282, 2, 21, 483625) I trust, too, that journalists’ associations in the provinces will take up the matter and persuade proprietors to exercise restraint in the matter of admitting advertisements.
('67', 282, 2, 22, 483801) It is not too much to expect them to remove all such as are likely to corrupt public morals or offend sense of decency.
('67', 282, 2, 23, 483921) Harijan, 27 7 1935

('67', 284, 6, 11, 486395) 449. ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS 1
('67', 284, 7, 12, 486423) July 27, 1935
('67', 284, 8, 13, 486437) Q. Apart from reforms in sanitation and food habits, as for example in respect of flour, rice, gur, oil, etc., what other reforms are necessary for an ideal village?
('67', 284, 9, 14, 486603) A. Every village has to be studied individually.
('67', 284, 10, 15, 486652) Q. Should I obey parents and other relatives and keep away from participating in activities of universal benefit when I am certain that there injunction is prompted only by misguided love?
('67', 284, 11, 16, 486841) A. In that case disobedience might be dharma for you.
('67', 284, 12, 17, 486895) Q. Would it be right to obey a command of one’s superiors, viz., parents, teachers and official superiors, if it goes against any one of the vows of truth, non violence and so on?
('67', 284, 14, 18, 487075) Q. The following is one of the ten rules laid down by the Arya Samaj: “An individual has some freedom in the observance of all rules of particular benefit but none in observing rules of universal benefit.”
('67', 284, 15, 19, 487281) 1 The questions were asked by Avadhesh Dutt Avasthi on July 25, 1935.
('67', 285, 0, 1, 487351) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 286
('67', 285, 1, 2, 487393) A. It is not quite clear to me.
('67', 285, 1, 3, 487425) If so, would it not mean that a vicious custom prevalent in society but calling for eradication should be conformed to until the whole of society or the majority is in favour of its eradication?
('67', 285, 1, 4, 487620) In other words, one should not individually offer active opposition to it though one may continue other efforts.
('67', 285, 1, 5, 487733) I want to learn the duty of an average individual.
('67', 285, 1, 6, 487784) A great man of course attracts the popular opinion to follow him in whichever cause he adopts.
('67', 285, 1, 7, 487879) The individual should firmly adhere to his duty.
('67', 285, 2, 8, 487928) Q. You have stated that only those jail rules really offending one’s self respect need be disregarded.
('67', 285, 2, 9, 488031) Therefore it may be explained which of these following seven conditions are really derogatory to one’s self respect as these were usually the causes of conflict in all the jails:
('67', 285, 3, 10, 488210) To be counted by pairs, to perform tasks in spite of abuse and beatings, to be served by the barber with handcuffs on, to be subjected to restraints in saying prayers, to remain standing during the parade holding one’s ticket, to parade, to be searched morning and evening in an objectionable manner.
('67', 285, 4, 11, 488511) A. We should disregard only that which we feel violates our dharma.
('67', 285, 5, 12, 488579) Q. You have said that dharma enjoins a husband to provide for the wife and also to co operate with her so long as she follows his way of life.
('67', 285, 5, 13, 488722) Therefore what is the husband’s duty when the wife holds views opposed to his and does not adopt his ways, and what is the wife’s duty when the situation is reversed?
('67', 285, 6, 14, 488889) A. Dharma indicates that they live separately and the husband provides for the wife.
('67', 285, 7, 15, 488974) Q. If anyone, especially a poor man or a Harijan, due to some reason, is being abused or beaten in my presence by a State official or a policeman or any arrogant person, especially a savarna as happens often enough, what would be my duty?
('67', 285, 8, 16, 489213) A. You should render non violent help to the victim by pleading with the oppressor.
('67', 285, 9, 17, 489297) Q. Would it not be right to kill a mad elephant or a dog that has caused death to many and that is altogether uncontrollable?
('67', 285, 9, 18, 489423) And if this is right, would it be proper for the State to give the same or similar treatment to men turned mad by selfishness, lust and anger?
('67', 285, 10, 19, 489566) A. It is possible to control even a mad elephant if one bears him true love and, as for insane people, the State has already some arrangement.
('67', 285, 11, 20, 489709) Q. Is man by nature slightly superior to woman?
('67', 286, 0, 1, 489757) VOL. 67 : 25 APRIL, 1935 22 SEPTEMBER, 1935 287
('67', 286, 2, 2, 489805) Q. Why is that women usually suffer no embarrassment in wearing male apparel while men feel it a matter of humiliation to dress like women?
('67', 286, 2, 3, 489945) I think women regard masculinity to be somewhat superior.
('67', 286, 3, 4, 490003) A. It is because man attributes weakness to woman.
('67', 286, 4, 5, 490054) Q. What is the reason behind your avoidance of food cooked on fire?
('67', 286, 5, 6, 490122) A. Non violence, saving on expense and time, health and so on.
('67', 286, 6, 7, 490185) Q. Owing to some reasons I have formed the opinion that one should keep totally aloof from political and social movements while one is a student.
('67', 286, 6, 8, 490331) Am I correct in this opinion?
('67', 286, 7, 9, 490361) A. That is for you to decide.
('67', 286, 7, 10, 490391) BAPU From a photostat of the Hindi: G. N. 3221
('67', 286, 8, 11, 490438) 450. VIOLENCE v.
('67', 286, 8, 12, 490455) NON VIOLENCE
('67', 286, 9, 13, 490468) A reader of Harijanbandhu writes to say: 1
('67', 286, 10, 14, 490511) The confrontation between violence and non violence has lasted from time immemorial and will last till eternity.
('67', 286, 10, 15, 490624) Everyone will interpret these words in his own way and act in accordance with his wishes and his capacity.
('67', 286, 10, 16, 490731) Hence, it seems that any further discussion on this much debated topic will not take us much further.
('67', 286, 10, 17, 490833) However, the way I look at non violence in our enfeebled circumstances appears to be a novel viewpoint and this sometimes has even hurt the votaries of non violence.
('67', 286, 10, 18, 490999) Non Violence is the characteristic of a brave man.
('67', 286, 10, 19, 491050) Fear and non violence are deadly enemies.
('67', 286, 10, 20, 491092) We are unable to see non violence inits true form as we are surrounded by fear and have become accustomed to look at it from a distorted angle.
('67', 286, 10, 21, 491236) This introduction seems necessary for a consideration of the above letter.
('67', 286, 10, 22, 491311) We have no evidence before us to support the belief that the death rate is higher where the number of snakes killed is great.
('67', 286, 10, 23, 491437) On the contrary snakes are seldom found in places where people have unanimously decided to make it their dharma to kill every snake.
('67', 286, 10, 24, 491570) But this evidence cannot establish the dharma of violence.
('67', 286, 10, 25, 491629) Non violence
('67', 286, 11, 26, 491642) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('67', 286, 11, 27, 491679) The correspondent had stated that he was unable to overcome the fear of snakes, though he knew that “ahimsa was the law of life”.
('67', 287, 0, 1, 491809) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 288
('67', 287, 1, 2, 491851) can be proved only by dying.
('67', 287, 1, 3, 491880) The practice of killing has always been there.
('67', 287, 1, 4, 491927) This state of affairs shocked a certain brave man who proclaimed: “This is not dharma.” Non violence alone is the true religion for all times.
('67', 287, 2, 5, 492070) If I have suggested that snakes should be killed in certain circumstances, it is to help non violence, not to destroy it.
('67', 287, 2, 6, 492192) Non violence is an attitude of mind.
('67', 287, 2, 7, 492229) My non violence is not put to shame if I kill a snake through fear although my efforts are directed towards befriending it.
('67', 287, 2, 8, 492353) If I make the fullest effort, I can even reach this ideal.
('67', 287, 3, 9, 492412) It is not because we are merciful that we refrain from killing snakes and such other creatures; we are persuaded to do so because we traditionally believe that there is non violence in doing so and hence do not kill snakes.
('67', 287, 3, 10, 492636) We cannot claim that human beings are kind towards those whom they fear.
('67', 287, 3, 11, 492709) He who is strong is merciful towards the weak.
('67', 287, 3, 12, 492756) Where is the mercy in catching hold of a snake and throwing it away because we are afraid of it?
('67', 287, 3, 13, 492853) While doing so, generally we do not even have the notion that some day we shall make friends with the snake.
('67', 287, 3, 14, 492962) Non violence is the dharma of awakening.
('67', 287, 3, 15, 493003) Its votary has to make conscious use of it at every moment as we are surrounded by violence on all sides.
('67', 287, 3, 16, 493109) Every one of us has according to his capacity to make his own way out of this dangerous predicament.
('67', 287, 4, 17, 493210) Let us examine that act of refraining from killing a serpent.
('67', 287, 4, 18, 493272) When a snake comes to attack us, we shall certainly kill it because it does not attack us.
('67', 287, 4, 19, 493363) While going its own way, it strays from its path and comes into our homes.
('67', 287, 4, 20, 493438) We then catch hold of it and throw it far away.
('67', 287, 4, 21, 493486) While taking care that it does not attack us, we subject it to as much pain as is necessary.
('67', 287, 4, 22, 493579) Mercy plays no part in this, but what is at work is the fear of punishment in our next birth for our failure to practise the dharma of non violence.
('67', 287, 4, 23, 493728) We have given no proof of our bravery in not killing the snake.
('67', 287, 4, 24, 493792) Killing it would not have been a courageous act either.
('67', 287, 4, 25, 493848) The motive behind both [the killing and non killing] is fear.
('67', 287, 4, 26, 493910) If mercy in its pure state were present in me, I would catch hold of the serpent and befriend it and rid others of the fear of snakes.
('67', 287, 4, 27, 494045) We do hear stories of sadhus who do this.
('67', 287, 4, 28, 494087) It is possible that these reports are not true or are mere exaggerations.
('67', 287, 4, 29, 494161) However, if non violence is real, such friendship between snakes and human beings is not an impossibility.
('67', 288, 0, 1, 494268) VOL. 67 : 25 APRIL, 1935 22 SEPTEMBER, 1935 289
('67', 288, 1, 2, 494316) If this much is clear to the reader, he will realize that there is no room for doubt regarding the sentence 1 in question.
('67', 288, 1, 3, 494439) This does not imply that so long as the fear of snakes presists, these should be killed at sight.
('67', 288, 1, 4, 494537) However, wherever their danger continues, it is not necessary to have any hesitation in killing them, as underlying that fear there is a deep rooted desire for their death.
('67', 288, 1, 5, 494710) One feels free from fear when one kills them.
('67', 288, 1, 6, 494756) I cannot imagine a more pitiable condition for the non violent person.
('67', 288, 1, 7, 494827) Anyone who attempts to befriend snakes and such other creatures will not rest satisfied by solving such problems in the traditional manner, but will rather make an effort to rid himself of the fear of such ferocious animals without indulging in violence of any kind.
('67', 288, 1, 8, 495094) The example of a beautiful woman is not applicable here at all.
('67', 288, 1, 9, 495158) If anyone desires her and tries to seduce her, many persons will be ready to beat him up.
('67', 288, 1, 10, 495248) Human beings suppress such desires.
('67', 288, 1, 11, 495284) Or by consciously nurturing them they seek the means of their own destruction.
('67', 288, 1, 12, 495363) The comparison with snakes could be made in the following manner.
('67', 288, 1, 13, 495429) Rather than be infatuated by a woman and yield to this infatuation, I should destroy the serpent within me or, in other words, drown myself by jumping into a well.
('67', 288, 1, 14, 495593) This should be regarded as pure non violence and be considered an act of bravery.
('67', 288, 1, 15, 495675) Snakes and such other creatures are symbols for us.
('67', 288, 1, 16, 495727) The passions within us are the reflection of evil.
('67', 288, 1, 17, 495778) If we make a Herculean effort to rid ourselves of the fear of our fellow creatures such as snakes.
('67', 288, 1, 18, 495877) However, so long as we cannot do so, we should do whatever we think best while entertaining the desire for friendship.
('67', 288, 2, 19, 495996) [From Gujarati]
('67', 288, 3, 20, 496012) Harijanbandhu, 28 7 1935
('67', 288, 4, 21, 496037) 1 The correspondent had quoted the following from Mahadev Desai’s Gujarati translation of “Ideals and Practice” (p.
('67', 288, 4, 22, 496153) 248) which appeared in Harijanbandhu, 14 7 1935: “Ahimsa is the law of life, but if I have not shed the fear of serpents, what am I to do?

('67', 291, 6, 11, 499359) I liked the charkha made by you and therefore tried hard and have mastered it.
('67', 291, 6, 12, 499438) I even made some improvements in it which occurred to me.

('67', 291, 6, 14, 499530) How can I find two persons?

('67', 299, 0, 1, 512090) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 300
('67', 299, 2, 2, 512132) A GOOD SERVANT GONE
('67', 299, 3, 3, 512152) Nibaranbabu who dies the other day in Purulia was one of the gentlest of souls.
('67', 299, 3, 4, 512232) He was a true servant of Harijans and equally true friend of all the poor.
('67', 299, 3, 5, 512307) He had realized to the full the matchless beauty of non violence which had become a living creed with him.
('67', 299, 3, 6, 512414) His life was an inspiration to many of his friends and followers who looked to him for guidance and comfort in their darkest hours.
('67', 299, 3, 7, 512546) May the memory of it ever sustain them and move them from good to better.
('67', 299, 4, 8, 512620) WEALTH WELL USED
('67', 299, 5, 9, 512637) Shri Jwala Prasad Mandelia, a great servant of Harijans, is no more.
('67', 299, 5, 10, 512706) He was the treasurer of the Central Harijan Sevak Sangh.
('67', 299, 5, 11, 512763) And what a treasurer he was to the cause which he loved with a rare passion!
('67', 299, 5, 12, 512840) He could not be called a wealthy man as the expression is understood nowadays.
('67', 299, 5, 13, 512919) But he was secretary of the Birla Mills and earned well.
('67', 299, 5, 14, 512976) He has willed away practically all he possessed.
('67', 299, 5, 15, 513025) During his lifetime too he spent liberally on charities.
('67', 299, 5, 16, 513082) He was a born reformer.
('67', 299, 5, 17, 513106) The cause of the widow was as dear to him as that of Harijans, and by his will he provided for both these, the bequest to be spent in his home, Pilani.
('67', 299, 6, 18, 513258) Harijan, 3 8 1935
('67', 300, 0, 1, 513276) VOL. 67 : 25 APRIL, 1935 22 SEPTEMBER, 1935 301
('67', 300, 1, 2, 513324) 471. SELF SUFFICIENT KHADI
('67', 300, 2, 3, 513351) The conditions promoting the success of and governing self sufficient khadi are different from those governing khadi produced for the town dweller who would not or cannot toil to make it at any stage of its manufacture.
('67', 300, 2, 4, 513571) In khadi, made for sale, every process from sowing and picking of cotton to weaving the yarn can be distributed with ease, especially when the cost of labour is equalized or nearly so.
('67', 300, 2, 5, 513756) Specialization under supervision and on a co operative basis must yield better returns.
('67', 300, 2, 6, 513844) But where an article is produced for personal use, the greater the concentration of all the processes in the same family or even the same hands, the greater the economy of time and money.
('67', 300, 2, 7, 514032) A person, who has a little land which he can call his own even for a fair period and works on it daily, can have his khadi for mere labour put in by him or his during their odd moments.
('67', 300, 2, 8, 514218) All he needs is instruction or education to show how each one can make his own khadi practically for nothing.
('67', 300, 2, 9, 514328) When labour has to be paid for and that at an equal rate per period, spinning would take in the largest part of the outlay.
('67', 300, 2, 10, 514452) For spinning yarn for one yard of Khadi takes longer then any of the other processes anterior or posterior to it will take.
('67', 300, 2, 11, 514576) If a person gins, cards and spins for himself, which he can do easily, he will get his khadi almost at the same price as mill cloth.
('67', 300, 2, 12, 514709) The cost of an article represents the cost of labour spent in its production.
('67', 300, 2, 13, 514787) So when the whole labour comes from the user himself the cost is practically nothing, when that labour is given during leisure hours.
('67', 300, 2, 14, 514921) Self suffcient khadi eliminates the middleman altogether.
('67', 300, 2, 15, 514979) It is the easiest method of perceptibly increasing the income of the millions of the semi starved villagers.
('67', 300, 2, 16, 515088) But will the villager ever take to self sufficent khadi?
('67', 300, 2, 17, 515145) Yes, if we have faith accompanied by technical skill, or rather a living faith that will move mountains and give the worker all the skill necessary for his task which is undoubtedly difficult.
('67', 300, 2, 18, 515338) But whether difficult or easy it has hardly been attempted as yet on any large or organized scale or a well conceived plan.
('67', 300, 2, 19, 515462) Not without a well conceived, India wide effort to educate the villagers to produce their own cloth and thus stop the unnecessary drain from their villages of what little they possess, will the A.I.S.A. have justified its existence; for as I have been of late insisting in these columns, the message of khadi is nothing less than its
('67', 301, 0, 1, 515796) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 302
('67', 301, 1, 2, 515838) universal use in the villages by local production and local use.
('67', 301, 1, 3, 515903) The beginning has to be made by inducing cotton cultivation in every village, even in those where it is never known to have been grown.
('67', 301, 1, 4, 516039) Without decentralization of cotton cultivation, universal manufacture in villages may not be possible.
('67', 301, 1, 5, 516142) We have authentic examples of deserts having been turned into smiling gardens by judicious manipulation of the soil.
('67', 301, 1, 6, 516259) It ought not, therefore, to be impossible to grow enough cotton in every village, for local use.
('67', 301, 1, 7, 516356) Not only will this cheapen khadi for the villagers, but it will also improve the durability of khadi.
('67', 301, 1, 8, 516458) Experience has conclusively demonstrated that the strength of yarn and the output are affected by the variety of cotton used and the manner of picking, cleaning, ginning, carding and spinning cotton.
('67', 301, 1, 9, 516658) A material from which the famous Dacca muslin could be produced must demand gentle handling during all the processes it undergoes, before it comes out as shabnam or the morningdew.
('67', 301, 1, 10, 516839) Harijan, 3 8 1935
('67', 301, 2, 11, 516857) 472. REMARKS ON BODY LABOUR 1
('67', 301, 3, 12, 516887) Why worry about those who do not do body labour?
('67', 301, 3, 13, 516936) I have never imagined that every man on earth will earn his bread by the sweat of his brow, but I have simply enunciated the golden rule.
('67', 301, 3, 14, 517074) Are you prepared to do it?
('67', 301, 3, 15, 517101) If you are, you need not be jealous of the man who is not prepared to do it or cannot do it.
('67', 301, 3, 16, 517194) I may not be able to earn what fruit and milk I eat by mere body labour, but that means that I am to be pitied, the rule is not affected.
('67', 301, 3, 17, 517332) Only a few people can observe brahmacharya, but should they, therefore, be jealous of the millions who cannot?
('67', 301, 3, 18, 517443) The latter may be pitied, rather than be envied.
('67', 301, 3, 19, 517492) I have indicated the ideal to work up to.
('67', 301, 3, 20, 517534) Let everyone try to observe it as best as one can.
('67', 301, 3, 21, 517585) Don’t worry because you are incapable of doing any body labour.
('67', 301, 3, 22, 517649) Do whatever other clean labour you can, and be sure that you do not exploit those that labour for you.
('67', 301, 3, 23, 517752) Do not worry about the doctors and the rest who in your opinion seem to have no time for body labour.
('67', 301, 3, 24, 517854) When they will practise their professions in a pure spirit of service to the community, the community will take care to see that they are not starved.
('67', 301, 3, 25, 518005) Harijan, 3 8 1935
('67', 301, 4, 26, 518023) 1 This is extracted from the “Weekly Letter” by Mahadev Desai, who had reported: “Some of the simplest things that Gandhiji has been saying and writing seem to puzzle and perplex people.
('67', 301, 4, 27, 518210) One of these is Gandhiji’s insistence on bread labour.” What follows is Gandhiji’s reply to them.

('67', 303, 3, 6, 520081) 2. Should any earmarked donation be accepted?
('67', 303, 3, 7, 520127) 3. Whether I wish to form a trust or a committee to deal with the expenditure or if I have thought of any alternative arrangement.
('67', 303, 3, 8, 520258) Here is my clarification on these points: Although my main requirement is for the propagation of Hindi in South India, I would like to utilize the funds when occasion arises for provinces like Bengal, Assam, Sind, Gujarat and Punjab where Hindi is not known well or has not been propagated.
('67', 303, 3, 9, 520549) There should be no objection to accepting for the purse earmaked contributions if a donor wishes to contribute for the work in any of these provinces or for the training of necessary propagandists.
('67', 303, 3, 10, 520747) Now about a trust or a committee.
('67', 303, 3, 11, 520781) I intend to form a trust or a committee or a registered institution when the whole sum is collected and disburse the funds through it under my own supervision.

('67', 308, 1, 2, 526961) 486. LETTER TO SHIVAPRASAD GUPTA
('67', 308, 2, 3, 526994) [August, 6, 1935] 1
('67', 308, 3, 4, 527014) DEAR SHIVAPRASAD,
('67', 308, 4, 5, 527032) Received your letter.
('67', 308, 4, 6, 527054) You have not forgotten the country even in your ill health.
('67', 308, 4, 7, 527114) After my severance from the Congress, the Working Committee met here for the first time.
('67', 308, 4, 8, 527203) It matters little whether it meets here or somewhere else.
('67', 308, 4, 9, 527262) Your question is why I am so very interested in the Congress after I have severed my connections with it, and why I give my advice and opinion to them.
('67', 308, 4, 10, 527414) I think you already know that when I severed my connection with the Congress I had already said that, if anything be referred to me.
('67', 308, 4, 11, 527547) I would give my opinion.
('67', 308, 4, 12, 527572) To control the Congress and to give advice to Congressmen are two different things.
('67', 308, 4, 13, 527656) The Congress Committee held its sittings here, but I never participated therein.
('67', 308, 4, 14, 527737) I am totally in the dark regarding its full proceedings up till now, Whenever any member wanted to consult me or have my opinion, they used to call at my place and I used to give them my advice most willingly.
('67', 308, 4, 15, 527947) I do not see any reason for not doing so.
('67', 308, 4, 16, 527989) I came out of the Congress only for its benefit.
('67', 308, 4, 17, 528038) I cannot forgo the ideals of the Congress.
('67', 308, 4, 18, 528081) Knowingly if I refuse to give them my advice, I fall from dharma.
('67', 308, 5, 19, 528147) Now as regards Council entry, I think Council entry is dharma at this stage but not for myself, for I have devoted myself to something else.
('67', 308, 5, 20, 528288) My sadhana at present is non violent disobedience of laws.
('67', 308, 5, 21, 528347) Council entry will prove a hindrance in the realization of that end of mi ne.
('67', 308, 5, 22, 528425) Do you not know, what is one man’s meat is another man’s poison?
('67', 308, 6, 23, 528490) I hope I have given answers to all your questions which will be to your satisfaction.
('67', 308, 7, 24, 528576) Leave the Council entry to me and devote yourself entirely to village industry and Hindi prachar.
('67', 308, 7, 25, 528674) If you will devote heart and soul to the above, you will not get time to think of other things.
('67', 308, 7, 26, 528770) May God

('67', 310, 3, 4, 530189) MY DEAR GAVAI,
('67', 310, 4, 5, 530204) I have gone through the interesting document left by you with me.
('67', 310, 4, 6, 530270) This is my opinion: All rules must be interpreted so as to advance their purpose; in this case the interest of the Harijans.
('67', 310, 4, 7, 530395) Therefore election of four is not obligatory but if there are more than four candidates, four have to be elected by the college.
('67', 310, 4, 8, 530524) Withdrawals are certainly permissible at any stage.
('67', 310, 4, 9, 530576) Any candidate of the Harijan class has the right of becoming a candidate for the general election.
('67', 310, 4, 10, 530675) If the electoral college is considered a burden, Harijans can any day by practically unanimous agreement forgo the privilege.
('67', 310, 4, 11, 530801) Such a provision is made in the Pact itself.
('67', 310, 4, 12, 530846) Needless to say mine cannot be in any way regarded as a legal opinion.
('67', 310, 4, 13, 530917) It is that of one who had a hand in promoting the Pact.

('67', 311, 5, 19, 533172) 491. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('67', 311, 6, 20, 533203) August 8, 1935
('67', 311, 7, 21, 533218) NARANDAS, I have received no such letter from Mathew as he speaks of.
('67', 311, 7, 22, 533288) His demand is against our principles.
('67', 311, 7, 23, 533326) He persists in it in spite of repeated warnings.
('67', 311, 7, 24, 533375) For the present, we are unable to send him anything for his parents, nor can he come to me just now.
('67', 311, 7, 25, 533476) He can consider himself permanent so long as he is satisfied with bare maintenance and works for it.

('67', 313, 1, 2, 535424) 494. LESSON TO LILAVATI ASAR 1
('67', 313, 2, 3, 535455) August 9, 1935
('67', 313, 3, 4, 535470) 1. A clause beginning with ‘when’ can be used either before or after the principal clause.
('67', 313, 3, 5, 535561) ‘When’ is used for all tenses as in Gujarati, e.g., ‘When you come, we shall play.’ 2. ‘Before you come, I shall have gone.’ ‘Before’ pahelan.
('67', 313, 3, 6, 535704) ‘Since you have come, we have been all well.’ ‘Since’ tyarthi or karanake [because].
('67', 313, 3, 7, 535789) ‘Ago’ is not used to make an independent sentence.
('67', 313, 3, 8, 535840) ‘Long ago’ lamba kal pahelan, ‘years ago’ varsho pahelan; they are thus used to suggest the tense.
('67', 313, 3, 9, 535939) 3. ‘Large’ is used for inanimate objects only, e.g., ‘A large vessel’; but ‘A big boy’.
('67', 313, 3, 10, 536027) ‘Big can be used in both cases.
('67', 313, 3, 11, 536059) The same is the case with ‘small’ and ‘little’.
('67', 313, 3, 12, 536107) BAPU From a photostat of the Gujarati: G.N. 9254. Also C.W. 10103. Courtesy: Lilavati Asar
('67', 313, 4, 13, 536198) 495. LETTER TO LILAVATI ASAR

('67', 313, 7, 18, 536355) You have certainly done well to reduce your expenses.
('67', 313, 7, 19, 536409) If you have patience, everything will be well.
('67', 313, 7, 20, 536456) Don’t reduce the expenses to a
('67', 313, 8, 21, 536487) 1 Lilavati Asar had written : “(1) The 14th lesson of the Pathmala is now completed.
('67', 313, 8, 22, 536572) Now I will start on the 15th.
('67', 313, 8, 23, 536602) It is about the past continuous tense.
('67', 313, 8, 24, 536641) I am giving you one example : ‘When I came yesterday you were writing.’ Here ‘when’ is at the beginning of the sentence.
('67', 313, 8, 25, 536762) The second sentence is as follows : ‘We were coming to school when the bell rang.’ Now in the first sentence ‘when’ is placed at the beginning of the sentence and in the second sentence after.
('67', 313, 8, 26, 536955) Is there any difference in their usage?
('67', 313, 8, 27, 536995) Is there any rule as to when ‘when’ is placed before or after?
('67', 313, 8, 28, 537058) Is the verb in the past tense when ‘when’ is used?
('67', 313, 8, 29, 537109) (2) Another thing I do not know well is how to use ‘since’.

('67', 313, 8, 32, 537283) Can both he used in the same place?
('67', 313, 8, 33, 537319) Is it the same with ‘small’ and ‘little’?

('67', 315, 0, 1, 538950) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 316
('67', 315, 1, 2, 538992) 497. DISCUSSION ON REORGANIZING KHADI PRODUCTION 1
('67', 315, 2, 3, 539043) [Before August 10, 1935]
('67', 315, 3, 4, 539068) QUESTION: In Bihar something like five thousand women walk ten miles a day to receive the present scanty wage.
('67', 315, 3, 5, 539179) More would come if we could sell more khadi.
('67', 315, 3, 6, 539224) What would happen to these poor women, if the demand for khadi disappeared?”
('67', 315, 4, 7, 539301) GANDHIJI: Quite, right.
('67', 315, 4, 8, 539325) I know the same is the state of things in Bengal villages and in South India.
('67', 315, 4, 9, 539403) But I would put your proposition in a converse way.
('67', 315, 4, 10, 539455) Supposing you gave one pie instead of two pies an hour that you give at present, you would be employing not 5,000 women but 10,000 women.
('67', 315, 4, 11, 539593) And supposing these helpless women were ready to accept even that miserable pittance, would you dare to do it?
('67', 315, 4, 12, 539704) I say, you would not.
('67', 315, 4, 13, 539726) That means that you will have to determine a point beyond which you cannot go.
('67', 315, 4, 14, 539805) Call it if you will a ‘helpless minimum’.
('67', 315, 4, 15, 539847) But if that minimum has to be fixed, why not fix it once and for all, no matter whether it affects some of the producers for the time being adversely?
('67', 315, 4, 16, 539998) So long as the number of purchasers is limited and the number of producers unlimited, there is no doubt that you will have to turn some of the producers away.
('67', 315, 4, 17, 540157) Why not then have a deliberately fixed, high enough minimum wage to ensure these poor women at least a living wage?
('67', 315, 4, 18, 540273) Otherwise there would be no end to this unconscious exploitation.
('67', 315, 4, 19, 540339) A paper manufacturer sends us paper from a place.
('67', 315, 4, 20, 540389) He is paying the labourers at the rate of six pice per day, and says he hopes to make the paper cheaper.
('67', 315, 4, 21, 540494) I tell him I will not have it cheaper.
('67', 315, 5, 22, 540533) Then you will now change the definition of khadi.
('67', 315, 5, 23, 540583) It no longer remains hand spun hand woven cloth, but cloth hand spun and hand woven at a particular wage.
('67', 315, 5, 24, 540689) There is no doubt.
('67', 315, 5, 25, 540708) I am sorry that you are making the discovery so late.
('67', 315, 6, 26, 540762) But spinning is a supplementary occupation, we have been telling the world all these years.
('67', 315, 6, 27, 540854) It is done only in one’s spare hours.
('67', 315, 7, 28, 540892) 1 This is extracted from “Weekly Letter” by Mahadev Desai who had explained that the presence of Congress Working Committee members like Rajendra Prasad, Vallabhbhai Patel, Jairamdas Doulatram, Jamnalal Bajaj, Pattabhi Sitaramayya, Gangadharrao Deshpande and J.B. Kripalani “stimulated the discussion” on the subject which had become a burning question ever since Gandhiji wrote the article on the “Need for a Standard Wage”
('67', 316, 0, 1, 541317) VOL. 67 : 25 APRIL, 1935 22 SEPTEMBER, 1935 317
('67', 316, 1, 2, 541365) Yes and no.
('67', 316, 1, 3, 541377) I know that there are thousands who are doing it for the whole day.
('67', 316, 1, 4, 541445) To them it is not a supplementary but a substantive occupation.
('67', 316, 1, 5, 541509) And even if it is not, why not give them for an hour’s work what you would usually give for any other hour’s work?
('67', 316, 2, 6, 541624) Do you know that in some parts of Guntur District, people are taking to rice pounding because it fetches a higher wage than spinning?
('67', 316, 2, 7, 541758) But you support my argument.
('67', 316, 2, 8, 541787) They will certainly choose whatever work fetches them a higher wage.
('67', 316, 2, 9, 541856) Then why not dignify the spinner by a wage which will be equal to any other wage?
('67', 316, 3, 10, 541938) Practical difficulties are very great.
('67', 316, 3, 11, 541977) You cannot induce these spinners to conform to your terms.
('67', 316, 3, 12, 542036) You want a regular register of them, you want them to spin yarn of a particular count, of particular evenness and of particular strength.
('67', 316, 3, 13, 542174) How will all that be done?
('67', 316, 3, 14, 542201) The difficulties have got to be conquered.
('67', 316, 3, 15, 542244) Don’t I know that for considerable length of time there will be tales of long drawn out agony—some saying we cannot induce the spinners to spin for themselves, some saying we cannot get them to conform to our requirements?
('67', 316, 4, 16, 542467) But supposing they conform to our regulations and we give them better machines and better spindles, they will automatically do more work and more than double the wage.
('67', 316, 4, 17, 542635) That they will do automatically but for no virtue of yours.
('67', 316, 4, 18, 542695) That more production means more earning is obvious enough.
('67', 316, 4, 19, 542754) But what are we going to do, by way of justice which we have denied them?
('67', 316, 4, 20, 542828) No, we shall have to forget that khadi has to compete with mill cloth.
('67', 316, 4, 21, 542899) Mill cloth is mill cloth and khadi is khadi.
('67', 316, 4, 22, 542944) The mill cloth producer will always concentrate on cheapening it, we must concentrate on justice and a fair wage.
('67', 316, 4, 23, 543058) There can be therefore no comparison between the two.
('67', 316, 4, 24, 543112) As regards the practical difficulties, let us reduce our establishments, let us stop advertisements, let us not patronize the private producer.
('67', 316, 4, 25, 543256) It is going to be the test of those who are pledged to khadi.
('67', 316, 4, 26, 543318) Let them produce it themselves or pay for it enough to give our brothers and sisters a living wage.
('67', 316, 4, 27, 543418) It is a question of the self purification of all khadi weavers.
('67', 316, 4, 28, 543482) Let us not forget that our mission is the service of Daridranarayana.
('67', 316, 4, 29, 543552) Difficulties there may be, but let us solve them gradually.
('67', 316, 5, 30, 543612) Harijan, 10 8 1935
('67', 316, 6, 31, 543631) 1 Mahadev Desai had concluded: “It seemed to be generally agreed that the experiment must be started wherever possible and with varying but increased wages for spinners.”
('67', 317, 0, 1, 543802) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 318
('67', 317, 1, 2, 543844) 498. THE BOMBAY KHADI BHANDAR
('67', 317, 2, 3, 543874) The Bombay Khadi Bhandar is the largest khadi bhandar depot of the A.I.S.A. It is no single individual’s property.
('67', 317, 2, 4, 543989) It belongs to the A.I.S.A. as the sole trustees for Daridranarayana.
('67', 317, 2, 5, 544058) As such its primary concern must be Daridranarayana.
('67', 317, 2, 6, 544111) Though it has served as a means of giving honourable employment to some middle class people, it must not be regarded as an employment bureau for them.
('67', 317, 2, 7, 544262) Since a new policy is in the course of adoption, reduction is being made in the staff in keeping with the requirements of the new policy.
('67', 317, 2, 8, 544400) Hitherto extraordinary efforts have been made to push up sales of khadi sent from all parts of India and ordered by Shri Jerajani in accordance with patterns designed by his inventive genius.
('67', 317, 2, 9, 544592) But this effort meant overhead charges out of proportion to the results achieved in terms of Daridranarayana.
('67', 317, 2, 10, 544702) And it drew the attention of the provincial workers away from their main work which was to make khadi self supporting or popular in their own provinces.
('67', 317, 2, 11, 544855) The universal mission of khadi cannot be fulfilled without true provincial effort.
('67', 317, 2, 12, 544938) That can be achieved only by its distribution as faras possible in the innumerable centres of production.
('67', 317, 2, 13, 545044) No doubt some khadi will always be required for big cities like Bombay which will never produce it themselves.
('67', 317, 2, 14, 545155) That will be a healthy demand to be met without extraordinary effort.
('67', 317, 2, 15, 545225) The rich variety one sees in the city khadi shop was possible only because the Association put forth the effort to meet the varied tastes of the city public.
('67', 317, 2, 16, 545383) But time has come, if khadi is to fulfil its mission,to turn the attention towards centres of production.
('67', 317, 2, 17, 545489) They are far too few.
('67', 317, 2, 18, 545511) Every village, if not every home, has to be such a centre even as every home is a centre of production of cooked food.
('67', 317, 2, 19, 545630) The economy of the kitchen is wholly different from the economy of the books.
('67', 317, 2, 20, 545708) Even so is the economy of khadi.
('67', 317, 2, 21, 545741) The contemplated change, then, means substantial reduction in the staff of large bhandars run by or on behalf of the A.I.S.A. It also means reduction in the number, if not disappearance, of certified private producers.
('67', 317, 2, 22, 545960) How it will all be worked, it is difficult to say as yet.
('67', 317, 2, 23, 546018) It is being carefully worked out by Shri Shankerlal Banker who has been travelling throughout India for that special purpose.
('67', 317, 2, 24, 546144) But meanwhile this is to warn the lovers of khadi, the votaries of Daridranarayana, the prices of khadi must go up, greater technical skill must be developed among khadi workers, a greater spirit of self 
('67', 318, 0, 1, 546349) VOL. 67 : 25 APRIL, 1935 22 SEPTEMBER, 1935 319
('67', 318, 1, 2, 546397) sacrifice must be evoked amongst all the classes connected with the production and distribution of khadi.
('67', 318, 1, 3, 546503) Sales depots have taken delight in showing a progressive decline in the prices.
('67', 318, 1, 4, 546583) I remember the time when I sold the first piece of very coarse khadi for over one rupee per yard.
('67', 318, 1, 5, 546681) Such coarse khadi will not fetch two annas today.
('67', 318, 1, 6, 546731) It is not on sale at khadi depots.
('67', 318, 1, 7, 546766) This decrease has been brought about no doubt by progressive efficiency in every department of khadi, but it has been largely purchased at the cost of the spinner.
('67', 318, 1, 8, 546930) And yet the concrete shape of Daridranarayana is the spinner—the lowest paid labourer in all India.
('67', 318, 1, 9, 547030) It was good that the A.I.S.A. found a means of employment on the widest scale possible for the chronic unemployed at a wage, be it ever so low, even one pie per hour.
('67', 318, 1, 10, 547197) But if it is to discharge its trust, it must find at least a subsistence wage for the spinner.
('67', 318, 1, 11, 547292) Her receipt for the spinning hour should be in proportion to the amount she would need to live if she worked for eight hours a day.
('67', 318, 1, 12, 547424) What that amount is to be is not so much matter of moment, as that there must be an increase in the rate of wages earned by the spinners.
('67', 318, 1, 13, 547562) Henceforth the reports of the A.I.S.A. should state not how much reduction in the price of khadi has taken place during the period under review, but they should take pride in showing how much increase has been made in spinning wage.
('67', 318, 1, 14, 547795) It should not be satisfied—I cannot be satisfied—till the spinner’s wage per hour has been put on a level with, say, the weaver’s.
('67', 318, 1, 15, 547926) And let the buying public remember that they are the unnamed members of that great trust and that the spinners are their wards.
('67', 318, 1, 16, 548054) Once that relation is realized there should be no difficulty in the progressive rise of khadi in the geometrical ratio.
('67', 318, 1, 17, 548174) Would that every lover of khadi will know his duty and falsify the fears of the unbelievers among khadi workers who think that the public will never pay a higher price for khadi!
('67', 318, 2, 18, 548353) Harijan, 10 8 1935

('67', 322, 8, 18, 553638) 506. LETTER TO ANAND T. HINGORANI
('67', 322, 9, 19, 553672) August 12, 1935 DEAR FRIEND, 1. No matter how weak a person is in body, if it is a shame to flee, he will stand his ground and die at his post.
('67', 322, 9, 20, 553816) This would be non violence and bravery.
('67', 322, 9, 21, 553856) 2. No matter how weak he is, he will use what strength he has in inflicting injury on his opponent and die in the attempt.
('67', 322, 9, 22, 553979) This is bravery but not non violence.
('67', 322, 9, 23, 554017) 3. If when his duty is to face danger, he flees, it is cowardice.
('67', 323, 0, 1, 554083) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 324
('67', 323, 1, 2, 554125) 4. In the first case the man will have love or charity in him.
('67', 323, 1, 3, 554188) In the 2nd and 3rd cases there would be dislike or distrust and fear.

('67', 324, 1, 2, 555518) 509. LETTER TO PREMABEHN KANTAK
('67', 324, 2, 3, 555550) WARDHA, August 13, 1935 CHI.
('67', 324, 2, 4, 555579) PREMA, I am observing two and a half hours’ silence today to overtake the arrears of correspondence.
('67', 324, 2, 5, 555680) Disposing of the letters one by one, I saw just now your letter of July 9, 1935. You did very well in meeting Kelkar 1. It would be good if you could take him to see your work.
('67', 324, 2, 6, 555857) What you say about work regarded as unclean is correct.
('67', 324, 2, 7, 555913) I am giving in Harijanbandhu the portion about the Mahars.
('67', 324, 2, 8, 555972) Your name will not be published.
('67', 324, 2, 9, 556005) Inform me when the Poona resolution is implemented.
('67', 324, 2, 10, 556057) Which is the other book about Hitler?
('67', 324, 3, 11, 556095) And now I come to your question.
('67', 324, 3, 12, 556128) There is great risk in taking Russia as a model to be emulated.
('67', 324, 3, 13, 556192) For one thing, we have no direct knowledge; secondly, the experiment has not yet lasted long enough; and thirdly, they rely on violence for what they are doing.
('67', 324, 3, 14, 556353) We should, therefore, leave out Russia when thinking about our problems.
('67', 324, 3, 15, 556426) This must be assumed to be common ground between us, that we do not wish to use violence to force people to do anything.
('67', 324, 3, 16, 556547) Hence the easiest way of securing justice from the rich is to see that they make the best use of the wealth they earn.
('67', 324, 3, 17, 556666) This may possibly result in their being no longer eager to acquire much wealth.
('67', 324, 3, 18, 556746) We need not mind that.
('67', 324, 3, 19, 556769) Nor need we mind, even if such a result does not follow.
('67', 324, 3, 20, 556826) We shall in this way get the use of so much wealth without having to bother about its safety.
('67', 324, 3, 21, 556920) If a large number of rich people become trustees, we shall want nothing more.
('67', 324, 3, 22, 556998) Your argument springs from the suspicion that the rich will never agree to be trustees of their own property.
('67', 324, 3, 23, 557108) We needn’t worry if your suspicion is well founded, for truth is bound to triumph ultimately.
('67', 324, 3, 24, 557202) He who keeps more than he needs is a thief and stolen wealth is like unprocessed mercury.
('67', 324, 3, 25, 557292) It cannot be digested.
('67', 324, 3, 26, 557315) We should have faith that the thief will
('67', 324, 4, 27, 557356) 1 N.C. Kelkar 2 In Bapuna Patro–5 : Ku.

('67', 333, 0, 1, 568175) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 334
('67', 333, 1, 2, 568217) 524. DECENTRALIZATION?
('67', 333, 2, 3, 568240) Before the forthcoming meeting (on 30th instant) of the executive of the Harijan Sevak Sangh Board, among the many important questions for discussion, will be that of the need for decentralization which some provincial boards have felt for the sake of the better advancement of its object.
('67', 333, 2, 4, 568530) Centralization was insisted upon by Sheth Ghanshyamdas Birla and Shri Amritlal Thakkar for the decisive reason that money was found by the Centre, the Presidents of the Provincial Boards were selected by Sheth Ghanshyamdas, and the policy was also evolved by the Central Board.
('67', 333, 2, 5, 568808) Though I have concurred in the policy of centralization I have always desired, as I have no doubt the Board, too, has desired, decentralization at the first opportunity.
('67', 333, 2, 6, 568978) But that could only be done when the Provincial Boards were ready and able to raise their own funds.
('67', 333, 2, 7, 569079) I would love nothing so much as that every village had its Harijan Board and was able to find its own funds.
('67', 333, 2, 8, 569188) When that day comes, it will also be one of complete abolition of untouchability in every shape and form.
('67', 333, 2, 9, 569294) For the present it has to be unfortunately admitted that the cause is still led by a handful of earnest reformers scattered all over the country.
('67', 333, 2, 10, 569440) Not all of them are able to raise funds locally nor are they all sure of the policy to be followed.
('67', 333, 2, 11, 569540) I use the word ‘policy’ deliberately.
('67', 333, 2, 12, 569578) For while everyone knows the goal, everyone does not know the grave limitations under which the reformer labours.
('67', 333, 2, 13, 569692) The slightest error of judgment, a hasty action or a hasty word may put back the hands of the clock of progress.
('67', 333, 2, 14, 569805) Policies have, therefore, to be cautiously evolved in the light of experiences daily gained by the few who have no other thought but that of serving Harijans and ridding Hinduism of its greatest blot.
('67', 333, 2, 15, 570006) Harijan workers will be grieved to learn that there are more than Rs. 80,000 as advances to Provincial Boards in the books of the Central Office.
('67', 333, 2, 16, 570152) This has a tale to tell.
('67', 333, 2, 17, 570177) Those Boards against whom the money stand have not been able to find their quota.
('67', 333, 2, 18, 570259) It is also a grievous fact that not all the Boards have sent in their returns in accordance with the prescribed manner.
('67', 333, 2, 19, 570379) The third thing to note is that in spite of the ceaseless vigilance of the Secretaries and their tours, the district
('67', 334, 0, 1, 570496) VOL. 67 : 25 APRIL, 1935 22 SEPTEMBER, 1935 335
('67', 334, 1, 2, 570544) organizations have not functioned as they might have done.
('67', 334, 1, 3, 570603) This is not to say that workers in the provinces and districts have nothing to their credit.
('67', 334, 1, 4, 570696) Indeed the columns of Harijan have abundantly shown, what amazing progress the cause has made during the very short period that the Boards have functioned.
('67', 334, 1, 5, 570852) But just now my purpose is to examine the debit side so as to enable interested workers to come to a right decision.
('67', 334, 1, 6, 570969) It may be that the defects to which I have drawn attention are due to the policy of overcentralization.
('67', 334, 1, 7, 571073) If it be so, the advocates of decentralization have to prove their case.
('67', 334, 1, 8, 571146) Had the Centre felt the need, it would have come long ago.
('67', 334, 1, 9, 571205) The forthcoming meeting is that of the executive of the Board.
('67', 334, 1, 10, 571268) It consists of seven members of whom the Chairman is absent.
('67', 334, 1, 11, 571329) I would invite the Harijan sevaks throughout the provinces to send their considered opinion to the Secretaries at Delhi supporting them as briefly as they can with facts and figures.
('67', 334, 1, 12, 571512) After all in a cause so humanitarian as that of Harijans involving the very existence of an ancient faith, nothing should be left undone that would advance it.
('67', 334, 1, 13, 571672) Personal considerations do not count in such matters.
('67', 334, 2, 14, 571726) Harijan, 17 8 1935
('67', 334, 3, 15, 571745) 525. COMPOST MANURE
('67', 334, 4, 16, 571765) There is in Indore an Institute of Plant Industry.
('67', 334, 4, 17, 571816) It issues from time to time leaflets for those whom it is designed to serve.
('67', 334, 4, 18, 571893) The first one of these describes the utility and the method of preparing compost manure from farm wastes.
('67', 334, 4, 19, 571999) As it is valuable for Harijans and village workers who handle cattle dung and night soil, I copy below practically the whole of the leaflet 1 incorporating footnotes into the running description of the process.
('67', 334, 5, 20, 572210) Harijan, 17 8 1935
('67', 334, 6, 21, 572229) 526. SNAKE POISONING
('67', 334, 7, 22, 572250) Dr. Sokhey, Director of Haffkine Institute, has kindly supplied me with a note on Indian snakes.
('67', 334, 7, 23, 572347) As co workers are spreading out in villages, it becomes necessary to arm them with information in matters of common occurrence in villages where city conveniences are
('67', 334, 8, 24, 572514) 1 Not reproduced here; it appeared, in parts, in this and the following issue of Harijan.
('67', 335, 0, 1, 572604) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 336
('67', 335, 1, 2, 572646) unfortunately unavailable.
('67', 335, 1, 3, 572673) The most dangerous is snakebite which proves fatal in many cases if the necessary measures are not immediately adopted.
('67', 335, 1, 4, 572793) I give below the important portions of the note 1. The whole contains useful information about identification of snakes.
('67', 335, 1, 5, 572914) But the description is too technical for the village worker to follow.
('67', 335, 1, 6, 572985) I am, therefore, omitting this part of the note.
('67', 335, 1, 7, 573034) Since nine tenths of snakes are non poisonous and are valuable protectors of fields against rats, etc., it would be a good thing if a simple key for distinguishing poisonous from non poisonous snakes can be had.
('67', 335, 1, 8, 573246) Meanwhile let those interested study the very simple remedy described below: 2
('67', 335, 2, 9, 573325) Though Col.
('67', 335, 2, 10, 573337) Sokhey has warned me that there is no sure remedy against bites of poisonous snakes except injections of antivenom serum, I cannot resist giving the remedy claimed to have been succesfully tried by Just, the author of Return to Nature.
('67', 335, 2, 11, 573573) I have tried it successfully in two or three cases of snake bites and numerous cases of scorpion stings.
('67', 335, 2, 12, 573678) It consists in applying an ample earth bandage to the affected part.
('67', 335, 2, 13, 573747) Take as much clean earth as possible, add cold water to it and make a cold poultice of it.
('67', 335, 2, 14, 573838) Spread the composition an inch as a pack on a wet linen piece, fold, apply and bandage.
('67', 335, 2, 15, 573926) If it is a toe that is bitten, the leg should have the poultice up to the knee, if a finger, the whole area should be bandaged, the more the better.
('67', 335, 2, 16, 574075) All the other treatment as described in the foregoing note should undoubtedly be taken.
('67', 335, 2, 17, 574163) And if the serum injection is taken, the earth treatment may be quite superfluous.
('67', 335, 2, 18, 574246) I was assured that if the injection was given in time, it was a sure antidote.
('67', 335, 2, 19, 574325) Nor can I vouch for the absolute efficacy of the earth treatment.
('67', 335, 2, 20, 574391) For I have no knowledge that the bites treated by me were highly poisonous.
('67', 335, 2, 21, 574467) I suggest the earth treatment as being harmless and most easily available in villages and as being highly acclaimed by its author.
('67', 335, 3, 22, 574598) Harijan, 17 8 1935
('67', 335, 4, 23, 574617) 1 Vide Appendix Extracts frrom Dr. Sokhey’s notes on snake poisoning.

('67', 338, 1, 2, 577495) 532. THE WAY TO SERVE
('67', 338, 2, 3, 577517) For nearly a year a lady has been doing welfare work in a village.
('67', 338, 2, 4, 577584) She is gradually making some headway.
('67', 338, 2, 5, 577622) She has already crossed some huge hurdles.
('67', 338, 2, 6, 577665) She ploughs with the farmer’s plough share, cleans roads and teaches women how to spin.
('67', 338, 2, 7, 577753) She is teaching the young and the old.
('67', 338, 2, 8, 577792) From among the experiences which she had, I give below 1 a recent one as it is a very useful one.
('67', 338, 3, 9, 577890) The Chamars would not take a goat’s carcass as it had been touched by a Mahar .
('67', 338, 3, 10, 577970) To take it to the Mangs I put the basket on my head.
('67', 338, 3, 11, 578023) When I started to walk people stared at me.
('67', 338, 3, 12, 578067) I went straight to the Mangs and they took the carcass.
('67', 338, 3, 13, 578123) They said, “why did you carry it?
('67', 338, 3, 14, 578157) If you had told us, we would have fetched it.” I replied, “I wanted to show that no work is dirty; I was not ashamed of this job.
('67', 338, 3, 15, 578287) So why should I trouble you?” This instance shows that nothing is accomplished through speeches, but that results can be obtained by our actually doing what we wish others to do.
('67', 338, 4, 16, 578466) [From Gujarati] Harijanbandhu, 18 8 1935

('67', 344, 7, 11, 586331) 545. A LETTER
('67', 344, 8, 12, 586345) August 21, 1935
('67', 344, 9, 13, 586361) Althought I have never thought in such terms as presented by you, now that I am challenged my first thought is that belief in man’s freedom is wholly unnecessary for conducting the highest type of activity.
('67', 344, 9, 14, 586568) But to answer your second question, I have always reconciled comparative freedom of the individual with the all powerfulness of the Supreme Will.
('67', 344, 9, 15, 586714) I came to that conclusion on observing some ordinary experience of life.
('67', 344, 9, 16, 586787) A prisoner, even in a solitary cell, has freedom of movement, however little it may be, and he has complete freedom of the mind.
('67', 344, 9, 17, 586916) In the question presented by you, even the mind is prisoner under the Supreme Will, and yet He permits us to think millions of idle thoughts.
('67', 344, 9, 18, 587058) Hence I conclude that there is some freedom left to the individual, be it the tiniest conceivable.
('67', 344, 9, 19, 587157) The acid test of complete obedience to the Universal Will would be full surrender even of that tiny freedom.
('67', 344, 10, 20, 587266) From the manuscript of Mahadev Desai’s Diary.
('67', 344, 10, 21, 587312) Courtesy: Narayan Desai

('67', 347, 0, 1, 590532) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 348
('67', 347, 1, 2, 590574) 549. DISCUSSION ON MINIMUM LIVING WAGE I 1
('67', 347, 2, 3, 590617) [August 22/23, 1935] 2
('67', 347, 3, 4, 590640) GANDHIJI: Let us realize our amazing limitations.
('67', 347, 3, 5, 590690) Do not mind even if we have to be like the three tailors of Tooley Street.
('67', 347, 3, 6, 590765) Our resources are few and limited.
('67', 347, 3, 7, 590800) We cannot afford to squander money on high sounding schemes and we cannot adopt any and every means.
('67', 347, 3, 8, 590901) We may fail to get workers and agents, and our branches may have to be few and far between.
('67', 347, 3, 9, 590993) But I am in no hurry to see a network of institutions all over the country.
('67', 347, 3, 10, 591069) Ours is a policy of ploughing a lonely furrow .
('67', 347, 3, 11, 591117) If we find that it is not possible for any industry to pay this minimum living wage, we had better close our shop.
('67', 347, 3, 12, 591232) We should see that in any industry that we handle the wage covers a reasonable maintenance allowance.
('67', 347, 4, 13, 591334) PRAFULLA: When I was an official earning a salary, I used to calculate how much my servants, including their dependants, would need for a fair maintenance and I used to pay them accordingly.
('67', 347, 4, 14, 591525) It used to come to Rs. 20 a month.
('67', 347, 4, 15, 591560) With clothing and other needs, it would come to Rs. 30.
('67', 347, 5, 16, 591616) GANDHIJI (laughingly): Then if you like we shall have a rupee a day as the minimum wage for Bengal.
('67', 347, 5, 17, 591716) What you used to do as an official you have now to do as a member of the Association.
('67', 347, 5, 18, 591802) I would certainly have the wage as high as possible and include in it the maintenance of at least one dependant.
('67', 347, 5, 19, 591915) But you will go as far as you can.
('67', 347, 6, 20, 591950) Vaikuntha Mehta, who is the Managing Director of the Provincial Co operative Bank in Bombay, had not the slightest doubt that the sooner we tackled the question the better; for, when we insisted on an adequate solution of the wage question and that of work in organized large scale industries, it was our duty to attend to these question in case of unorganized industries.
('67', 347, 6, 21, 592323) There were obvious difficulties, but he had no doubt that the moment people were made to see that ninety per cent or more of the rupee that the people spend on an article they purchase goes directly into the pocket of the man who has produced it, they would not grudge to pay the money.
('67', 347, 7, 22, 592610) Shankerlal Banker emphasized the importance of collecting data, from different provinces, of the prices of the minimum articles of a balanced diet, but he had some difficulty in applying the wage question to existing industries.
('67', 347, 8, 23, 592839) 1 The discussion is extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “Weekly Letter”.
('67', 347, 8, 24, 592907) The Management Board of the All India Village Industries Association met at Wardha.
('67', 347, 8, 25, 592991) 2 From The Searchlight, 30 8 1935
('67', 348, 0, 1, 593025) VOL. 67 : 25 APRIL, 1935 22 SEPTEMBER, 1935 349
('67', 348, 1, 2, 593073) Gandhiji made it clear that we were exclusively concerned with dead or dying industries which we were trying to revive and we were not going to disturb the existing industries.
('67', 348, 1, 3, 593250) Was the minimum wage likely to make matters difficult for the villager?
('67', 348, 1, 4, 593322) What about the little articles of the villagers’ daily need, earthen pots and lamps, for instance?
('67', 348, 1, 5, 593421) Because the townspeople were to pay a higher price for those articles, were the villagers also to pay that higher price?
('67', 348, 1, 6, 593542) Already villagers in villages in close proximity to towns were paying a higher price for milk than those in distant villages.
('67', 348, 1, 7, 593668) Gandhiji said: That was inevitable.
('67', 348, 1, 8, 593704) But the villagers among themselves will adjust the prices.
('67', 348, 1, 9, 593763) Besides, when our organization is in good running order, the carpenter and the smith and the weaver and the spinner, who purchase from the potter at the minimum wage price, will have also had their minimum wage price for their respective wares, and they won’t grudge the poor potter his price.
('67', 348, 1, 10, 594057) But that is a distant goal.
('67', 348, 1, 11, 594085) Let us at the present moment content ourselves with things that pass out of villages to the towns and let us refuse to have them at anything less than the minimum living wage price.
('67', 348, 2, 12, 594267) Harijan, 31 8 1935

('67', 349, 3, 16, 596086) Money for this is provided by a certain big firm.

('67', 350, 0, 1, 597322) VOL. 67 : 25 APRIL, 1935 22 SEPTEMBER, 1935 351
('67', 350, 1, 2, 597370) 552. LETTER TO LILAVATI ASAR
('67', 350, 2, 3, 597399) August 23, 1935
('67', 350, 3, 4, 597415) LILAVATI,
('67', 350, 4, 5, 597425) If you leave some space below the questions in your exercises, it will be easier for you to study my comments.
('67', 350, 4, 6, 597536) The questions should be serially numbered.
('67', 350, 4, 7, 597579) ‘I will’ indicates the future tense.
('67', 350, 4, 8, 597616) In the second and the third person ‘would’ expresses desire.
('67', 350, 4, 9, 597677) Apply this rule whenever you find these words used in the lesson you read.
('67', 350, 4, 10, 597752) 1. ‘If’ and ‘will’ can be used in the same sentence.
('67', 350, 4, 11, 597805) If is a conjunction and ‘will’ a verb in this context.
('67', 350, 4, 12, 597860) 2. ‘You will have received my letter.’ ‘I hope you are happy.’ 3. ‘Though you are good, yet will I not hurt you.’ There is very little difference between ‘still’ and ‘yet’.
('67', 350, 4, 13, 598033) 4. ‘He must be punished’ means “He ought to be punished”.
('67', 350, 4, 14, 598091) ‘He shall have been punished’ means ‘He must certainly have been punished’.
('67', 350, 4, 15, 598167) There is not much difference between ‘must’ and ‘shall have’.
('67', 350, 4, 16, 598229) Shall in the second or the third person can have the force of ‘must’.
('67', 350, 5, 17, 598299) 6. ‘Though’ and ‘yet’ or ‘still’ are used in the same sentence.
('67', 350, 5, 18, 598363) ‘Yet’ and ‘still’ complete the sense of ‘though’.
('67', 350, 5, 19, 598413) I hope you will be able to understand all the answers.
('67', 350, 5, 20, 598468) If you do not understand any of them, do not hesitate to ask again.
('67', 350, 6, 21, 598536) Blessings from BAPU
('67', 350, 7, 22, 598556) From a photostat of the Gujarati: G.N. 9337. Also C.W. 6612. Courtesy: Lilavati Asar
('67', 350, 8, 23, 598641) 1 As in the source
('67', 351, 0, 1, 598660) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 352
('67', 351, 1, 2, 598702) 553. LETTER TO NARAHARI D. PARIKH
('67', 351, 2, 3, 598736) August 23, 1935
('67', 351, 3, 4, 598752) NARAHARI,
('67', 351, 4, 5, 598762) Though your letter of the 18th has been lying before me for the last two days, I could read it only today.
('67', 351, 4, 6, 598869) I like Bhai Velchand’s intention.
