('67', 353, 0, 1, 601714) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 354
('67', 353, 1, 2, 601756) 555. NOTES
('67', 353, 2, 3, 601767) HARIJAN–NATTAR PROBLEM This problem is ever with us.
('67', 353, 2, 4, 601820) I have before me a long report sent by a worker in the black area.
('67', 353, 2, 5, 601887) It shows that the Nattars are not much better than before.
('67', 353, 2, 6, 601946) What improvement there is, is due not to conviction or enlightenment.
('67', 353, 2, 7, 602016) It is largely due to the fear of prosecution against the Nattars for the harm they may do to the Harijans, and it is also due to the good work done by the Harijan Sevak Sangh’s workers among the Harijans.
('67', 353, 2, 8, 602221) They have somewhat succeeded in their effort to lessen the Harijans’ fear of the Nattars.
('67', 353, 2, 9, 602311) Permanent improvement is possible only if, as the report suggests, there is steady education spread both among Harijans and Nattars.
('67', 353, 2, 10, 602444) The latter need perhaps more enlightenment than the former.
('67', 353, 2, 11, 602504) Their unspeakable intolerance is due not so much to viciousness as it certainly is to unpardonable ignorance among them.
('67', 353, 2, 12, 602625) Therefore the Sangh has to continue its labours undismayed by difficulties no matter how grave they may appear to be.
('67', 353, 2, 13, 602743) If their faith survives them, it is sure to triumph.
('67', 353, 3, 14, 602796) NOT BOUND Some weavers of Piplav, Bhadran Taluka, Baroda State, write to say that two years ago they resolved to give up carrion eating and to that end gave up carrying and flaying carcasses.
('67', 353, 3, 15, 602988) But the tanners and the Bhangis of the village have been doing that work.
('67', 353, 3, 16, 603062) The Patidars of the village would not tolerate what they thought was presumption on the weavers part and proclaimed a severe boycott of them, cutting off all social services.
('67', 353, 3, 17, 603237) They polluted their well, and began throwing stones on their roofs.
('67', 353, 3, 18, 603305) The writers ask for guidance.
('67', 353, 3, 19, 603335) The Baroda State is well known for its enlightened policy about untouchability.
('67', 353, 3, 20, 603415) I trust that the authorities will go out of their way to save these helpless Harijans whenever they are persecuted by the so called caste Hindus.
('67', 353, 3, 21, 603561) It is also up to the many reformers of advanced Bhadran to befriend these poor weavers and persuade the Patidars of Piplav to desist from the reported ill treatment of its weavers.
('67', 353, 3, 22, 603742) The latter deserve congratulations on their having given up carrion eating.
('67', 353, 3, 23, 603818) They need not have, on that account, given up the carrying and flaying of dead cattle, which is a lucrative and honourable calling and a necessary social service.
('67', 353, 3, 24, 603981) But they are in no way bound to do the carrying or the flaying.
('67', 353, 3, 25, 604045) If an honourable calling is regarded as
('67', 354, 0, 1, 604085) VOL. 67 : 25 APRIL, 1935 22 SEPTEMBER, 1935 355
('67', 354, 1, 2, 604133) degrading, the responsibility for its being so regarded lies on savarna Hindus.
('67', 354, 1, 3, 604213) No wonder if the weavers of Piplav, having become conscious of their degradation and being determined to get rid of it, decided to give up a calling that had led to their being regarded as degraded people.
('67', 354, 1, 4, 604419) It is well for the village of Piplav that it has tanners and scavengers who, not having attained class consciousness, are yet doing carcass carrying and flaying, which society wrongly considers degrading.
('67', 354, 1, 5, 604624) The whole social structure must crumble to pieces if the so called higher classes do not realize the obvious duty of abolishing the evil custom of considering any class of persons as lower than themselves.
('67', 354, 1, 6, 604830) But, while that consummation is being reached, it is the duty of the authorities and the reformers to do everything in theirpower to protect the Harijans against the cruel treatment to which the poor weavers of Piplav are said to be subjected.
('67', 354, 2, 7, 605074) UNTRUTHFUL ADVERTISEMENTS The other day I drew attention 1 to indecent advertising.
('67', 354, 2, 8, 605158) A Calcutta correspondent now sends me cuttings from well known newspapers of advertisement which I would call untruthful.
('67', 354, 2, 9, 605280) Just now a very vigorous propaganda seems to be going on in Bengal and probably in the other provinces also in favour of drinking Indian tea.
('67', 354, 2, 10, 605422) The following is the translation sent by the correspondent of an advertisement in Bengali:
('67', 354, 3, 11, 605513) TEA DRINKING AND YOUTHFUL LOOK
('67', 354, 4, 12, 605544) JALPAIGURI, May 15
('67', 354, 5, 13, 605563) That tea helps retain youthful look and energy long is, it appears, demonstrated from the experience of Shrijut Nepal Chandra Bhattacharya.
('67', 354, 5, 14, 605703) He is now forty eight, but he looks no older than thirty four.
('67', 354, 5, 15, 605766) He maintains that this youthful look of his is due to his taking tea.
('67', 354, 5, 16, 605836) He had his first cup of tea when he was fourteen.
('67', 354, 5, 17, 605886) Since then he has been a regular tea drinker, and since the year before last he has been taking more or less thirty cups of tea daily.
('67', 354, 5, 18, 606021) In this respect he has a peculiarity all his own.
('67', 354, 5, 19, 606071) He does not take tea immediately it is prepared, nor does he sip in the whole of it, but rejects a little at the bottom.
('67', 354, 5, 20, 606192) He takes from six to ten cups of it at a time.
('67', 354, 5, 21, 606239) This is a specimen of many such and reads as if it were a report from the paper’s own correspondent.
('67', 354, 5, 22, 606340) It advances a claim for tea drinking which has no support in human experience anywhere.
('67', 354, 5, 23, 606428) On the contrary even those who advocate tea drinking advise extreme
('67', 354, 6, 24, 606496) 1 Vide “Notes” Sub title “Need for Correctness
('67', 355, 0, 1, 606543) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 356
('67', 355, 1, 2, 606585) moderation.
('67', 355, 1, 3, 606597) We should be no worse off if there was no tea drunk in India.
('67', 355, 1, 4, 606659) But unfortunately tea and such other so called harmless drinks have come to stay in our midst.
('67', 355, 1, 5, 606754) My plea is for due regard for truth in advertising.
('67', 355, 1, 6, 606806) It is a habit with people, especially in India, to treat the printed word in a book or a newspaper as gospel truth.
('67', 355, 1, 7, 606922) There is need, therefore, for extreme caution in drawing up advertisements.
('67', 355, 1, 8, 606998) Untruths such as my correspondent has drawn attention to are most dangerous.
('67', 355, 1, 9, 607075) To drink thirty cups of tea per day not only does not refresh the body or the mind but weakens digestion and enervates the drinker.
('67', 355, 1, 10, 607207) One or two cups of weak tea per day is about as much as the human body can accommodate, perhaps, without harm.
('67', 355, 1, 11, 607318) In India the tea leaves are actually boiled so as to draw all the tannin they may contain.
('67', 355, 1, 12, 607409) Any doctor would testify that tannin is bad for the stomach.
('67', 355, 1, 13, 607470) The Chinese know how to drink tea.
('67', 355, 1, 14, 607505) Theyput their leaves in a strainer and pour boiling water over the leaves which are never put in the tea pot.
('67', 355, 1, 15, 607615) The water has to attain only the colour of the straw.
('67', 355, 1, 16, 607669) It is pale yellow, never bordering on the red as tea made generally in India.
('67', 355, 1, 17, 607747) Strong tea is poison.
('67', 355, 2, 18, 607769) Harijan, 24 8 1935
('67', 355, 3, 19, 607788) 556. ANSWERS TO VILLAGE WORKERS’ QUESTIONS 1
('67', 355, 4, 20, 607833) 1 5. There is no difference whatsoever between the two villages, so far as the village industries programme is concerned.
('67', 355, 4, 21, 607955) In no case should a worker come in conflict with the authorities.
('67', 355, 5, 22, 608021) 1 This is extracted from “Weekly Letter” by Mahadev Desai who had explained: “Some young men who have settled in a village in a Kathiawar State have sent the following questions to Gandhiji: (1) Which of the two should be preferred for swaraj work—a village in a native State or a British Indian village.
('67', 355, 5, 23, 608326) (2) Which should be prefered from the point of view of the village industries programme?
('67', 355, 5, 24, 608415) (3) Is not the need for uplift work greater in the British Indian village?
('67', 355, 5, 25, 608490) (4) If the answer to 3 is in the affirmative, why should not all workers go to the British Indian villages?
('67', 355, 5, 26, 608598) (5) Would not the Congress give any definite direction in the matter?
('67', 355, 5, 27, 608668) (6) What standard of living should be adopted by the village worker?
('67', 355, 5, 28, 608737) The villagers standard is far too low to be acceptable to the workers.
('67', 355, 5, 29, 608808) You do not taboo milk and fruit for village workers.
('67', 355, 5, 30, 608861) But villagers never get these things.
('67', 355, 5, 31, 608899) How can a village worker conscientiously take them?
('67', 355, 5, 32, 608951) (7) It is a fact that millions are starving.
('67', 355, 5, 33, 608996) If we too follow suit, how are we to do work for them?
('67', 355, 5, 34, 609051) And yet in a family a brother would share his loaf with a brother rather than let him starve.
('67', 355, 5, 35, 609145) (8) What are the minimum necessaries of life?”
('67', 356, 0, 1, 609192) VOL. 67 : 25 APRIL, 1935 22 SEPTEMBER, 1935 357
('67', 356, 1, 2, 609240) 6 8. The main thing to be borne in mind by the village worker is that he is in the village for the villagers’ service, and it is his right and his duty to allow himself such articles of diet and other necessaries as would keep him fit and enable him to fulfil his function.
('67', 356, 1, 3, 609514) This will necessarily involve the acceptance of a higher standard of living by the village worker, but I have an impression that the villagers do not grudge the worker these necessary things.
('67', 356, 1, 4, 609706) The worker’s conscience is the test.
('67', 356, 1, 5, 609743) He must be self restrained, he will eat nothing in order to indulge his palate, he will go in for no luxuries, and will fill all his waking hours with work of service.
('67', 356, 1, 6, 609911) In spite of this, it is likely that a handful of people will cavil at his mode of life.
('67', 356, 1, 7, 609999) We have to live that criticism down.
('67', 356, 1, 8, 610036) The diet I have suggested is not quite unobtainable in a village, with a certain amount of labour.
('67', 356, 1, 9, 610135) Milk can generally be obtained, and there are numerous fruits, e.g., ber, karamda, mhora flower, which are easily available, but which we count of no value because they are so easily available.
('67', 356, 1, 10, 610329) There are all kinds of leaves available which grow wild in ourvillages, which we do not use because of sheer ignorance or laziness (if not snobbery).
('67', 356, 1, 11, 610479) I am myself using numerous varieties of these green leaves which I had never tried before, but which I find I should have used.
('67', 356, 1, 12, 610607) It is quite possible to make a cow in a village pay for her upkeep and maintenance.
('67', 356, 1, 13, 610691) I have not tried the experiment but I think it should be possible.
('67', 356, 1, 14, 610758) I have also an impression that it is not impossible for the villagers to obtain and live on the same articles of diet as the village workers and thus to adopt the same standard of life.
('67', 356, 2, 15, 610944) Harijan, 24 8 1935
('67', 356, 3, 16, 610963) 557. SELF SUFFICING KHADI
('67', 356, 4, 17, 610989) From Madhopur centre in Bihar comes the news that in ten villages nineteen persons have had their yarn woven into khadi measuring 166 1 2 yards for personal use and that 82 persons in 22 villages had their yarn exchanged for khadi measuring 709 yards.
('67', 356, 4, 18, 611241) This is good news.
('67', 356, 4, 19, 611260) Good news of distribution of seeds and sowing them for growing cotton for self spinning comes from Payyanur and Nileshwar in Malabar.
('67', 356, 4, 20, 611394) When cotton growing for self spinning becomes universal
('67', 357, 0, 1, 611450) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 358
('67', 357, 1, 2, 611492) in the country, people can have their khadi for the mere labour spent upon it during leisure hours if the home growers of cotton will learn all the processes as they do in Assam for silk in many homes.
('67', 357, 1, 3, 611694) Silk connot be universalized.
('67', 357, 1, 4, 611724) Cotton can and almost was at one time.
('67', 357, 1, 5, 611763) This method means a most substantial addition to the national income and a perfect scheme of employment for the millions of the partially unemployed in this country.
('67', 357, 1, 6, 611929) Though the proposition is thus simple to state, it is undoubtedly very difficult to work.
('67', 357, 1, 7, 612019) But it is in no way impossible.
('67', 357, 1, 8, 612051) It needs no great outlay of capital.
('67', 357, 1, 9, 612088) The processes to be learnt are simple, the tools required are all ready in the villages or can be quickly made.
('67', 357, 1, 10, 612200) The greatest stumbling block is the disinclination of the people to work at new things and to exert intelligence.
('67', 357, 1, 11, 612314) Generations of enforced idleness and consequent starvation have led to loss of hope, stamina and even the will to live.
('67', 357, 1, 12, 612434) No greater calamity can befall a people than that they should lose hope even to the extent of the will to live.
('67', 357, 1, 13, 612546) But those who have not lost hope have to work with greater zeal than ever before with an unquenchable faith in their mission.
('67', 357, 1, 14, 612672) Their faith will certainly overcomemountains.
('67', 357, 1, 15, 612718) In this glorious country, where sufficient food and clothing can be produced without much labour and skill, there need never be any loss of hope.
('67', 357, 1, 16, 612864) But hope has to be translated into progressive action based on ever increasing knowledge of the science of khadi.
('67', 357, 1, 17, 612978) Workers have to respond to the lead that the Centre may give from time to time, and they have also to anticipate the objections of the villagers whom they have to serve.
('67', 357, 1, 18, 613148) For that purpose they have to come into closest touch and trust.
('67', 357, 1, 19, 613213) They may never appear before the villagers as patrons but they should appear as voluntary servants who have hitherto neglected their trust.
('67', 357, 1, 20, 613353) Given a due fulfilment of this primary indispensable condition, the rest will follow as night follows day.
('67', 357, 2, 21, 613460) Harijan, 24 8 1935

('67', 364, 4, 14, 623729) 570. PRIZE ESSAY ON BARTER SYSTEM
('67', 364, 5, 15, 623763) WARDHA, August 26, 1935 Shri Uppulur Venkatakrishnayya is the trustee of the Khaddar Samsthanam which was started in the year 1927 at Gunadala near Bezwada.
('67', 364, 5, 16, 623920) He is an ardent believer in the system of barter, and has been practising it to some extent in his institution in its internal and external dealings, especially with reference to the production and distribution of food and clothing.
('67', 364, 5, 17, 624153) He believes it to be the only remedy for the present economic depression and thinks that it can solve the many evils arising from the present monetary system.
('67', 364, 5, 18, 624312) He further believes that the adoption of barter is essential to the development of agriculture, revival of khadi and other handicrafts and cottage industries in India, and the propagation and practice of the doctrine of non violence.
('67', 364, 5, 19, 624546) He holds that it is implied in non violence itself.
('67', 364, 5, 20, 624598) He fervently desires to know how far his views can stand the test of a scientific study and examination of the system.
('67', 364, 5, 21, 624717) He therefore offers a prize for the best essay on the subject, and he has chosen me as his instrument for
('67', 364, 6, 22, 624823) 1 Addressee’s son
('67', 365, 0, 1, 624841) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 366
('67', 365, 1, 2, 624883) announcing his intention.
('67', 365, 1, 3, 624909) I have gladly consented to be the medium for inviting essays on the system of barter.
('67', 365, 1, 4, 624995) The prize winner will be given at his choice Rs. 500 in cash or Rs. 500 worth of geniune, durable khadi woven in the Samsthanam itself.
('67', 365, 1, 5, 625131) The cash amount is deposited with me.
('67', 365, 1, 6, 625169) The essay (which should be in English) should trace the early history of the barter system, the causes of its decline, and the possibilities of its revival at present.
('67', 365, 1, 7, 625337) It should also describe the purpose it served in the past and the part it can play in the future economic life of the world, with particular reference to its adaptability to the Indian village life concerning some or all of the departments of its activities.
('67', 365, 1, 8, 625596) The essay should discuss the conditions congenial for its successful working and development and to what extent the assistance of the ruling power is required for the same, and should indicate the nature and mode of exchange if the adoption of the system is recommended.
('67', 365, 1, 9, 625867) The essay should also discuss the effects of the barter system on the development of the internal and international trade of India.
('67', 365, 1, 10, 625999) K. T. Shah, Shri Vaikunth L. Mehta and Prof.
('67', 365, 1, 11, 626044) J.C. Kumarappa have kindly consented to act as examiners.
('67', 365, 1, 12, 626102) Kumarappa will also act as Secretary to whom all essays should be sent addressed Maganwadi, Wardha.
('67', 365, 1, 13, 626202) The essays should reach Prof.
('67', 365, 1, 14, 626232) Kumarappa not later than the noon of August 31, 1936. No prize will be awarded if no essay reached the standard to be determined by the examiners.
('67', 365, 1, 15, 626379) The result of the examination will be announced not later than 31st December 1936. The copyright of the prize essay will vest in the Khaddar Samsthanam.
('67', 365, 1, 16, 626532) I do hope that there will be keen competition for winning the prize not for its monetary value but for the importance of the subject.
('67', 365, 2, 17, 626666) M. K. GANDHI
('67', 365, 3, 18, 626679) Harijan, 31 8 1935

('67', 376, 1, 2, 640922) 591. LETTER TO A VILLAGE WORKER 1
('67', 376, 2, 3, 640956) [Before August 31, 1935] If you can get good and clean cow’s ghee made there, you can certainly concentrate on the industry.
('67', 376, 2, 4, 641081) You must first ascertain whether it secures the ghee maker anything like a living wage.
('67', 376, 2, 5, 641169) We have to enter into the lives of our working classes, ascertain, what they eat and drink, where they live, and how they live, to what extent they are indebted, and so on and so forth.
('67', 376, 2, 6, 641355) You should thus be able to tell me the whole history of the sample of ghee you have sent me.
('67', 376, 2, 7, 641448) You must maintain in your shop a register containing all these details: (1) the name and place of the producer; (2) time taken for preparation; (3) quantity of milk from which ghee was prepared; (4) price of ghee; (5) wage earned by the producer per hour; (6) the middle man’s share and transit charges.
('67', 376, 2, 8, 641752) Every article that you stock and sell out of your depot must bear this history ticket and whoever purchases it has a right to ask for it.
('67', 376, 2, 9, 641890) You will not tell me that this is a tedious procedure and that you have not time for it.
('67', 376, 2, 10, 641979) When once the thing has got started, it will be a matter of routine and not much time will be required.
('67', 376, 2, 11, 642083) Whatever minimum wage may be fixed by the A.I.V.I.A., you will in no case pay less than half an anna per hour.
('67', 376, 2, 12, 642194) This is easily done.
('67', 376, 2, 13, 642215) Find out the number of hours taken up in the manufacture of an article, and then fix the wage and the price.
('67', 376, 2, 14, 642324) Thus, for instance, it takes an ordinary spinner one hour to spin 400 yards of yarn of 15 counts.
('67', 376, 2, 15, 642422) You will therefore pay half an anna as the wage for spinning 400 yards of 15 counts of strong, even yarn.
('67', 376, 3, 16, 642528) Harijan, 31 8 1935
('67', 376, 4, 17, 642547) 592. AN IMPORTANT RESOLUTION
('67', 376, 5, 18, 642576) After a full two days’ discussion the following resolution was unanimously passed by the A.I.V.I.A. Board at its periodical meeting last week:
('67', 376, 6, 19, 642719) 1 This is extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “Weekly Letter”.
('67', 376, 6, 20, 642777) The addressee had asked “if he could concentrate on ghee making as a supplementary industry to agriculture” and, if so, “how he should do it”.
('67', 376, 6, 21, 642920) Harijan, 19 10 1935, published an account of the addressee’s experience about procuring good ghee.
('67', 377, 0, 1, 643019) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 378
('67', 377, 1, 2, 643061) Whereas the object of the Association includes bringing about the moral and material advancement of the rural population by encouraging the revival of dead and dying industries, the Board of Management desire that, for all commodities produced or marketed under the aegis of the Association, each workman should receive a minimum wage calculated on the basis of eight hours’ efficient work sufficient at least for his (or her) maintenance in accordance with a scientifically prescribed scale of minimum food requirements; and it should be the duty of all connected with the Association to see that the workmen engaged in the industries promoted by them actually receive remuneration never less than the scale herein prescribed, always bearing in mind that as and when circumstances permit there should be a progressive rise in the scale so as to reach a standard enabling a worker’s family to be properly maintained out of the earnings of its working members.
('67', 377, 1, 3, 644021) If this resolution is honestly worked it must produce far reaching consequences.
('67', 377, 1, 4, 644102) It would render a measure of tardy justice to the working class, whether labourers or artisans.
('67', 377, 1, 5, 644198) To arrive at the correct figure in terms of money is going to prove a difficult task.
('67', 377, 1, 6, 644284) The members and agents will have to compile three kinds of tables: 1. How much do the workmen and work women earn per hour at their work in the different spheres in the different provinces?
('67', 377, 1, 7, 644474) 2. What is the daily diet of the workmen within their area of work and what is its cost?
('67', 377, 1, 8, 644563) 3. A scientific scale on a minimum basis prepared by experts in the respective provinces out of the local staples with the cost thereof.
('67', 377, 1, 9, 644700) What statistics I have received go to show that all over India, except in the Punjab, the articles of diet the masses live on are deficient in nutritive value.
('67', 377, 1, 10, 644860) The most helpful pamphlet on the minimum diet scale is the one prepared by Dr. H. V. Tilak, on behalf of the Bombay Presidency Baby and Health Week Association (Delisle Road, Bombay 11).
('67', 377, 1, 11, 645047) It is called Balanced Diets.
('67', 377, 1, 12, 645076) Its price is four annas.
('67', 377, 1, 13, 645101) It has been translated into Marathi and Gujarati.
('67', 377, 1, 14, 645151) The diet recommended by the pamphlet, containing a variety of whole grain (some of which is sprouted) including soya beans, dried skim milk and vegetables, increases a white rat to 55 grammes in weight from 13 grammes when fed on a diet containing an excess of highly polished rice with very little vegetables and milk.
('67', 377, 1, 15, 645471) The diet scale recommended in the pamphlet has been prepared after careful experimentation.
('67', 377, 1, 16, 645563) It costs in Bombay Rs. 5 per month.
('67', 377, 1, 17, 645599) I have my doubts about the possibility of introducing soya
('67', 378, 0, 1, 645658) VOL. 67 : 25 APRIL, 1935 22 SEPTEMBER, 1935 379
('67', 378, 1, 2, 645706) beans and dried skim milk in the poor man’s diet even in a place like Bombay.
('67', 378, 1, 3, 645784) The sprouting of pulses and malting of jowari recommended by Dr. Tilak is also very difficult of enforcement in private households.
('67', 378, 1, 4, 645916) It is almost impossible of introduction in villages.
('67', 378, 1, 5, 645969) Skim milk is unobtainable in the villages, and I know that in hundreds of them not a drop of fresh milk or good ghee is to be had.
('67', 378, 1, 6, 646100) I mention these difficulties in order that taking Dr. Tilak’s carefully prepared scale as a basis, experts may work out a scale more suited to the villages in their provinces and yet produce the results that Dr. Tilak’s diet is claimed to have achieved.
('67', 378, 1, 7, 646354) We may not be satisfied until the village workers have put the workmen coming under their influence in possession of means to procure an adequate diet for themselves and their dependants.
('67', 378, 1, 8, 646542) Reduction in price of articles must be a consideration that must always be subordinated to the ability of workmen engaged in their production to earn a living wage for themselves.
('67', 378, 1, 9, 646722) We must rule out the question of competition with machine made articles whether foreign or indigenous.
('67', 378, 1, 10, 646825) Millions of workmen must not live on the margin of starvation so that the few engaged in production by powerdriven machinery may have more than they need.
('67', 378, 1, 11, 646980) In the absence of State protection public opinion should be so cultivated that it will refuse to exploit the toilers of the land.
('67', 378, 1, 12, 647110) Let khadi workers who are engaged in producing khadi for sale note that what applies to the other village industries applies equally to khadi produced for sale.
('67', 378, 1, 13, 647271) From the spinner to the weaver all the khadi working men should have the wage contemplated in the resolution under discussion.
('67', 378, 1, 14, 647398) Harijan, 31 8 1935
('67', 378, 2, 15, 647417) 593. OUR DUTY
('67', 378, 3, 16, 647431) Perhaps the burden of untouchability falls on Harijans in one way nowhere so heavily as in Gujarat.
('67', 378, 3, 17, 647531) In Dholka a Harijan was done to death by a savarna Hindu and the murderer escaped with a fine of Rs. 300. In Kavitha the so called Rajputs mercilessly attacked helpless Harijans for daring to send their children to a public school.
('67', 378, 3, 18, 647763) In Kathiawar just now in various villages in its various provinces savarnas persecute Harijans because a plague has broken out among the cattle.
('67', 378, 3, 19, 647908) They do so under the superstitious belief that the disease is caused owing to the incantations or some other machinations of Harijans.
('67', 379, 0, 1, 648043) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 380
('67', 379, 1, 2, 648085) Harijan is in perpetual fear of injury to his person or property.
('67', 379, 1, 3, 648151) The reformer feels helpless; the State is indifferent or is itself also helpless in the face of the powerful savarnas.
('67', 379, 1, 4, 648270) The reason is obvious.
('67', 379, 1, 5, 648293) The Harijan does not know how to secure redress.
('67', 379, 1, 6, 648342) He has no will to defend himself.
('67', 379, 1, 7, 648376) He is wholly unconscious of his human dignity or innate ability to protect himself against the insolence of fellow human beings.
('67', 379, 1, 8, 648505) The reformer has to carry the torch of knowledge among the persecutors, for they know not what they are doing.
('67', 379, 1, 9, 648616) Leaflets may be distributed among them.
('67', 379, 1, 10, 648656) But the savarna lynchers rarely read newspapers or leaflets.
('67', 379, 1, 11, 648717) They are self contained and self satisfied.
('67', 379, 1, 12, 648761) Personal contact is the only way of approach to them.
('67', 379, 1, 13, 648815) They must be visited if need be in their own homes.
('67', 379, 1, 14, 648867) Meetings should be addressed in their villages.
('67', 379, 1, 15, 648915) No amount of anger or declamation will cure them of their ignorance.
('67', 379, 1, 16, 648984) The quickest way to combat ignorance is the spread of the knowledge that would tell them how cattle diseases are contracted and how by careful treatment they may be prevented or cured.
('67', 379, 1, 17, 649169) All this means patient labour on the part of those who will carry on the propaganda.
('67', 379, 1, 18, 649254) The States concerned should also be moved to protectthe poor Harijans who are molested.
('67', 379, 1, 19, 649342) Where the reformers are fairly numerous they may have to settle in the midst of Harijans and themselves share their hardships, if their presence does not prevent molestation.
('67', 379, 1, 20, 649517) In this campaign against ignorance the sanatanists’ assistance should also be invoked.
('67', 379, 1, 21, 649604) I am sure no sane sanatanist will defend the cruel persecution of the utterly innocent Harijans by ignorant, misguided savarnas.
('67', 379, 2, 22, 649733) Harijan, 31 8 1935

('67', 388, 4, 15, 665217) The undertakings with which I am connected are so vast in their scope that they can absorb fortunes.
('67', 388, 4, 16, 665318) That they have never yet done so is because I have never allowed them to go out of hand.
('67', 388, 4, 17, 665407) And there is protection from within as there is little chance of personal gain.
('67', 388, 4, 18, 665487) All I want therefore is your great ability, constancy and purity dedicated to the service of the lowliest and the downtrodden.
('67', 388, 4, 19, 665614) That, thank God, I already have.

('67', 388, 4, 25, 665844) I fear however that he must have missed him by a few hours.

('67', 391, 0, 1, 668408) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 392
('67', 391, 1, 2, 668450) 611. DISCUSSION WITH SWAMI YOGANANDA 1
('67', 391, 2, 3, 668489) [Before September 7, 1935] 2
('67', 391, 3, 4, 668518) GANDHIJI: Why is there evil in the world, is a difficult question to answer.
('67', 391, 3, 5, 668595) I can only give what I may call a villager’s answer.
('67', 391, 3, 6, 668648) If there is good there must also be evil, just as where there is light there is also darkness, but it is true only so far as we human mortals are concerned.
('67', 391, 3, 7, 668805) Before God there is nothing good, nothing evil.
('67', 391, 3, 8, 668853) We poor villagers may talk of His dispensation in human terms, but our language is not God’s.
('67', 391, 3, 9, 668947) The Vedanta says the world is maya.
('67', 391, 3, 10, 668983) Even that explanation is a babbling of imperfect humanity.
('67', 391, 3, 11, 669042) I therefore say that I am not going to bother my head about it.
('67', 391, 3, 12, 669106) Even if I was allowed to peep into the innermost recess of God’s chamber I should not care to do it.
('67', 391, 3, 13, 669207) For I should not know what to do there.
('67', 391, 3, 14, 669247) It is enough for our spiritual growth to know that God is always with the doer of good.
('67', 391, 3, 15, 669335) That again is a villager’s explanation.
('67', 391, 4, 16, 669375) YOGANANDA: But if He is All mighty, as unquestionably He is, why does He not free us from evil?
('67', 391, 4, 17, 669471) I would rule out this question, too.
('67', 391, 4, 18, 669508) God and we are not equals.
('67', 391, 4, 19, 669535) Equals may put such questions to one another, but not unequals.Villagers do not ask why town dwellers do things which if they did would mean certain destruction.
('67', 391, 5, 20, 669697) I quite see what you mean.
('67', 391, 5, 21, 669724) It is a strong point you have made.
('67', 391, 5, 22, 669760) But who made God?
('67', 391, 5, 23, 669778) If He is All powerful, He must have made Himself.
('67', 391, 6, 24, 669828) Do you think He is an autocrat or a democrat?
('67', 391, 6, 25, 669874) I do not think these things at all.
('67', 391, 6, 26, 669910) I do not want to divide the power with Him and hence I am absolved from having to consider these questions.
('67', 391, 6, 27, 670018) I am content with the doing of the task in front of me.
('67', 391, 6, 28, 670074) I do not worry about the why and wherefore of things.
('67', 391, 7, 29, 670128) But has He not given us reason?
('67', 391, 8, 30, 670160) 1 This is extracted from “Weekly Letter” by Mahadev Desai, who had reported that Swami Yogananda had “just returned home after a long stay in America”.
('67', 391, 8, 31, 670312) On his way to Ranchi, he halted at Wardha to meet Gandhiji.
('67', 391, 8, 32, 670372) 2 According to Gandhi—1915 1948: A Detailed Chronology, the discussion took place on August 26 and 27.
('67', 392, 0, 1, 670475) VOL. 67 : 25 APRIL, 1935 22 SEPTEMBER, 1935 393
('67', 392, 1, 2, 670523) Indeed He has.
('67', 392, 1, 3, 670538) But that reason helps us to see that we should not dabble in things we cannot fathom.
('67', 392, 1, 4, 670624) It is my implicit belief that a true villager has an amazing amount of common sense and therefore he never worries about these things.
('67', 392, 2, 5, 670759) Then I will now ask a different question.
('67', 392, 2, 6, 670801) Do you believe it is easier to be evil
('67', 392, 3, 7, 670840) than good, that a descent is easier than an ascent?
('67', 392, 3, 8, 670892) Apparently it is so.
('67', 392, 3, 9, 670913) But really it is easier to be good than to be evil.
('67', 392, 3, 10, 670965) Of course poets have said that descent to hell is easy, but I do not think so.
('67', 392, 3, 11, 671044) Nor do I think there are more bad people in the world than good.
('67', 392, 3, 12, 671109) In that case God himself would be evil and not an embodiment of ahimsa or love which He is.
('67', 392, 4, 13, 671201) May I know your definition of ahimsa?
('67', 392, 4, 14, 671239) Ahimsa means avoiding injury to anything on earth, in thought, word and deed .
('67', 392, 5, 15, 671318) I shall now change the subject.
('67', 392, 5, 16, 671350) You would prefer self control to birth control?
('67', 392, 5, 17, 671398) I think artificial birth control or birth control according to methods suggested today and recommended in the West is suicidal.
('67', 392, 5, 18, 671526) When I say ‘suicidal’, I do not mean resulting in the extinction of the race, I mean suicidal in a higher sense of the term, that is to say these methods make man lower than the brute; they are immoral.
('67', 392, 6, 19, 671729) But how long are we to tolerate indiscriminate procreation?
('67', 392, 6, 20, 671789) I know a man who
('67', 392, 7, 21, 671806) used to purchase a seer of milk, and went on diluting it with water in order to divide it
('67', 392, 8, 22, 671896) between his children whose number increased every year.
('67', 392, 8, 23, 671952) Don’t you think this was a
('67', 392, 9, 24, 671979) It is a sin to bring forth unwanted children, but I think it is a greater sin to avoid the consequences of one’s own action.
('67', 392, 9, 25, 672104) It simply unmans man.
('67', 392, 10, 26, 672126) What then is the most practical method of telling man this truth?
('67', 392, 10, 27, 672192) The most practical method is to live the life of self control.
('67', 392, 10, 28, 672255) Example is better than precept.
('67', 392, 11, 29, 672287) But the West asks us, “Why is it that you have greater child mortality and
('67', 392, 12, 30, 672362) lower life average than we, though you regard yourselves as more spiritual than the
('67', 392, 13, 31, 672446) West?” Do you believe in many children, Mahatmaji?
('67', 392, 13, 32, 672497) I believe in no children.
('67', 392, 14, 33, 672523) Then the whole race will be extinct.
('67', 393, 0, 1, 672560) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 394
('67', 393, 1, 2, 672602) It won't be extinct, it will be transformed into something better.
('67', 393, 1, 3, 672669) But it can never happen, for we have inherited from eternity the sex instinct from our progenitors.
('67', 393, 1, 4, 672769) It means a tremendous effort to check this habit of ages, and yet it is a simple effort.
('67', 393, 1, 5, 672858) Absolute renunciation, absolute brahmacharya is the ideal state.
('67', 393, 1, 6, 672923) If you dare not think of it marry by all means, but even then live a life of self control.
('67', 393, 2, 7, 673014) Have you any working method to teach this to the masses?
('67', 393, 2, 8, 673071) It is, as I said a moment ago, to attain complete self control and go and live that life amongst the masses.
('67', 393, 2, 9, 673180) A life of self restraint and denial of all luxuries cannot but have its effect on the masses.
('67', 393, 2, 10, 673274) There is an indissoluble connection between self control and the control of the palate.
('67', 393, 2, 11, 673362) The man who observes brahmacharya will be controlled in every one of his acts and will be humble.
('67', 393, 3, 12, 673460) I see what you mean.
('67', 393, 3, 13, 673481) The masses do not know the happiness of self control
('67', 393, 4, 14, 673534) and we have to teach them that.
('67', 393, 4, 15, 673566) But what about the argument of the West I referred to
('67', 393, 5, 16, 673620) before?
('67', 393, 5, 17, 673628) I do not think that we are more spiritually minded than the West.
('67', 393, 5, 18, 673694) If we were, we should not have fallen so low.
('67', 393, 5, 19, 673740) But because the average life of a Westerner is much higher than ours, it does not prove the spirituality of the West.
('67', 393, 5, 20, 673858) Whoever is spiritually minded must show a better, not necessarily longer, life.
('67', 393, 6, 21, 673938) Harijan, 7 9 1935
('67', 393, 7, 22, 673956) 612. HARIJAN SEVAK SANGH RESOLUTIONS
('67', 393, 8, 23, 673993) The meeting of the Executive of the Harijan Sevak Sangh Board held from 30th August to 2nd September passed several important resolutons.
('67', 393, 8, 24, 674131) The following is one of them:
('67', 393, 9, 25, 674161) The question of decentralizing the finance and administration of the Sangh was discussed, in the presence of Sjt.
('67', 393, 9, 26, 674275) J. N. Kunzru, who was specially invited to attend this meeting of the Committee; the position with regard to U. P. (East) and the representations from the other provinces were considered.
('67', 393, 9, 27, 674463) At the end of the discussion Pandit Kunzru was requested to frame a separate scheme for U.P. (East) in consultation with his Provincial Board and District Committees by way of experiment and to submit it for consideration at the next meeting of the Executive Committee.
('67', 393, 10, 28, 674733) Another important resolution passed was the following:
('67', 394, 0, 1, 674788) VOL. 67 : 25 APRIL, 1935 22 SEPTEMBER, 1935 395
('67', 394, 1, 2, 674836) Resolved that the [24th] 1 of September 1935, the day on which the Poona Pact was signed, be celebrated as the ‘Harijan Day’ in accordance with instructions issued in that behalf by the Head Office, Delhi.
('67', 394, 1, 3, 675042) It is to be hoped that Harijan workers throughout India will make a special effort to establish closer contact with Harijans and that there will be an all round greater self dedication.
('67', 394, 1, 4, 675228) The third resolution of importance runs:
('67', 394, 2, 5, 675269) Resolved that efforts be made for the co ordination of the activities of the Charkha, Gram Udyog and Harijan Sevak Sanghs, and to secure that purpose it is suggested that a joint committee, consisting of the Secretaries of these sister organizatons, be created after getting constitutional recognition from the Charkha and Gram Udyog Sanghs.
('67', 394, 2, 6, 675611) Seeing that all the three activities are constructive and meet at many points, much time, energy and money can be saved and the work of the three organizations advanced if there is greater co ordination among workers wherever it is possible and desirable.
('67', 394, 3, 7, 675867) Harijan, 7 9 1935
('67', 394, 4, 8, 675885) 613. PRIVATE PRODUCERS BEWARE
('67', 394, 5, 9, 675915) Whilst the new policy of giving an adequate wage to the spinners and others working at the manufacture of khadi is taking shape, the question of certified private producers of khadi comes up for serious consideration.
('67', 394, 5, 10, 676133) They are responsible for a large quantity of khadi.
('67', 394, 5, 11, 676185) The Association has a duty towards these no less than towards the wage earners.
('67', 394, 5, 12, 676265) The contracts made with them must be duly fulfilled.
('67', 394, 5, 13, 676318) But the duty ends there.
('67', 394, 5, 14, 676343) The whole organization of the Spinners’ Association is or should be run as a trust for the spinners whose lot must be progressively improved.
('67', 394, 5, 15, 676485) Private producers are certified primarily for the benefit of the spinners.
('67', 394, 5, 16, 676560) They should get their profit through the service of the latter, not at their expense, as we discover, they and others are doing.
('67', 394, 5, 17, 676689) But certificates issued to them need not be withdrawn if they will put themselves on a par with the direct agents of the Associaton.
('67', 394, 5, 18, 676822) But they will have to radically revise their method of work if they will do so.
('67', 394, 5, 19, 676902) They will have even to suffer loss.
('67', 394, 5, 20, 676938) They have to maintain in accordance with the requirements of the Association registers of the
('67', 394, 6, 21, 677032) 1 The source has.
('67', 394, 6, 22, 677050) “25th” which was subsequently corrected by Gandhiji; vide “Notes”, 14 9 1935 and 21 9 1935.
('67', 395, 0, 1, 677142) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 396
('67', 395, 1, 2, 677184) spinners and other wage earners served by them.
('67', 395, 1, 3, 677232) They have to produce proof of payment of wages, collect and supply satistics regarding them.
('67', 395, 1, 4, 677325) This may be too onerous for them.
('67', 395, 1, 5, 677359) The risk entailed by the probable increase in the price of khadi may be too great to be borne by them.
('67', 395, 1, 6, 677462) The requirements of the Association may be too exacting for producers who have undoubtedly to work hard for making the profits they do.
('67', 395, 1, 7, 677598) Those who feel so, should from now begin to wind up their khadi business.
('67', 395, 1, 8, 677672) Those who wish to continue to do khadi work, should put themselves in touch with the agents of the Association.
('67', 395, 1, 9, 677784) Only they should know that the slightest neglect in the observance of the conditions will entail cancellation of certificates.
('67', 395, 1, 10, 677911) Loss or no loss, strictest honesty is the essential condition of continuation of their contract with the Association.
('67', 395, 1, 11, 678029) Only those therefore should continue who are lovers of khadi and devotees of Daridranarayana for whose sake they will not mind losses.
('67', 395, 1, 12, 678164) Those who are themselves not users of khadi in their own persons and homes need not entertain any hope of continuing the contract.
('67', 395, 2, 13, 678295) Harijan, 7 9 1935
('67', 395, 3, 14, 678313) 614. LEPROSY AND ITS PREVENTION
('67', 395, 4, 15, 678345) Savli is one of the hives of khadi workers who are living in the midst of poor spinners and weavers.
('67', 395, 4, 16, 678446) Leprosy is rampant in Savli.
('67', 395, 4, 17, 678475) It is no wonder when these toilers have to slave to eke out a bare living, spinners getting no more than two pies at the most per hour.
('67', 395, 4, 18, 678611) Their average bill of fare is one rupee per month.
('67', 395, 4, 19, 678662) The workers inquire how they are to deal with the lepers, who mix with everyone without let or hindrance.
('67', 395, 4, 20, 678768) Many of them work for their living or help their relatives.
('67', 395, 4, 21, 678828) What is to be done with their manufacture?
('67', 395, 4, 22, 678871) How are they to serve these unfortunate countrymen?
('67', 395, 4, 23, 678923) The Indian Council of the British Empire Leprosy Relief Assocition has published a booklet called Leprosy Diagnosis, Treatment and Prevention.
('67', 395, 4, 24, 679066) It is running its fifth edition.
('67', 395, 4, 25, 679099) The author is Dr. Muir, M.D.I quote freely from the chapter on Preventon.
('67', 395, 5, 26, 679173) Harijan, 7 9 1935
('67', 395, 6, 27, 679191) 1 The extracts are not reproduced here.

('67', 399, 1, 2, 683690) 621. LETTER TO P. KODANDA RAO
('67', 399, 2, 3, 683720) WARDHA, September 10, 1935 DEAR KODANDA RAO,
('67', 399, 3, 4, 683765) The statement that I had derived my idea of civil disobedience from the writings of Thoreau is wrong.
('67', 399, 3, 5, 683867) The resistance to authority in South Africa was well advanced before I got the essay of Thoreau on civil disobedience.
('67', 399, 3, 6, 683986) 1 But the movement was then known as passive resistance.
('67', 399, 3, 7, 684043) As it was incomplete I had coined the word satyagraha for the Gujarati readers.
('67', 399, 3, 8, 684123) When I saw the title of Thoreau’s great essay, I began the use of his phrase to explain our struggle to the English readers.
('67', 399, 3, 9, 684248) But I found that even civil disobedience failed to convey the full meaning of the struggle.
('67', 399, 3, 10, 684340) I therefore adopted the phrase civil resistance.
('67', 399, 3, 11, 684389) Non violence was always an integral part of our struggle.
('67', 399, 3, 12, 684447) As per your advice, a copy is going to Mr. Pearson.
('67', 399, 3, 13, 684499) I hope you have done well.
('67', 399, 3, 14, 684526) Mahadev is in Bombay just now.
('67', 399, 4, 15, 684557) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI SJT.
('67', 399, 4, 16, 684592) KODANDA RAO 2
('67', 399, 5, 17, 684606) From a photostat: G.N. 6280; also Gandhi and the American Scene, pp.

('67', 402, 0, 1, 689246) VOL. 67 : 25 APRIL, 1935 22 SEPTEMBER, 1935 403
('67', 402, 1, 2, 689294) The theory about man having descended from the ape does not convince me.
('67', 402, 1, 3, 689367) There is no doubt, however, that the soul which lives in the human body now has lived in the bodies of an ape and other animals in the past.
('67', 402, 1, 4, 689508) I do not like the argument that the atatayi 1 may be killed.
('67', 402, 1, 5, 689569) Who should be regarded as an atatayi?
('67', 402, 1, 6, 689607) For the present I do believe that murderers and other criminals will have to be imprisoned.
('67', 402, 1, 7, 689699) But I do not remember even having said that that is ahimsa.
('67', 402, 1, 8, 689759) I certainly do not believe that it is.
('67', 402, 1, 9, 689798) I have said that in the existing circumstances such action may be unavoidable.
('67', 402, 1, 10, 689877) This only means that my ahimsa is still far from perfect and that, therefore, I have not yet been able to discover a remedy for this kind of violence.
('67', 402, 1, 11, 690028) Truth lies in recognizing a fall from an ideal as what it is.
('67', 402, 1, 12, 690090) If we win power by any means other than ahimsa, the swaraj will most certainly not be the swaraj of the poor.
('67', 402, 1, 13, 690200) They will profit only in proportion to the degree of ahimsa we observe in winning swaraj.
('67', 402, 1, 14, 690290) Perfect ahimsa neither you nor I nor anybody else can claim.
('67', 402, 1, 15, 690351) But one who believes in ahimsa will become more and more non violent day by day and in consequence his field of service will keep ever expanding.
('67', 402, 1, 16, 690497) The field of service of the votary of violence will become narrower day by day and will ultimately become restricted to himself.

('67', 405, 3, 4, 694154) BHAI DILKHUSH,
('67', 405, 4, 5, 694169) Only today I have been able to read the question you have sent to Kishorelal.
('67', 405, 4, 6, 694247) The questions are good.
('67', 405, 4, 7, 694271) In fixing the wages for spinning by the poor students who spin for their own needs, you may make them as high or as low as you like.
('67', 405, 4, 8, 694404) If the khadi so spun is more than what they need, you can adopt the rate prevailing in any [khadi] association.
('67', 405, 4, 9, 694516) If it is sold in the market, it should be sold so as to help khadi sales.
('67', 405, 4, 10, 694590) If the spinning activity is merely [part time] for buying condiments or pan and bidis, the wages can be fixed quite low.
('67', 405, 4, 11, 694711) But if it is [a whole time activity] for buying ghee and milk, the rate of wage for an hour’s spinning should be sufficiently high to meet one’s needs.
('67', 405, 4, 12, 694863) You may consider this a new theory, but according to me it is not.
('67', 405, 4, 13, 694930) It can be inferred from what I have written earlier.
('67', 405, 4, 14, 694983) So it is not a new theory and can be deduced logically from what has been stated as a premise.
('67', 405, 4, 15, 695078) Experience shows that thousands of women earn their livelihood from spinning.
('67', 405, 4, 16, 695156) When the question of fixing their wages came up, I had to say that they should at least be able to maintain themselves with that.
('67', 405, 4, 17, 695286) Or we should show them some occupation by which they can do so.
('67', 405, 4, 18, 695350) I think thiscovers answers to all your questions.
('67', 405, 4, 19, 695400) If not, by all means ask me again.

('67', 407, 1, 2, 697080) 632. LETTER TO BRIJKRISHNA CHANDIWALA
('67', 407, 2, 3, 697118) WARDHA, September 12/ [13] 1, 1935
('67', 407, 3, 4, 697153) BRIJKRISHNA,
('67', 407, 4, 5, 697166) Your letter.
('67', 407, 4, 6, 697179) Your suggestion that the expenses should be reduced is quite pertinent.
('67', 407, 4, 7, 697251) Let Krishnan Nair remain in Calcutta for a year.
('67', 407, 4, 8, 697300) In the mean time you and Hardhyan Singh can do what you can.
('67', 407, 4, 9, 697361) Any enterprise that depends solely on one person is bound to break down ultimately, and how long can you keep Krishnan Nair in Delhi?
('67', 407, 4, 10, 697495) This time I chanced to notice the secret hatred K.N. bears towards the rich.
('67', 407, 4, 11, 697572) He too realized that his heart has yet to digest it.
('67', 407, 4, 12, 697625) What you write is quite correct.
('67', 407, 4, 13, 697658) His stay in Bengal should prove beneficial.
('67', 407, 4, 14, 697702) Gradually he will acquire mastery over everything.
('67', 407, 4, 15, 697753) Meanwhile the other Ashram inmates too will have been tested.
('67', 407, 4, 16, 697815) Only those can be defined as Ashram inmates who have no financial or any other kind of obligations towards parents and other relatives, whose wants comprise only food and clothing and who are ever alert in the observance of ahimsa and the other eleven vows.
('67', 407, 4, 17, 698073) That is why one who is inclined to put aside even the smallest amount is disqualified as an Ashram inmate.
('67', 407, 4, 18, 698180) Keeping this in view no one should be paid more than Rs. 10 and moreover anything saved over andabove food, etc., should be returned to the Ashram.
('67', 407, 4, 19, 698328) But we can employ on a salary those whose services are needed and who in spite of their spirit of service cannot, owing to their other obligations, work except on a higher remuneration.
('67', 407, 4, 20, 698514) We should strictly limit our expenditure in accordance with the sums available in the budget.
('67', 407, 4, 21, 698608) You can circulate this to all the workers currently employed.
('67', 407, 4, 22, 698670) This will shift the responsibility from your head and have the desired effect.
('67', 407, 4, 23, 698749) My health is satisfactory.
('67', 407, 4, 24, 698776) The diet consists of milk, vegetables and occasionally fruit.
('67', 407, 4, 25, 698838) Part of this letter has been written by me and the rest dictated, with many interruptions in between.
('67', 407, 4, 26, 698940) In the mean while Rajaji arrived yesterday and informed me of your having fallen ill; how is it?

('67', 409, 4, 14, 701727) 635. DISCUSSION ON MINIMUM LIVING WAGE–II 2
('67', 409, 5, 15, 701771) [Before September 14, 1935]
('67', 409, 6, 16, 701799) Our objective is as the name implies to represent the spinners who are the lowest paid labourers, i.e., to improve their lot.
('67', 409, 6, 17, 701925) Therefore we have to show a progressive improvement in their lot.
('67', 409, 6, 18, 701991) You must remember my earliest formula which holds good as much today as it did then—a spinning wheel in every home and a loom or looms in every village.
('67', 409, 6, 19, 702144) That is the ideal of self sufficing khadi, and if I could take you with me I would have you serve the spinners not so much by selling their khadi as by making them prepare it for their own use.
('67', 409, 7, 20, 702338) 1 The name is omitted in the source 2 This is extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “Weekly Letter” which gave the following summary of arguments by khadi workers : “(1) It is wrong to say that we are exploiting the poor spinners.
('67', 409, 7, 21, 702562) On the contrary, the consumers who can easily purchase cheap Japanese and other foreign stuffs, go in for khadi which is dearer.
('67', 409, 7, 22, 702691) This is patriotism and not exploitation.
('67', 409, 7, 23, 702732) (2) The minimum wage may mean a few more coppers in the pocket of a very few, but what about the thousands who will find their occupation gone?
('67', 409, 7, 24, 702876) (3) The spinners themselves would far rather prefer a permanent small wage than a precarious higher minimum wage.
('67', 409, 7, 25, 702990) If a referendum were to be taken, they would cast their vote against the minimum wage.
('67', 409, 7, 26, 703077) (4) We have not reduced the spinners’ wage; the reductions in our prices are due to the fall in the price of cotton, and reduction in the weavers’ wages.
('67', 409, 7, 27, 703231) (5) It would have been possible to do something when the political situation was favourable, but at the present moment it is hardly the atmosphere.”
('67', 410, 0, 1, 703380) VOL. 67 : 25 APRIL, 1935 22 SEPTEMBER, 1935 411
('67', 410, 1, 2, 703428) make our own chapatis, there are no hotels in villages; in the same way all villagers should make their own khadi.
('67', 410, 1, 3, 703543) Not that some of them will not make extra khadi but that will depend only on the demand.
('67', 410, 1, 4, 703632) We shall certainly take orders from the city people who will want our khadi, and we shall get that khadi done by those who will get a wage per hour proportionate to their daily need.
('67', 410, 1, 5, 703815) This may mean a temporary rise in the present price of khadi.
('67', 410, 1, 6, 703877) We may no longer exploit the poverty of the people.
('67', 410, 1, 7, 703929) I have never said it was deliberate exploitation.
('67', 410, 1, 8, 703979) I take the fullest responsibility for allwe have done during the past fifteen years, and what we have done was inevitable.
('67', 410, 1, 9, 704102) But we have now to strike a new departure.
('67', 410, 1, 10, 704145) We have ignored the proletariat for centuries, and whilst we have arrogated to ourselves the right of commanding their labour, the thought has never crossed us that they have a right to dictate their wage, that labour is as much their capital as money is ours.
('67', 410, 1, 11, 704406) It is time we began to think in terms of their needs, their hours of work and leisure and their standard of living.
('67', 410, 1, 12, 704522) It is idle to argue that the spinners themselves would plump for a smaller wage for all than a higher wage for a few.
('67', 410, 1, 13, 704640) That is the argument of every exploiter and slave owner, and indeed there were unfortunate folks amongst slaves who hugged the chains of slavery.
('67', 410, 1, 14, 704786) But why should you fear that the majority of them will find their occupation gone?
('67', 410, 1, 15, 704869) Haven’t we other occupations to recommend them?
('67', 410, 1, 16, 704917) In Andhra, Sitarama Sastry has not hesitated to encourage them to prefer paddy husking to spinning as the former gives a better wage.
('67', 410, 1, 17, 705051) Let us not deceive ourselves.
('67', 410, 1, 18, 705081) We have made their necessity our opportunity, and have never looked at the question from their point of view.
('67', 410, 2, 19, 705191) Satisbabu had a fear that the minimum wage would open the door of fraudulent transactions.
('67', 410, 2, 20, 705282) That fear, said Gandhiji, was always there.
('67', 410, 2, 21, 705326) Without the minimum wage, had we not that trouble already?
('67', 410, 2, 22, 705385) That was a problem which had to be independently dealt with.
('67', 410, 2, 23, 705446) Gandhiji entirely agreed that the atmosphere of competition must disappear, and he was sure it would disappear as soon as the commercial spirit behind khadi disappeared.
('67', 410, 2, 24, 705616) Satisbabu was also anxious that in no case should the workmen’s minimum wage exceed the wage of an agriculturist.
('67', 410, 2, 25, 705730) There was no such thing as an agriculturist’s wage, explained Gandhiji.
('67', 410, 2, 26, 705802) In many parts of India the peasant hardly got out of his land enough to keep body and soul together, and the peasant who had no land of his own and cultivated it on lease produced not even enough to pay his rent.
('67', 410, 2, 27, 706015) Gandhiji said: The peasant’s condition is no standard.
('67', 410, 2, 28, 706070) The only standard is to get the daily bread.
('67', 410, 2, 29, 706115) To seek to pay anything less would be called criminal.
('67', 410, 2, 30, 706170) Harijan, 14 9 1935

('67', 411, 1, 2, 706231) 636. NOTES
('67', 411, 2, 3, 706242) HARIJAN DAY
('67', 411, 3, 4, 706254) The Central Office of the Harijan Sevak Sangh has issued the following circular:
('67', 411, 4, 5, 706335) The Harijan Sevak Sangh will complete the third year of its existence by the end of September, and the Poona Pact agreed to by the leaders of caste Hindus and Harijans was signed at Poona on the 24th September 1932. It is therefore natural that the end of September, and more specially the 24th of September, should be considered an important date in the life of the Harijan Sevak Sangh.
('67', 411, 4, 6, 706723) The Executive Committee of the Sangh which recently met at Wardha has therefore resolved that the 24th September be celebrated both by caste Hindus and Harijans all over the country in the following manner:
('67', 411, 5, 7, 706930) (a) On that day all Harijan sevaks should visit Harijan bastis in the morning and speak to Harijans on the importance of sanitation and perform some personal service for them however small.
('67', 411, 6, 8, 707120) (b) In the evening Harijan and non Harijan children may be taken to open places for sports and entertainments.
('67', 411, 7, 9, 707231) (c) Processions, kirtan or bhajan parties may be organized.
('67', 411, 7, 10, 707291) Public meetings may also be held wherever possible and the solemn pledge of the Hindu community for the abolition of untouchability by birth reiterated.
('67', 411, 8, 11, 707444) (d) Association and sympathizers of the Sangh should be enrolled.
('67', 411, 9, 12, 707510) (e) Collections for the Harijan Wells Fund—the special feature of this year’s work—be continued with zeal and vigour.
('67', 411, 9, 13, 707628) I hope that the Sangh’s appeal will receive ready response from all reformers, both Harijans and non Harijans, no matter to what party they belong.

('67', 412, 3, 15, 709638) 637. FALLACIES
('67', 412, 4, 16, 709653) A careful observer of events and things writes:
('67', 412, 5, 17, 709701) I have no doubt that there is an enormous scope for work in the directions indicated by you in your letter under reply.
('67', 412, 5, 18, 709821) Cottage industries have a place.
('67', 412, 5, 19, 709854) But, to be quite frank, I do not think that these can replace industries on a big scale.
('67', 412, 5, 20, 709943) Leaving aside the financial interests of those controlling such industries, I think that it will not be in the interest of the country to work for the ruin of such industries, which have been established and which can be established in this country.
('67', 412, 5, 21, 710193) The greatest objection to machinery that has been urged is the growing tendency to reduce the number of men employed.
('67', 412, 5, 22, 710311) This results in unemployment.
('67', 412, 5, 23, 710341) The present method of distribution of profits may require readjustment.
('67', 412, 5, 24, 710413) But leisure, if it can be well utilized, is more important than many other things.
('67', 412, 5, 25, 710496) Merely to keep a large number employed at work I do not think it is necessary to discard economic and efficient machinery.
('67', 412, 5, 26, 710619) It should be able to give leisure and food to many, and in this ‘many’ I include people not even distantly connected with the industry.
('67', 412, 5, 27, 710755) With such a large population as in India and steadily increasing I fear that at no time will it be possible to keep everyone in reasonable comfort.
('67', 412, 5, 28, 710903) With improved education and sanitation life will be prolonged and death rate will come down.
('67', 412, 5, 29, 710996) From the
('67', 413, 0, 1, 711005) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 414
('67', 413, 1, 2, 711047) population point of view this will make the condition worse.
('67', 413, 1, 3, 711108) So, you will forgive my saying that the first thing that requires to be done is to take measures to restrict population and it cannot be done without birth control.
('67', 413, 1, 4, 711273) I know that you are against it.
('67', 413, 1, 5, 711305) But now that you are applying your mind solely to the problem of economic reconstruction by improvement in sanitation, food values, cottage industries, etc., I request you to consider if this is not also one of the things that should receive your attention.
('67', 413, 1, 6, 711563) The writer is an honest thinker and yet, as it seems to me, has missed the whole aim of the work being done by the two organizations he has in mind.
('67', 413, 1, 7, 711712) Their aim is not to replace or to ruin the big industries, but it is to revive the dead or dying industries and therethrough to find employment for the millions who are semi starved because they are forced to live in complete or semi idleness.
('67', 413, 1, 8, 711956) This is a constructive, not a destructive, programme.
('67', 413, 1, 9, 712010) The big industries can never, they don’t hope to, overtake the unemployed millions.
('67', 413, 1, 10, 712094) Their aim is primarily to make money for the few owners, never the direct one of finding employment for the unemployed millions.
('67', 413, 1, 11, 712223) The organizers of khadi and other village industries don’t hope in the near future to affect the big industries.
('67', 413, 1, 12, 712336) They may hope to bring a ray of light into the dark dungeons, miscalled cottages, of the villagers.
('67', 413, 1, 13, 712436) My esteemed correspondent seems to give up his whole case when he says ‘leisure, if it can be well utilized, is more important than many other things’.
('67', 413, 1, 14, 712588) The activities which he disapproves of are intended to accomplish the very end he has in view.
('67', 413, 1, 15, 712683) They are designed to well utilize the leisure hours of the idle millions.
('67', 413, 1, 16, 712757) In this there is no war against the misuse and abuse of machinery, i.e., its use to the detriment of the millions.
('67', 413, 1, 17, 712872) Dead machinery must not be pitted against the millions of living machines represented by the villagers scattered in the several hundred thousand villages of India.
('67', 413, 1, 18, 713036) Machinery to be well used has to help and ease human effort.
('67', 413, 1, 19, 713097) The present use of machinery tends more and more to concentrate wealth in the hands of a few in total disregard of millions of men and women whose bread is snatched by it out of their mouths.
('67', 413, 1, 20, 713289) The movement represented by the A.I.S.A. and the A.I.V.I.A. has been conceived so as to minimize the evil wrought by the craze for amassing large fortunes through the use of dead tools in order to avoid having to deal with very sensitive human tools.
('67', 413, 1, 21, 713540) The writer fears that at no time will it be possible to keep everyone in reasonable comfort.
('67', 413, 1, 22, 713633) This fear is not shared by those who
('67', 414, 0, 1, 713670) VOL. 67 : 25 APRIL, 1935 22 SEPTEMBER, 1935 415
('67', 414, 1, 2, 713718) are working in the villages.
('67', 414, 1, 3, 713747) On the contrary, closer contact with the villagers andcloser knowledge of the villages fill them with the hope that if only the villagers can be induced to shed their traditional idleness they can all live in reasonable comfort, without causing any very great dislocation.
('67', 414, 1, 4, 714020) Certain oppressive conditions have no doubt to be abated.
('67', 414, 1, 5, 714078) But the process will almost be unfelt, if there is some co operation from what are termed vested interests.
('67', 414, 1, 6, 714186) The correspondent’s fear about the securing of reasonable comfort for the existing population leads naturally to the fear of over population.
('67', 414, 1, 7, 714328) The resort to birth control becomes more than the logical step.
('67', 414, 1, 8, 714392) Birth control to me is a dismal abyss.
('67', 414, 1, 9, 714431) It amounts to playing with unknown forces.
('67', 414, 1, 10, 714474) Assuming that birth control by artificial aids is justifiable under certain conditions, it seems to be utterly impracticable of application among the millions.
('67', 414, 1, 11, 714634) It seems to me to be easier to induce them to practise self control than control by contraceptives.
('67', 414, 1, 12, 714734) This little globe of ours is not a toy of yesterday.
('67', 414, 1, 13, 714787) In has not suffered from the weight of over population through its age of countless millions.
('67', 414, 1, 14, 714881) How can it be that the truth has suddenly dawned upon some people that it is in danger of perishing of shortage of food unless birth rate is checked through the use of contraceptives?
('67', 414, 1, 15, 715065) My fear is that my correspondent has led himself from one fallacy to another ending in the quagmire of contraceptives on a scale hitherto unknown.
('67', 414, 2, 16, 715212) Harijan, 14 9 1935

('67', 415, 7, 27, 716622) 640. LETTER TO BISWANATH
('67', 415, 8, 28, 716647) September 14, 1935 MY DEAR BISWANATH, Neither Baba 2 nor Ma should have suppressed you.
('67', 415, 8, 29, 716735) You have a perfect right to write to me as you have now at last done.
('67', 415, 8, 30, 716805) You have a double claim upon me.
('67', 415, 8, 31, 716838) First because you are in an organization of which I am the head and secondly because you are connected with two persons who have for many years accepted my word as law.
('67', 415, 8, 32, 717007) In writing your letter, therefore, you have not only recognized your unadulterated right but you have also performed the duty which you owe to me.
('67', 415, 8, 33, 717154) That you have grievously erred in your writing does not in
('67', 415, 9, 34, 717213) 1 Vide also "Letter to Amrit Kaur”, 10 9 1935 2 Satis Chandra Das Gupta and his wife Hemprabha Das Gupta
('67', 416, 0, 1, 717318) VOL. 67 : 25 APRIL, 1935 22 SEPTEMBER, 1935 417
('67', 416, 1, 2, 717366) any shape or form diminish the value of your letter.
('67', 416, 1, 3, 717419) On the contrary, the value is enhanced in that you have dared to tell me what you hold to be unadulterated truth although it may appear bitter to me and although I may consider it to be the reverse of truth.
('67', 416, 1, 4, 717627) Very often we mount to truth by wading through errors so long [as] they do not appear to us to be errors.
('67', 416, 1, 5, 717733) Your attachment as distinguished from affection for khadi has led you into a maze of errors.
('67', 416, 1, 6, 717826) All India Spinners’ Association is the head and the associations affiliated to it are the branches.
('67', 416, 1, 7, 717926) The head has rights which branches do not and cannot possess.
('67', 416, 1, 8, 717988) What appeared to me at one time a sound policy under given circumstances may prove unsound under altered circumstances or on a fuller perception of even same circumstances.
('67', 416, 1, 9, 718161) I would be an unworthy head of an organization if I sacrificed its interests for a seeming consistency.
('67', 416, 1, 10, 718265) Again the liberties that Baba and Ma have allowed me to take with them and their creation I may not take with others.
('67', 416, 1, 11, 718383) I would never be afraid of being misunderstood by them.
('67', 416, 1, 12, 718439) Every one of my actions in connection with Pratishthan, therefore, you have to interpret in the light of my relationship with Baba and Ma.
('67', 416, 1, 13, 718578) It is a relationship of their creation.
('67', 416, 1, 14, 718618) So much for the Pratishthan.
('67', 416, 1, 15, 718647) Now for my new experiment.
('67', 416, 1, 16, 718674) Since you admit that I am the creator of the khadi movement I must have the right to regulate its growth and even to destroy it.
('67', 416, 1, 17, 718803) He who creates can also recreate.
('67', 416, 1, 18, 718837) And if I found that I made a mistake in fashioning my creation I must have the right to refashion it in any manner I like so long as I carry with me my associates in nursing the creation.
('67', 416, 1, 19, 719025) You would admit that I would be a traitor to myown creation if for fear of the judgement of fellow workers like you I fail to act up to my own judgement if it abide in spite of the criticisms of fellow workers.
('67', 416, 1, 20, 719236) I think this covers all the points that you have raised.
('67', 416, 1, 21, 719293) You may write to me as often as you like till I have convinced you or till you despair of my ever succeeding in convincing you.

('67', 424, 5, 9, 729663) 654. LETTER TO BALVANTSINHA
('67', 424, 6, 10, 729691) MAGANWADI, WARDHA, September 17, 1935
('67', 424, 7, 11, 729729) BALVANTSINHA, Your account of the offering of goats to the goddess made painful reading.
('67', 424, 7, 12, 729818) We cannot in a moment remove superstitions centuries old.
('67', 424, 7, 13, 729876) The people’s hearts, too, will not be prepared to take any note of us till we have performed some tangible service apparent to them.
('67', 424, 7, 14, 730009) The approach to their intellect is even more difficult.
('67', 424, 7, 15, 730065) The very spirit of ahimsa is a matter of the heart only, it touches the intellect in a much lesser degree.
('67', 424, 7, 16, 730172) Hearts can be reached soon enough by disinterested service.
('67', 424, 7, 17, 730232) Therefore our present duty consists of service among those making the goat offering to the goddeses and we shall as the occasion arises remove their superstition.
('67', 424, 7, 18, 730395) Keep in mind that the scene witnessed by you among the uneducated can be seen among the educated, too, in Calcutta and that on a vast scale.
('67', 424, 7, 19, 730536) The other incident also is of the same category 1 though not so painful or unbearable and the remedy is the same.
('67', 424, 7, 20, 730650) I am not aware if Krishnadas has taken with him the seeds, etc.
('67', 424, 7, 21, 730714) Your letter came into my hands after he had left.
('67', 424, 7, 22, 730764) Yes, the patient from Delhi is Harishchandra.
('67', 424, 7, 23, 730810) Dr. Pingle is treating him with massage, etc., and they both have good hope of his recovery.

('67', 425, 0, 1, 731107) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 426
('67', 425, 1, 2, 731149) 655. LETTER TO BRIJKRISHNA CHANDIWALA
('67', 425, 2, 3, 731187) MAGANWADI, WARDHA, September 18, 1935
('67', 425, 3, 4, 731225) BRIJKRISHNA,
('67', 425, 4, 5, 731238) The question you have raised at this late date surprises me.
('67', 425, 4, 6, 731299) What is the meaning of absolution of sins?
('67', 425, 4, 7, 731342) Who is to absolve and why?
('67', 425, 4, 8, 731369) Such language is used only by those who have no doubts because in talking of absolution they imply purification of man.
('67', 425, 4, 9, 731489) But basically the effect of sin needs must be endured.
('67', 425, 4, 10, 731544) One who endures it intelligently does not sin again and becomes pure.
('67', 425, 4, 11, 731614) This is the meaning of being absolved.
('67', 425, 4, 12, 731653) Absolution can never mean that man may continue to sin and seek forgiveness over and over again.
('67', 425, 4, 13, 731750) One who has been forgiven does not sin again and, if he does, the absolution is no absolution.
('67', 425, 4, 14, 731845) Secondly, why must we regard every ailment as a visitation for our sins?
('67', 425, 4, 15, 731918) Why should we not regard it as a blessing of God?
('67', 425, 4, 16, 731968) That is, we can interpret both ways and improve ourselves either way.
('67', 425, 4, 17, 732038) Nair wrote to me, too.
('67', 425, 4, 18, 732061) I would not like to interfere any more.
('67', 425, 4, 19, 732101) You may yourself write to Nair.
('67', 425, 4, 20, 732133) If he is indispensable for the Ashram he may suspend the training and come away.
('67', 425, 4, 21, 732214) And if he comes he should be given complete authority and whatever financial assistance he may need.
('67', 425, 4, 22, 732315) Whatever is to be said may be said only by way of advice.
('67', 425, 4, 23, 732373) He may then act according to his judgment.
('67', 425, 5, 24, 732416) Blessings from BAPU
('67', 425, 6, 25, 732436) From a photostat of the Hindi: G.N. 2433

('67', 426, 1, 2, 732920) 657. LETTER TO AGATHA HARRISON
('67', 426, 2, 3, 732951) WARDHA, September 20, 1935 MY DEAR AGATHA, I have not been able to write to you for weeks though I have succeeded at times in asking someone to write to you for me.
('67', 426, 2, 4, 733116) All this of course apart from what Mahadev and Chandrashanker may be writing to you.
('67', 426, 2, 5, 733201) Your work in connection with Jawaharlal’s release was prompt and glorious.
('67', 426, 2, 6, 733276) As you very properly say, it was more humanitarian than political.
('67', 426, 2, 7, 733343) I am glad, too, that the authorities rose to the occasion and lost not a minute in granting adequate relief.
('67', 426, 2, 8, 733452) At this end, too, our machinery was set in motion.
('67', 426, 2, 9, 733503) The whole thing ended so well.
('67', 426, 2, 10, 733534) This release of Jawaharlal stands out prominently as the one bright spot on the black and mournful surface.
('67', 426, 2, 11, 733642) I know you do not want thanks.
('67', 426, 2, 12, 733673) You may have them by the train load if you want them.
('67', 426, 2, 13, 733727) I know this, that it would have been a severe disappointment to me if you had not acted as you did.
('67', 426, 2, 14, 733827) You have accustomed me to look for such prompt and decisive action on your part.
('67', 426, 2, 15, 733908) Do please, however, thank all those who helped you and made your difficult mission so completely successful.
('67', 426, 2, 16, 734017) You did well in flying to Badenweiler.
('67', 426, 2, 17, 734056) 1 I am eagerly looking forward to your description of the visit.
('67', 426, 2, 18, 734121) There can be no doubt that, if we really ever succeed in disturbing God’s plans and if God has any plans, these efforts resulting in Jawaharlal’s reaching there have prolonged Kamala’s life.
('67', 426, 2, 19, 734312) I am old fashioned enough to believe that not a blade of grass moves but by His will.
('67', 426, 2, 20, 734398) Then, too, I can derive ample satisfaction in the knowledge that you and other friends conspired to fulfil God’s purpose and therefore whilst you were doing your duty angels above were saying, ‘well done, well, done’.
('67', 426, 2, 21, 734616) Ghanshyamdas had to leave this morning abruptly, for he received a telegram yesterday that his mother was suffering from fever.
('67', 426, 2, 22, 734744) He would otherwise have stayed here at least four days longer.
('67', 426, 2, 23, 734807) He was able, however, to give me a fair summary of his doings there.
('67', 426, 2, 24, 734876) Charlie must have told you all about the situation here.
('67', 426, 2, 25, 734933) I can add nothing to what he must have said.
